nonproductive transitive suffix. see huaʻi, luaʻi, lumaʻi.
how many? How much? (Follows ʻa-, ʻe-, or pā-.)
hoʻohiki₂. to vow, swear, take an oath, promise; to administer an oath; vow, oath, promise, pledge.
father- or mother-in-law, usually after makua and followed by kāne or wahine for specific designation of sex. These terms apply also to uncle and aunt by marriage.
nominalizer noted in pale, to ward off, and palekana, safety; pili, to cling, and pilikana, relative.
indicator of plurality in the plural pronouns and possessives only (kākou, mākou, ʻoukou, lākou).

intensifying suffix. see:
   auwalakī₁,₂,  entangled, snarled...  destitute (wala to fall backwards...)
   halakī. to go off course, miss the way. (hala to pass by, miss...)
   hilikī, to hit carelessly, at random (hili₃ to whip, smite, thrash, switch, bat...)
   kūpakakī, intensive of kūpaka, kick, thrash... 
   makakī, to look at with hatred. (maka eye, face...)
   mōkākī, scattered, littered, mess... (moka offal, waste matter, refuse, filth...)
   pakakī₁. to talk irrationally, loudly, or contentiously... (paka₂ to criticize constructively, to look for flaws...)
   pūkalakī, rough, boisterous, as wind; ruffled, mussed... (pukakala rough, coarse... )
   walawalakī, to fall back; to plummet to the ground... (wala to fall backwards...)
transitivizer, as in kaulaʻi, kulaʻi, lualaʻi.
dual number in pronouns and possessives, as ʻolua, kāua, māua.
a rare transitivizer. cf. hili, to wander, and hilinaʻi, to believe; pī, to sprinkle, and pīnaʻi, to fill a crack;
common nominalizing suffix, sometimes with shortening of a long vowel in the base.
second person singular poss. suffix in kāu and kou, your.
indicator of the dual number in first and third persons of pronouns and poss. only (kāua, māua, lāua).
many. (Eight being a sacred number may have led to this extension of the meaning.)

simulative ligature in the sequence 'verb + noun' compounds; particle for forming verb compounds; like, similar to. 
usu. verb + ā + noun:
     ʻaiāmanō eat like a shark, have a prodigious appetite
     ʻaiāpuaʻa eat like a pig
     hanuāpuaʻa breathe like a pig, gasp for breath
     heleāiʻa (= holoāiʻa) swim like a fish
     heleāwai  flow like water
     hikiāloa long-range, long-term
     holoāiʻa swim like a fish
     huliāmahi turn like a strong (cock); cooperation, strength
     kaheāwai flowing like water
     kaʻiālupe lit. to lead like a kite (support a person between two others)
     kūākanaka turn into a man, look like a man
     kūākiʻi stand with hands on hips... like a statue...
     kūāmaʻi very sick
     mokuāhana dividing into factions
     mokuāhua grief, pity, disappointment
     mokuāwai burst as floodwaters, rush as a crowd
     paiālewa tossed here and there (lit., lift into space)
     paʻiāumi beat one's chest (as in lamentation)
     pukaāmaka to appear to the eyes (seal a relationship of two families by marriage)
    ʻumiāpuaʻa strangled like pigs
also verb + ā + verb:
     uhaiāholo chase like running
     uluāhewa mania, delusion; grow wild and lush
pejorative suffix, often written wā after o or u. see ʻaiā, haiā, hainā, huā (huwā), kauā (kauwā), lonoā, (lonowā), mākoeā, naʻauʻauā (naʻauʻauwā), poluā (poluwā)
personal article occurring only after the preposition i, written ia.
first person singular poss. suffix in kaʻu, koʻu, and kuʻu, mine, my.
a lua fighting stroke. lit., the liver of Milu
name of the 14th night of the full moon.
name of a star, probably used in navigation.
name of a downtown Honolulu street. lit., white road.
lua fighting stroke. lit., stairway of the shrimp.
a wind of Mānoa Valley, Honolulu.
name of a Kauaʻi wind, said to bring good weather. lit., happy path.
name of a star said to be in the Milky Way.
name of a star, possibly Jupiter, lit., star light.
abbreviation for ʻāpana, land parcel, used in surveying.
name of a star, companion to Hōkūʻula and Paikauhale. Perhaps the three are Sigma, Antares, and Tau Scorpii.
name of a stroke in lua fighting. lit.., tropic bird hastens, it is calm.
name for the trade wind. see ex., kiʻekiʻe.
abbreviation of ʻākau, north, as in surveying reports.
name of a lua stroke. lit., let the hero of Mānoa return, [it's] evening. (E- is sometimes omitted.)
a lua fighting stroke. lit., the birds of Kānealoha tear to bits.
type of lua fighting in which the contestants did not use their hands, but fought with feet, legs, shoulders, head.
name of a star associated with Hanakauluna, considered a sign of pestilence or calamity; also the name of a legendary place.
name of a constellation. lit., chicken roost.

Prince Albert, only son of Kamehameha IV and Queen Emma who died at the age of four in 1862, "leaving his father and mother heartbroken and the native community in desolation". lit., lord of Hawaiʻi. See chant, kiakahi.
name of a star. lit., lord of dark night.

a romantic Oʻahu anti-hero who wooed, sometimes with success, the beautiful but fickle Puna princess, Kamalālāwalu. The account of the kilu (quoits) match contains some of the most beautiful of Hawaiian poetry. At the end of the tale the lovers apparently tire of one another. see ʻAikanaka₃.  lit., many houses.
name of a Hāna wind. lit., grass house.
name of a pleasure-loving chief of Niʻihau in ancient times. His name became synonymous with fun-making.
bay, valley (only in place names, as Hanalei, Hanapēpē. Also Hono-, as in Honolulu).
an ancient chief of Hilo whose name was used in poetry to designate the Hilo district.
name of a star associated with Hanakauluna, and the name of a legendary place. lit., Hana, the abundant food.
name of a star associated with Hanakalauʻai, and Hakalauʻai; all were omens of pestilence or calamity.
name of a death stroke in lua fighting.
name of a large valley on Kauaʻi. lit., lei  valley. see saying kaupoku₁.
a stroke in lua fighting. lit., rising breath.
name of a handsome surfer of Kauaʻi who vainly wooed Lāʻieikawai (SH 214-15); also a place name on Kauaʻi.
a lua fighting stroke. lit., the blow enters...
a personal name. lit., ruling royal chief (this meaning is based solely on historical evidence: see hau-₂).

an earth-mother goddess equated with Papa, Laʻilaʻi₃, and Kāmehaʻikana, the 'great source of female fertility' (HM 185) who bore children in successive generations. She is also called '[Haumea] … of mysterious forms, Haumea of eightfold forms, Haumea of four-hundred-thousand-fold forms...' (KL. 232). She married Wākea and later married Hāloa, her husband's son by his own daughter Hoʻohokukalani. Haumea had many other husbands. She is considered the mother of Pele and of Pele's many siblings who were born from her mouth or armpits. She presided over childbirth. Beckwith has summarized the many tales about her (HM 276-290). see Kaulu; Punaʻaikoaʻe; Kāmehaʻikana. lit., red ruler.
name of a star in the Milky Way.
name of a wind associated with Kailua quadrangle, Hawaiʻi. lit., cool [wind] of Māʻihi (a wind goddess whose full name was Māʻihiʻalakapualono, fragrant sacred Māʻihi [child] of Lono).
a lua fighting stroke. lit., the drowned blow...
name of a legendary figure believed by some to have discovered Hawaiʻi, but see Barrère-1969; place name. lit. distant Hawaiʻi.
a forest-dwelling goddess of tapa makers and bird catchers, sometimes referred to in chants as Haʻiwahine or Haʻi.
a legendary woman who had many adventures. She was deserted by her husband and ran away crazed at Waipiʻo, Hawaiʻi. lit., grumbling answer.
variant name for Haʻinakolo₁, a forest-dwelling goddess of tapa makers and bird catchers...
var. spelling of Haʻinakolo₁ a forest-dwelling goddess...
rain name associated with Poʻo-kū, Kauaʻi. lit., stepping upon pandanus flowers.
the planet Uranus, formerly called Hershel for its discoverer, Sir William Hershel, in 1781.
abbreviation used in surveying for hema, south.
name of a misty rain observed off the coast of Hilo when nehu fish are running.
name of an unknown person, used something like so-and-so, usually followed by mā.

name of the wife of the famous legendary navigator, Pākaʻa and of the coastal area, Molokaʻi, where she lived. She was lost during labor pains and her husband searched vainly for her, hence the saying applied to fruitless endeavors, Hikauhi i Kaumanamana, Hikauhi is at Kaumanamana [another place on Molokaʻi]. [cf slightly different explanation at (ON 1162)]
name of a star, described as medium-bright and near the equator; visible from April to September; used as a guide to mariner and fisherman.
name of a star; according to some, Sirius.
wind name associated with Hālawa, Molokaʻi.
Kauaʻi name for the star Hikianalia.
generally known as Hiku, this hero was the son of Kū-ʻōhiʻa-laka and the goddess Hina. lit., Hiku in the forest.
name of a star and of a Hawaiian month (same as Māhoe Mua: see month).
name of the eleventh month (Molokaʻi) eighth (Kauaʻi), or tenth (Alexander).
first night of the new moon. See (Malo 35).
name of a famous Polynesian navigator for whom the city and district may have been named. see sayings, Hilo (Eng.-Hawaiian)
a Hawaiian star and month name.

vague accounts (HM 214) mention this goddess as being born in the undersea land Kahikihonuakele (wet land Kahiki), and as floating on the sea and becoming a gourd bailer—Hinaikekā (Hina in the bailer) (KL. 235). In some stories she makes tapa in the moon (HM 220). She was also called Hinahanaakamalama (Hina foster-child of the moon), the name of Queen Emma's home in Nuʻu-anu Valley, Honolulu. lit., Hina in the moon. see ʻAikanaka₃; Hema.

goddess of canoe bailers, sometimes called the sister of Hina who was the mother of Māui (HM 219), or equated with the mother of corals, Hinaʻōpūhalakoʻa. Most commonly she took the form of a gourd canoe bailer (kā); Wākea found her floating and took her into his canoe. lit., Hina (in) the bailer. see Hinaikamalama; Pīmoe.
name of a chief in whose time occurred a famous deluge called kai a ka Hinaliʻi; the Biblical flood (Kin. 6.17) . See saying ʻiliki₁.
name of a star that appears in the month of Hilinehu and follows in its course the star Polowehilani [Polo-Wehi-Lani].
name of a star, said to be the tutelary star of Hāna, Maui.

goddess of food plants (HM 69), also known as Hinahele, and sister of Hinapukuiʻa. She assumed the form of Lea, and as an ʻelepaio flycatcher alighted on trees that canoe makers wanted to cut; if she pecked a tree, canoe makers knew that it was insect ridden and not suitable for a canoe. The spot where she landed on a felled tree was to be the prow; she then ran toward the stern. lit., Hina gathering vegetable food.

goddess of corals and spiny creatures of the sea, appearing as a woman and as a coral reef. From her shells Māui made his famous hook for drawing the islands together. lit., Hina stomach passing coral.

a goddess associated with Kū (upright), with whom she had incestuous relations. Hina in this instance means 'prostrate.' When gathering medicine with their left hands, people prayed to Hina for success. See Hikuikanahele, Kū.
a goddess... Probably the most widely known goddess or demigoddess of Polynesia, frequently connected with the moon. Four well-known Hawaiian Hinas follow.
wife of Akalana and mother of Māui. see Kaʻalaenuiahina and (HM 220).

mother of Kamapuaʻa by Kahikiʻula and referred to in chants by her mother, Kamaunuaniho, in order to save Kamapuaʻa in time of peril (FS 196-203). When she failed to recognize her pig son, Kamapuaʻa, in human form, she exposed herself in humiliation (FS 242-249).
a wife of Wākea and the mother of the island of Molokaʻi, celebrated in the song Molokaʻi Nui a Hina, Great Molokaʻi Child of Hina.

Pele's favorite younger sister born from the mouth of Haumea rather than from the bosom, as were the many other Hiʻiaka sisters ((Westervelt p. 69), says there may have been forty sisters). Born as an egg, she was carried under Pele's bosom until she became a young beauty. She is the heroine of the epic concerning her trip from Kīlauea Volcano  to Kauaʻi  to find and fetch Pele's dream lover, Lohi'au; on her long and dangerous journey she transformed many evil moʻo into stones which are still visible (see PH). One of her forms was the palaʻā lace fern used to treat diseases and one of the first plants to grow on new lava. As the physician of the Pele family, she resuscitated Lohiʻau. She instituted the eating of fish from head to tail. She was worshiped by hula dancers. lit., Hiʻiaka in the bosom of Pele.
first part of the names of the twelve younger sisters of the goddess Pele; the youngest and most famous was Hiʻiakaikapoliopele. see (PH).
name of a star said to rise on the night of Hoaka and to vanish on the night of Muku in the month of Welehu.
name of the highest waterfall in Hawaiʻi, and one of the highest in the world, with a vertical drop of about 300 m, at Waipiʻo Valley, Hawaiʻi. see (EM 49), for a famous song.
name of a star that rises and vanishes at the same times as Hiʻikua.
night of the full moon. When this moon set before daylight it was called Hoku Palemo, Hoku that slips away. When it set after daylight it was called Hoku Ili grounded Hoku.
name of a star, perhaps Mars.
name of a legendary star (Kep. 77) that guided Hawaiʻinui on his return to Kahikihonuakele after discovering Hawaiʻi.
wind famous at Waipiʻo, Hawaiʻi. lit., running in the hollows.
semi-weekly newspaper in Hawaiian and Eng. published 1901–02.

bay, gulch, valley (as a part of place names such as Honolulu, Honokōhau, Honoliʻi, Honomanu; also in the poetic phrase nā Honō a Piʻilani, the bays beginning with Hono- of Piʻilani [a chief who ruled the bays on Maui, Molokaʻi, and Lānaʻi that were visible from Lahaina]. Hana- occurs similarly as in Hanalei and Hanauma.
name of the capital city in the Hawaiian Islands lit., sheltered bay.
name of a strong wind threatening to be a gale

the daughter of Wākea and Papa, the ancestors of the Hawaiians. Wākea instituted taboo nights so that he might sleep with Hoʻohoku. The root -hoku may be cognate with Tahitian hotu, to produce fruit, and Tongan fotu, to appear; if so, the translation would be 'to bear fruit in the heavens'.
name of a strong, north wind associated with Makaiwa, Kauaʻi; Hāna, Maui; and Hālawa, Molokaʻi. At Hālawa the name may be qualified by Iho, Kaʻi, Kele, Pehu, Wahakole
night of the day called Huna₃, eleventh night of the month, when the hoʻāo nuptials took place.
name of the thirteenth night of the lunar month.
name of a strong northwesterly wind of the winter months. Also Kiu Inu Wai and Mālua Kiʻi Wai.
Pacific Yacht Club. lit., Pacific ship racing club.
a name for Pleiades. lit., Makaliʻi's net hanging above.
Hudson, as the river or bay.
name of a wind at Lahaina, Maui. lit., turn to the face of the cliff.
name for the cluster of three stars in a row in the constellation Aquila. lit., Humu and companions.
name of a place on the slopes of Mauna Kea.
the star Altair, in Aquila, said to have been used for navigation from Hawaiʻi to Tahiti. Also Hoʻohumu.
oppressive older brother of ʻUmi... see ʻUmi₃.
a star, said to be observed in the month of Hilinehu.
name of a lua fighting stroke. lit., Hāmākua of the bowers fragrant with pandanus.
name of Queen Emma's residence in Nuʻu-anu Valley.
name of a district and town, East Maui.
name of a famous evil sorcerer. See lauhue₁, for figurative meaning.
name of a rain at ʻAuʻaulele, Kaʻū and at Nuʻuanu, Oʻahu, so called because its showers follow one another like members of a chief's retinue.
place names on Hawaiʻi, Kauaʻi, and Oʻahu.
a Kauaʻi peak. see saying, keha.
a Hawaiian constellation, perhaps Boōtes. lit., frigate-bird star.
Morning Star, Venus when seen in the morning.
the star Sirius. lit., canoe-guiding star.
a navigational star, probably Arcturus; a zenith star above Hawaiʻi. lit., clear (or happy) star.
a name for the Milky Way. lit., ruling star.
name of a constellation, perhaps Leo or the head of Cetus. lit., fence star.
name of a star. lit., very dark star.
a star, perhaps Mars, but see Auhaele. lit., red star.
name of a mythical place. Stars observed by priests were Hōlani-aliʻi and Hōlani-kū.
rain name associated with Hawaiʻi and Oʻahu.

a dancer who was turned into a balancing rock by Pele at Puna, Hawaiʻi...  A girl friend of Pele's little sister, Hiʻiakaikapoliopele. When Hiʻiaka left to fetch Pele's dream lover, Lohiʻau, from Kauaʻi, she entrusted Hōpoe and her favorite lehua groves to Pele. Pele became jealous of Hiʻiaka, burned the lehua groves, and changed Hōpoe into a balancing rock at Keaʻau, Puna, Hawaiʻi (HM 181). The stone may still be there, and waves lapping against it suggest movement; hence Hōpoe, famous as a hula dancer, is mentioned in songs as ka wahine hoʻolewa i ke kai, the woman shaking hips in the sea. lit., fully developed, as a lehua flower. Other names are Hōpoe-lehua and Hōpoe-wahine.
Protestant. lit., Denier of the Pope.
stand! Take your places! Get ready! Let's go!
name of a wind blowing down from the uplands of Kawela, Oʻahu. lit., cold nose.
name reported for a Hawaiian star, although it may be a general term for any guiding star standing (kū) above the bow (ihu) of a canoe.
deadly stroke in lua fighting. lit., nose of the pig.
name of a star. lit., in the mountain area occupied by gods or high chiefs.
name of a month in the summer season.  see month.
name of a sea breeze. lit., water drinking.
the planet Jupiter, originally known as Kaʻāwela.
name of a star and of an ancient chief of Hawaiʻi.
name of a stroke in lua fighting. lit., fish touching skin of man.
name of a wind at Wailuku, Maui, at Hoʻolehua, Molokaʻi (For. 5:101), and at Hāna, Maui. lit., little fish.
Milky Way. lit., fish jumping in shadows.

name of the Hawaiian newspaper printed by students of the Hawaiian language at the University of Hawaiʻi at Mānoa, begun in 1971. lit., the growing bitter yam [or happiness; see hoi₁ and hoi₂ for word play]. [online here at Ka Ulu Hoi Index]
star name, said to be the twentieth in the Milky way. lit., going to Kahaʻi [hero's name].
the youngest and most important of the Maile sisters. lit., the pandanus of wafted fragrance.

a Mānoa beauty, the wife of Kauhi. In the legend gossips told Kauhi that she was unfaithful. He led her to a forest on Ka'ala mountain and slowly beat her to death and buried her under an ʻōhiʻa tree. Passers-by restored her to life. (HM 152-153). In the story as told by Westervelt (Old Honolulu, pp. 128-130), her cruel lover, a Waikiki chief, killed her three times; each time she was resuscitated by an owl god, Pueoaliʻi. lit., the pandanus of Puna.
a lua fighting stroke. lit., the blow enters.
a lua fighting stroke. lit., the drowned blow.
name of an ancient chief associated with Niʻihau. lit., the royal going.
name of a district or ahupuaʻa on Maui. lit., great Tahiti.

name of a legendary tree and place in the uplands of Kauaʻi (FS 233), probably a var. of Kahilikolo. Kamapuaʻa used the tree as a club with which he knocked away (kuehu) his foesʻ clubs from their hands, enabling him to kill them.
name of a navigation star, said to be named for one of the eight steersmen of Hawaiʻiloa.

Tahiti. The sky was divided into five areas beginning with the term Kahiki: 
      Kahikimoe, horizon; lit., prostrate Kahiki. 
      Kahikikū, sky just above the horizon; lit., upright Kahiki. 
      Kahikikapapanuʻu, the next layer; lit., Kahiki the elevated stratum
      Kahikikapapalani, high in the sky, almost directly overhead; lit., Kahiki the sky (or god) stratum.
      Kahikikapuihōlanikekuʻina, the sky directly overhead; lit., sacred Kahiki at Hōlani the meeting place
a variety of banana, common wild on Maui. Kinds are kahiki hae, kahiki mauki, and kahiki puhi.
name of a legendary chief in whose time was a great sea flood (HM 315), (Malo Ch. 58), perhaps a tsunami.

the only uninhabited major Hawaiian Island. In prehistoric times 80 men, sent front Hawaiʻi, dug a well ten fathoms deep at Keanapou. lit., the taking away [as by currents], see Kanaloa₄ and saying, kūpala₄.

a god, said to be in the Pele family, sometimes associated with the underworld. During makahiki rituals for Kū, he was impersonated by a naked man, and was presented the eye of a human victim or of a bonito (aku) or ulua fish. lit., the chiefly companion.
Mediterranean Sea. lit., sea middle earth.
place name at Kona, Hawaiʻi, said to be the name of a canoe bailer for Keawe-nui-a-ʻUmi.
name of a pleasant, gentle trade-wind breeze, famous in song, at Waiʻanae, Oʻahu.
a lua fighting stroke. lit., fish touching human skin.
a valley on northwest Kauaʻi, uninhabited and difficult of access in 1977.
wind name. lit., the peace spread far. See chant, hiʻia. cf. the island Raʻiatea.

name of a surf at Waikīkī. lit., the opening lehua, said to be so named when the taboo on surfing at Waikīkī was broken by a young chief from Mānoa who removed his lehua lei and gave it to the daughter of Chief Kākuhihewa, who had been the only one permitted to surf there; the taboo was broken when the princess accepted the lei.

land section, channel, stream, valley, elementary school, field, street, and shopping center, Honolulu, said to have been named by Prince Lot (afterwards Kamehameha V) in 1856. Kalihi in Honolulu is famous in legend as the home of Pele's sister Kapo (HM 186), and of Haumea, Pele's mother who is identified with Papa, the wife of Wākea. She had many adventures at Kalihi and saved her husband Wākea, who was being taken away for sacrifice, by embracing him. His bonds loosened and the two disappeared into a tree. Kaʻieʻie was a heiau here for her worship.
a lua fighting stroke, named for a limu associated with Hanalei, Kauaʻi (see limukākanaka).
a lua fighting stroke. lit., neat length.
name of a star. lit., the pit of dregs.
name of a star. lit., the pit of the bamboo.
star or stars, probably Pleiades.  see Pleiades.
name of a star; probably this and Kamaile Mua were a star pair, such as Castor and Pollux or Alpha and Beta Centauri. lit., the last maile vine.
star name, perhaps same as Unulau.
name of a star. lit., the light.
a lua fighting stroke. lit., the malo of Līloa (This malo, of red feathers, is preserved in the Bishop Museum.)

a Maui chief who sent his son to spy on Hawaiʻi. The latter reported the island undefended. Kamalālāwalu invaded with an enormous army, found many people (see lēʻī) and, as a result of a series of stupid actions, was annihilated with his forces by the Hawaiʻi chief, Lonoikamakahiki.
the Puna princess wooed by Halemano. lit., child [with] eight [family] lines.

a pig demigod... The pig demigod whose rootings created valleys and springs. He leaned against the cliffs at Kaliuwaʻa, Oahu (where a troughlike depression is still visible) to allow his family to climb up his body and escape Chief ʻOlopana₁. He had many affairs and is a symbol of lechery. He exchanged ribald taunts with Pele and then called on his plant forms — olomea, hala (pandanus), ʻuhaloa, ʻamaʻumaʻu (ferns) — to block her advancing fires, which they did (FS 228-229). He finally mated with Pele, taking for himself Hilo, Hāmākua, and Kohala, and allotting Kaʻū, Puna, and Kona to Pele. When he fought the dog Kūʻīlioloa he called on his kukui, ʻuhaloa, and ʻāmaʻumaʻu forms to hold the dog's mouth open; he then multiplied himself into many pigs and entered the mouth to kill the dog (FS 214-215). Other forms included a handsome man, kūkaepuaʻa grass, clouds, the humuhumunukunukuāpuaʻa fish, and the god Lono. lit., hog man. see Makaliʻi₄; ʻOlopana₁. (FS 196–249). see texts.
a lua fighting stroke. lit., the bitter sickness.
the constellation Gemini. lit., the twins.
name of a star. lit., the calm.
name of a star. lit., the last calm.
name of a star. lit., the first calm.

a major god... One of the four great gods. His name was not coupled with innumerable epithets, as were the names of the others. His companion and leader was Kāne. They were renowned as kava drinkers, and they found water in many places. Three days of the lunar month were sacred to Kanaloa — the twenty-fourth (Kāloa-Kū-Kahi), the twenty-fifth (Kāloa-Kū-Lua), and the twenty-sixth (Kāloa-Pau). Some considered him a god of the sea, and in Christian times he was equated with Satan. Emerson (Malo 111) gives a healing prayer to him as god of squids (he had this form, as well as that of the ʻalaʻala-pū-loa weed).
name of a star, said to be the tutelary star of Chief Kaumualiʻi [Ka-umu-aliʻi] of Kauaʻi.

Canaan. (for Hawaiian glottal stop, (Gram. 2.9.3))

----------------------------------------
Kanaʻana
Canaan.
a stroke in lua fighting, for chiefs.

a demigod... The stretching demigod born as a rope on Maui. He could stretch from Molokaʻi to Hawaiʻi and wade in the deep sea. His exploits explain gashes, ledges, and footprints on the islands. He restored the sun and, with his brother Nīheu, rescued his mother, Hina, who had been stolen (not, perhaps, against her will) by a Molokaʻi chief.  Emerson calls him a god of jugglers. (Malo 227-229, Emerson note).
name of a star. lit., lost sound.
rain that accompanies the Koʻolau wind. lit., cane-tapping.
name of a mistlike rain famous at Hilo. lit., [rain that] lehua flowers drink. [An alternate interpretation is "rain that makes lehua flowers rustle."]
name of a star. lit., the Pleiades mist.
Hyades. lit., the opening of the fireplace.
name of a constellation said to preside over the destiny of Hanalei, Kauaʻi (no data).
Aldebaran, a star in the horns of the constellation Alpha Tauri.
northeast trade wind in some localities, as at Hāna, Maui.
name of a star. lit., the pawa or predawn hour.
name for the nether world, where ghosts of men strove to appease hunger by eating moths and lizards.
a lua fighting stroke. lit., the navel of Wākea.
a lua fighting stroke. lit., the clinging [to] fingernail.

more commonly known as Kapo, this unusual goddess was a sister of Pele and daughter of Haumea. She had a dual nature — as a benevolent hula goddess identified with Laka, and as a fierce goddess of sorcery. At Maunaloa, Molokai, she entered an ʻohe tree and poisoned it (see kālaipāhoa). She saved Pele from being raped by Kamapuaʻa by sending her flying vagina (kohe lele) as a lure. Kama followed this to Koko Head, Oahu, where it left an imprint. Later Kapo hid it in Kalihi Valley. (HM 187, 212-213). Kapo was also called Kapokohelele. As a hula goddess, one of her forms was the hala-pepe tree, branches of which were therefore placed on hula altars. lit., Kapo red dotted with dark.
a lua fighting stroke. lit., fireplace of Kuʻialua [a god].
name of a star, perhaps the same as Kanukuokapuahi.
a lua fighting stroke. lit., the pig strikes body hair.
a lua fighting stroke, reserved for chiefs. lit., footprint of Kana, a stretching demigod.
wind name. lit., the raging rain.
name of a star associated with Kohala, Hawaiʻi.
a star, possibly Sirius. lit., placed in holy stillness. Other names are Kauluikua, Kauʻōpae, Hoʻokelewaʻa, ʻAʻā and ʻĀikikauelono. This star was used by navigators and fishermen.
Kauaʻi (name of one of the Hawaiian islands), Kauaʻi person.  (perhaps kau, to place + -aʻi, transitivizer.)
a strong mountain wind, often destructive, at Lahaina, Maui. lit., the red rain [referring to red soil washed away by a storm].
name of an unknown lazy man.
a lua fighting stroke. Uhumākaʻikaʻi was the name of the giant uhu fish that dragged Kawelo for two days in his canoe from Waiʻanae to Niʻihau and back to Waiʻanae.
name of a star that rises with Kawelolani in the month of ʻIkuā.
name of a star, Acubeus; a poetic name for the west.
name of a star called the chief of the month of Ikiiki because it appears in that month.
probably same as Liolioiwawau, a star name.
probably same as ʻAʻā, Sirius. (cf. Maori Te-Kokota; the present Hawaiian form may have metathesized from an earlier ʻOkaʻoka)

names of several stars begin thus; see:
     Kaulu₂, Southern Cross. also Newe.
     Kaulua₃, one of the many names for the star Sirius; 
     Kauluakoko, Betelgeuse
     Kauluikua, star name, perhaps same as ʻAʻā, Sirius. 
     Kaulu Koʻakoʻa, probably same as ʻAʻā, Sirius. 
     Kaulu Lena,  same as ʻAʻā, Sirius.
     Kauluwena, star name, no data.

one of the many names for the star Sirius; according to some reports, a constellation. The name may be qualified by the terms koko (said to be Betelgeuse), Lena (Sirius), Mōhaʻi (or Haʻi Mōhaʻi), Okaoka.
star name, perhaps same as ʻAʻā, Sirius.

a trickster demigod born as a rope. In human form with his strong hands he created surf by breaking the waves; he created small dogs by breaking Kū-ʻīlio-loa (Kū long dog) into pieces. He made the sea salty by draining it and spitting it out. Makaliʻi gave him his nets and he entangled and killed Haumea. (HM 436-437). He defeated Lonoka‘eho and gained control of Koʻolau, Oahu (For. 5:370-371). lit., the inspired one.
name of a star in the northern sky that served as guide to mariners.
a lua fighting stroke. lit., the mouth of the shark.
name of a constellation in the Milky Way. lit., precipice of Makaliʻi.
name of a star appearing in the month of Hilina-mā. lit., the great forests of Life.
site of a jail in Kalihi, Honolulu.
name of a star said to rise during the month of Hilinehu, and to be accompanied by the star Kamalama. lit., the royal family.
name of a star that rises with Kaukamalama in the month of ʻIkuwā and disappears shortly.

a hero born at Hanamāʻulu, Kauai, who killed ʻAikanaka's warriors and finally drove ʻAikanaka into exile. (ʻAikanaka was a Kauai chief who had mistreated Kawelo's parents.) This is one of the most richly detailed of Hawaiian legends. lit., the family trait. Kawelo's full name was Kaweloleimakua (Kawelo beloved of parents).
a lua fighting stroke. lit., the feather cloak.
name of a star or constellation, said to be on the border of the Milky Way.

a sorcery god (Malo 82) or goddess (HM 115). lit., the great mudhen of Hina [Hina was the mother of Māui, who learned the art of fire-making from a mudhen; Emerson (Malo 103) says Hina herself was the mudhen].
name of a star, said to be the tutelary star of Niʻihau.
name of a month. see month.
a lua fighting stroke. lit., the floating chin.
a fine rain in Kohala, Hawaiʻi.
star name, probably the same as Hōkūloa, Venus. lit., the messenger of the dawn.
name of a wind of Kalelewaʻa, Molokaʻi.
a lua fighting stroke; fish was taboo to learners. lit., the hawk.
a lua fighting stroke. lit., the soaring petrel.
a lua fighting stroke. lit., the petrel trespasses.
a lua fighting stroke. lit., the swinging petrel.
a rocky islet off Niʻihau.  [Kaʻula was famous for its birds: see examples].
name of a wind associated with Pōhakuloa, Maui.
name of a planet, probably Venus or Jupiter. (Probably the same as Hōkūloa (Kep. 82), Hōkūao and Kalaniʻōpuʻu).
a lua fighting stroke. lit., the wing.
a lua fighting stroke. lit., the foreskin of the dog.
star appearing in month of Kaulua, remaining visible through the month of Ikiiki.
a sky-dwelling god who conducted the souls of dead chiefs. see Kūwahailo.

a supernatural being who lived in the eyeball of the sun (ka ʻōnohi o ka lā). He was taken to Paliuli as a prospective husband for Lāʻieikawai. They went to the sun to live, but on a later journey to the earth he was unfaithful, and Lāʻie banished him to become the first wandering spirit or ghost (lapu).
a lua fighting stroke. Perhaps lit., the copulating scrotum.
name of a district on Hawaiʻi. see epithets, kua₁, Kuehu Lepo, mākaha₁, wehi₃, and chant, kiʻekiʻe.
name of a star that rises in the month of Welehu, accompanied by Keʻalohilani. lit., the firebrand.
a lua fighting stroke; fish was taboo to the learner.
a lua fighting stroke. lit., the liver of Milu.
name of a star. lit., the rolling pathway,
the star Canopus. lit., the chief of the south in the heavens.
name of a southern star, said to be named for an ancient chief.

star appearing on the night of Hoaka in the month of Welehu and vanishing on the night of Muku in the same month. Other stars perhaps rising at about the same time are Hiʻi Lei, Hiʻi Kua, Pākōnane, and Kahulialiʻi.
probably the constellation Lyra, including the star Vega. Kehoʻoea may be a variant.
patron star of Lānaʻi. lit., the life.
name of a star appearing in the month of Māhoe Hope, accompanied by Kaʻaʻei.
star name (no data). lit., the dam within Kahiki.
a lua fighting stroke, lit., the gusty one.
star name, short for Keaolewa. lit., the light [of the] atmosphere.
name of a star that appears on the night of Hoaka in the month of Kaʻaona after the disappearance of Pauahilani; it in turn vanishes in Welehu. lit., the brightness.

a star that rises on the night of Mauli in the month of Welo and continues through the month of Māhoe Mua, when it vanishes on the night of Muku. A ring around it is said to portend a coming revolution. lit., the heavenly brightness.
name of a star visible on the night of Muku in the month of Hinaiaʻeleʻele, rising with Luahoʻomoe.
Assembly Hall, where the Territorial House of Representatives met.
North Star. lit., pillar of salt, so called because, like Lot's wife, it was immovable.
son of Moʻikeha who went to Kahiki to fetch Moʻikeha's adopted son, Laʻamaikahiki.
wind associated with Waiheʻe, Maui, and windward Molokaʻi.
rain associated with Panaʻewa, Hawaiʻi. lit., quenching lehua flowers.
name of a mountain rain. lit., countless lehua blossoms.
name of a wind from the mountains, stronger and cooler than the Kēhau. lit., waterdrinking Kiu.
name of a wind associated with Koʻolau, Kauaʻi.
name of a wind associated with Nā-wiliwili, Kauaʻi.
probably same as Kiu Wai Lehua.
name of a cold wind. lit., Kiu of the lehua honey.
name of a strong, moderately cold northwesterly wind, known as Mālualua, Māluakiʻiwai, and Hoʻolua, in some localities.
cool mountain rain accompanied by wind and fog, sometimes associated with Alakaʻi swamp on Mt. Waiʻaleʻale, Kauaʻi, as well as Nūʻuanu Valley, Oʻahu. see chant, kohāhā.
name of a wind at Mālei, Molokaʻi.
name of a wind blowing from east to west, associated with Hāmākua, Hawaiʻi, and Hāna, Maui. Also Kiu and Koholā Pehu (also of Kī-pahulu, Maui, (Nak. 68)). lit., leaping whale.
name of a wind associated with Hālawa, Molokaʻi.
star said to be named for Kokoiki, Kohala, Hawaiʻi, where it was first observed at the time of Kamehameha's birth. lit., little blood.
wind associated with Moloaʻa, Kauaʻi (For. 5:97) and Kīpahulu, Maui (Nak. 68).
name of a wind usually accompanied by rain, common at Waimea, Hawaiʻi. lit., rough creep.
commissioners to Quiet Land Titles, a board set up by Kamehameha III to settle land claims; it served between 1846 and 1855 and heard more than 11,000 claims (Indices, VII–VIII).
Palm Sunday. (Catholic term.) lit., dominical of the tree branches.
name of a cold Kona storm. A var. name is Kona Hea Puka.
name of a Kona wind with protracted rains. lit., Kona wind smiting bananas.
name of a Kona wind with heavy rain.
name of a Kona wind with slight showers.
name of a cold Kona wind. lit., withering Kona.
name of a cold Kona wind and rain.
name of a star, Agena; probably short for Kukuiakonamaukuku [Kukui a kona mau kuku].
name of a strong Kona storm. lit., great Kona that bites with teeth.
leeward sides of the Hawaiian Islands; leeward.
a famous leeward wind; to blow, of this wind. Many names of Kona winds follow.
old name for Honolulu harbor and vicinity, famous rendezvous for kōnane checkers.
breeze blowing from the north of Niʻihau. lit., feminine windward.
windward sides of the Hawaiian Islands.
abbreviation used in surveying for kapuaʻi, foot.
(more commonly Tuahine). Name of a misty rain famous in Mānoa, Oʻahu, named for Kuahine, who turned to rain after the murder of her daughter, Ka-hala-o-Puna; the rain is also in other localities.
a famous legendary place in the high heavens, a home of the deified dead.
far mythical land, a rendezvous of spirits; homeland of the ancestors.
distant legendary place, as the brink of the nether world into which spirits leaped. Also Leinaakeakua.
name of a wind accompanied by heavy rain.
name of a wind of Miloliʻi, Kauaʻi.
name of a wind of Nāālehu, Kaʻū (For. 5:93) and Oʻahu (Nak. 56). lit., dust scatterer.
name of a breeze blowing from the northwest of Niʻihau. lit., strike Lehua (Island).
Morning Star. lit., early morning light.
name of a legendary chief at Hilo.
easternmost cape, Hawaiʻi. Kumukahi and the western extremity of the islands at Lehua are mentioned poetically
Sovereign Pontiff. lit., teacher of testament.
easterly wind at Kaluakoʻi, Molokaʻi and Kamaile, Oʻahu.
a mat motif with a continuous row of red lozenges with their lateral angles touching.
name of a star. lit., demigod beneath the heavens.
the god of trainees in lua fighting; if training rules were broken the student might be maimed. After finishing training, the student ate the eyeball of a victim. lit., lua fighting blows.
name of a wind of Weliweli, Kauaʻi.
Reciprocity Treaty, by which Pearl Harbor was given to the United States as a coaling station. lit., treaty equal reciprocity.
stroke in lua fighting. lit., Mēhēʻula's single blow.
name of a wind associated with Kalāheo, Kauaʻi.
name of a star, seen in the month ʻIkuwā.

name of a place at Kohala, Hawaiʻi, celebrated in song for the tests held there for the presence of sharks: ti stalks (ʻau kī), whose bark had been beaten off (kākā), were thrown into the water; if the stalks were pulled under this was a sign of the presence of sharks and the natives climbed the steep cliff trail rather than swim.
name of a stroke in lua fighting.

sorcery god represented by images made of the wood of three trees at Maunaloa, Molokaʻi. The trees, believed poisonous, were the nīoi, entered by the god Kāneikaulanaʻula (Kāne at red resting place); the kauila, entered by Ka-huilaokalani (the lightnings of the heavens), believed by some to be a brother of Pele; and the ʻohe tree, entered by the goddess Kapo. The first image of nīoi wood was carved by a Molokaʻi man grateful for a gambling victory. (HM 111). Chips from these trees were used in sorcery.  Only the god Maʻiola could render such sorcery harmless. A Kālaipāhoa image is on display at the Bishop Museum (Buck, Figures 297, 298). lit., dagger carving.
lua fighting stroke from the back.
twenty-fourth day of the Hawaiian month. lit., Kāloa standing first.
twenty-fifth day of the Hawaiian month. lit., Kāloa standing second.
twenty-sixth day of the Hawaiian month. lit., last Kāloa.

names of three nights of the month:
     Kāloa Kū Kahi, 24th day of the Hawaiian month...
     Kāloa Kū Lua, 25th day of the Hawaiian month... 
     Kāloa Pau, 26th day of the Hawaiian month...
These nights were sacred to the god Kanaloa.
god of thunder.  lit., thunder Kāne.
name of the taboo imposed during the nights of Kāne. lit., Kāne bind firmly.
a place on the bird island Kaʻula and a name for the west.
name of a god that sometimes took the form of a click beetle.

the "leading god among the great gods" (HM 42); a god of creation and the ancestor of chiefs and commoners; a god of sunlight, fresh water, and forests (Thrum, p. 82) to whom no human sacrifices were made. In prayers to Kāne (HM 53-55) his name is followed by more than seventy epithets. Kanaloa was his constant companion, but Kāne's name always preceded. Twelve sacred paradisic islands lay off the Hawaiian group "within easy reach," visible on the distant horizon at sunrise and sunset. One is Kāne-hūnā-moku (Kāne hidden island) where Kāne and Kanaloa lived. (HM 67) The twenty-seventh night of the lunar month was sacred to Kāne. see (UL 257-259) for a famous chant to Kāne. lit., male.
name of the 27th night of the lunar month.
name of a sacred star, seen by priests as portending great misfortune, as the death of a chief; perhaps a variable like Mira or Algol, or even a nova.
Book of Deuteronomy. lit., two laws, i.e., a repetition of the laws of Moses [the Hawaiian term is a translation of the Latin and Greek names for this book, Deuteronomium and Desuteronomion].
name of a trade wind at Hāna, Maui, and at Puna, Hawaiʻi.
Captain James Cook, 1728-1779, British explorer, navigator, cartographer, made first formal European contact with Hawaiʻi, January 1778. .
name of a navigation star (no data).
the daughter of ʻOlopana and wife of Hikuikanahele. She was named for a grass (kāwelu₁).
a favorable Hālawa, Molokaʻi, wind mentioned in (For. 5:123); also associated with Hanamāʻulu, Kauaʻi (For. 5:97).
name of a rain at Makiki, Oʻahu.
name of a star, possibly Betelgeuse.
name of a gentle land breeze, as of West Hawaiʻi; Kapaʻa, Kauaʻi; Kula, Maui; Hālawa, Molokaʻi and Oʻahu.
name of a wind associated with Hilo.
breeze at Puʻuʻōhua on the Hāmākua side of Hilo. lit., to shred ti leaves.
name of a star. lit., red emitting.

Kalani Ahumanu i Kaliko o Iwi Kauhipua o Kīnaʻu [c. 1805 – April 4, 1839], daughter of Kamehameha I and Kaheiheimālie, and wife of Kekūʻanaōʻa; she was the mother of Kamehameha IV, Kamehameha V, Victoria Kamāmalu, and Kekūāiwa. After Kaʻahumanu's death she became Kuhina Nui for Kamehameha III, an office she held until her death in 1839 at the age of 35 (RC 348). In a chant in her honor, Kīnaʻu is said to have been named for a mythical.bird, Kamanukīnaʻu-a-Pae. lit.: flaw. .
name of a chilly wind and rain at Waimea, Hawaiʻi.
name of a company of warriors from Waimea in Kamehameha I's time, named for the wind.
Sea Island, Gossypium barbadense, a variety of cotton grown in Hawaiʻi.
wind associated with Kahauiki, Honolulu. lit., sweat sugar cane.
name of the third day in the lunar month.
to pray to the god Kanaloa, as on the Kāloa days of the month.
name of the fifth day in the lunar month.
fourth day of the old lunar month; also, the name of the 17th day and second after the full moon.
name of the sixth day of the lunar month, and last of the four taboo days of Kū.

one of the last great chiefs, a descendent of Līloa's wife Pineʻa, said to have subjugated first his own Oʻahu, and then the remainder of the Hawaiian Islands. He was succeeded by his son Peleiōhōlani (Pele at Hōlani [a mythical realm] ). (Kam) says he died in 1730 at the age of 175 (For. 4:432). In a 610-line chant he is praised as a mortal (kanaka), a god (akua), one who flies from heaven (ulele mai ka lani), and a foreigner (haole) from Tahiti (For. 4:394-395).  lit., royal Kū.
name of a rain and wind famous at Honolulu.

said to be an old name for the gods Kāne, Kū, and Lono. The theory of a trinity is believed due to remaking of Hawaiian legends by Kepelino, Kamakau, and Fornander to conform to the Bible. see Barrère-1969.
name of a god appealed to in ʻanāʻanā, evil sorcery.
Pillars of Kahiki; it was believed that the sky was supported by a vertical wall along the horizon; the section of the wall over Kahiki (formerly Tahiti) was the Kūkulu o Kahiki.
mythical pond or lake in the sky; its overflow comes to the earth as rain. lit., like heaven agitated.
name of a wind at Hāmākua, Maui. (Probably a contraction of kū kololio, gusty state.)
a god of forests and canoe makers; his wife was Lea. lit., Kū island spreader.
name of a star. lit., stands the rainy sky cover.
name of a constellation of a cluster of seven stars.
a stroke in lua fighting. lit., people traveling at night are hindered.

a giant man-dog. He was killed by Kamapuaʻa (pig man), who stuffed his own weed bodies down the dog's throat and cut his way out (HM 202). The hero Kaulu tore him apart; therefore dogs are small today (HM 348). A girl fled down his throat and his tail was cut off; hence dogs have short tails (HM 500). lit., Kū long dog.
name for the third, fourth, fifth, and sixth days of the month, usually called respectively Kū Kahi, Kū Lua, Kū Kolu, Kū Pau.

ancient Hawaiian god of war. Prayers connected with this major god include Kūkoliʻi, Kūlawa, Kūlewalewa, Kūpapaʻa, Kūwā, Kūwī... 
In some accounts, Kū and Hina were the first gods to reach Hawaii, and were followed next by Kāne and Kanaloa, and last by Lono (HM 11). Kū (upright) represented male generating power, and Hina (prostrate) was the expression of female fecundity and the power of growth. Kū also refers to the rising sun, and Hina to the setting sun; hence their realm includes the whole earth and the heavens and all generations of man born and unborn. (HM 12-13). Many fictional characters are named Kū and Hina, with implication of high birth, and most of the few references to infanticide in the stories refer to Kū and Hina, possibly indicating that it occurred rarely and that the motive was racial purity. Dozens of epithets are associated with Kū. Various forms of Kū were appealed to for rain and growth, fishing, and sorcery, but he is best known as a god of war. When gathering medicine with their right hands, people prayed to Kū for success. The third, fourth, fifth, and sixth nights of the lunar month were sacred to Kū. He sometimes assumed the form of the ʻō-hiʻa tree or the ʻio hawk. lit., upright.

sister of the antihero Halemano, who often assumed the form of the fish of the same name and once that of a chicken. She found Halemano's sweetheart for him, and twice brought him back to life after he had died of love sickness.
goddess of the hula, maile, ʻieʻie, and other forest plants (UL 24), often identified with Kapoʻulakīnaʻu.
a hero whose log, which was felled for a canoe, was found growing upright the following morning.
a god worshiped by canoe makers; also known as Kuʻōhiʻalaka (upright ʻōhiʻa tree Laka).
Rarotonga, Rarotongan. (Tahitian; the regular Hawaiian correspondent of Tahitian Rarotoʻa would have been Lalokona; the second a in Lalakoʻa probably assimilated to the preceding a).
name of a star. lit., the light floats.
name of a star. lit., chief stands [at] work.
a rain known at ʻUlupalakua, Maui.
name of a goddess worshipped by tapa makers.
wind associated with Hālawa, Molokaʻi.  lit., kamani leaf.
wind associated with Maui. lit., water dragnet.
wind, Punakou, Molokaʻi. lit., green leaves.
a gentle wind and rain associated with Hāna, Maui.
name of a group of seven stars.
name of a mountain wind at Nāpali, Kauaʻi.
name of a legendary people who were said to worship images and not gods, in the time of Wākea or of Hawaiʻi Loa.
an early immigrant brought from Kahiki by Kila. He introduced image worship in the form of an image called Lonoikaʻoualiʻi  lit., sacredness from afar.
name of a wind associated with Hālawa, Molokaʻi.

goddess of canoe builders... wife of Kūmokuhāliʻi, and sister of Hinapukuʻai, who sometimes assumed her form. Both sisters took the form of an ʻelepaio flycatcher to help canoe makers choose proper logs (see Hinapukuʻai). She was also called Hinakūwa'a (canoe upright) and Laea.
star in the Milky Way, perhaps Antares. lit., south lehua flower.

name of the small island just west of Niʻihau. As the westernmost of the Hawaiian Islands (except for the Northwest Hawaiian Islands), Lehua is associated with a setting sun (see chant, kalakalaʻihi). In poetry, the extent of the Hawaiian Islands is shown by coupling Lehua Island and Haʻehaʻe and Kumukahi on East Hawaiʻi . A breeze is named for this island.
name of a strong, wintry wind.
name of a gusty, wintry wind.
name of a star, perhaps Sirius.
name of a yellow-tinted rain famous at Hanalei, Kauaʻi, and on Maui.
Republican (political party). A newspaper, 1901–2, was entitled Home Rula Republalika.
nickname for Gilbertese, because their stretched ear lobes dangled. [see  Grimble's Tungaru Traditions for a description of this former Gilbertese practice]
wind associated with Haʻena, Kauaʻi.  lit., turning hand.
stroke in lua fighting.) lit., man-striking moss of Mahamoku.
name of a star, and name for the southern sky. (Wawaʻu is a widely distributed Polynesian place name) see (PN 229).
name of a star in the southern skies, and hence sometimes the name for the southern sky.

Pele's dream sweetheart fetched by Hiʻiakaikapoliopele from Kauai. In some accounts he is destroyed by Pele after reaching Kīlauea because of her jealousy at seeing him embrace Hiʻiaka. lit., tardy [he is an antihero] .
the god of the annual fall harvest makahiki circuit of the islands when taxes were collected. He was symbolized by a tapa banner suspended on a mast with a tiny carving of a human head at the top.

a younger son of Keawenuiaʻumi who became chief of Hawaiʻi Island and defeated the invading forces of Kamalālāwalu of Maui. He was also famous as a debater (hoʻopāpā) and mokomoko fighter. (HM 392-394), (For. 4:256-363), (RC 47-63).

an image god taken by Laʻamaikahiki from Raʻiātea, Society Islands, to Wailua, Kauai. (HM 497) Upon the request of the demigod Māui he lengthened the night so that Māui might kill Peʻapeʻamakawalu (eight-eyed Peʻapeʻa). His taboos were the kapu lama (torch taboo) and the kapu loulu (loulu palm taboo). lit., Lono at the chiefly supremacy.

an eight-headed chief from Kahiki (afar) who pierced the cliff at Kānehoalani, Kualoa, Oʻahu, and severed Kahuku from Kahipa. He was killed by Kamapuaʻa, who called on his plant bodies to entangle the eight stone foreheads of Lonokaʻeho. (HM 205.) lit., Lono the stone.
a legendary fire guardian and the name of the makahiki image.

one of the four great gods, the last to come from Kahiki, considered a god of clouds, winds, the sea, agriculture, and fertility. He had also the form of the pig man, Kamapuaʻa. He was the patron of the annual harvest makahiki festivals, and his image (Lonomakua) was carried on tax-collecting circuits of the main islands. Some fifty Lono gods were worshiped.
the 28th day of the lunar month.
name of a star, said to appear in the month of Hinaiaʻeleʻele.
A legendary chiefess, sister of Kāwelu, daughter or wife of ʻOlopana.
Thanksgiving Day. lit., day to bless.
Thanksgiving Day. lit., day for expression of affection.
Decoration Day. lit., day to place flowers.
Decoration Day. lit., day to scatter flowers.
a name for the Milky Way (Kep. 81), and also of a single star.
Lānaʻi Island. perhaps lit., day conquest. also Nānaʻi.
Labor Day. lit., holiday of the laborers.
eighteenth day of the lunar month.
nineteenth day of the lunar month.
twentieth day of the lunar month.

the heroine of the romance of the same name called 'the masterpiece of Hawaiian romantic fiction' (HM 534). Lāʻie was hidden at birth in a pool at Lāʻie, Oahu, and later reared in a sacred house of yellow feathers at Paliuli, a mythical paradise on Hawaiʻi. ʻAiwohikupua of Kauaʻi vainly wooed her. She adopted his Maile sisters. They found her a god husband who lived in the sun — Kaʻōnohiokalā (the eyeball of the sun) — but he was unfaithful. Lāʻie was worshiped as ka wahine o ka liʻulā, the lady of the twilight. Using traditional motifs, Haleʻole (in (Laie)) wrote this long story in imitation of European romances. lit., ʻie leaf in the water. see Kaʻōnohiokalā; Maile; Waka.
place name, windward Oʻahu. Mormon Temple and Brigham Young University-Hawaiʻi site.
a rain associated with Makawao, Maui.
a wind reported at Hālawa, Molokaʻi.
name of an early chief, the father of ʻUmi.
name of a wind and rain, famous at Pālolo, Oʻahu, and Waiehu, Maui. lit., lehua chill.
young undersea volcano 30 kilometers southeast of Hawaiʻi Island.
a wind associated with Ōlaʻa, Hawaiʻi. lit., scattering dew and flowers.
name of a rain associated with Kauaʻi. lit., rain that scatters sugar-cane leaves.
wind name associated with Wainiha, Kauaʻi. lit., flower scattering.
stars in the belt of Orion.
name of a star used in navigation.

four sweet-scented sisters with human and plant forms: Mailehaʻiwale (brittle maile), Mailekaluhea (fragrant maile), Mailelauliʻi (small-leaved maile), Mailepākaha (Laie 454-455). They appear in numerous legends, in the most famous as guardians of Lāʻieikawai and her house thatched with bird feathers in legendary Paliuli. Fragrance had supernatural power and was associated with gods (HM 531), royalty, and religion, especially for worshipers of Laka, the hula goddess.
name of a star or constellation in the Milky Way. lit., twinkling eye.
name of a star. lit., eye following canoe.
name of a star, perhaps variant name for the North Star. lit., sailing-canoe eye.
wind name, probably at Kauaʻi. lit., small eye of Lea.
Pleiades; Castor and Pollux. see Pleiades.
Hawaiian month name; the six summer months collectively.

a chief of Waimea, Kauai, father-in-law of Manokalanipō, and famous as an agriculturalist. A month and the summer season collectively were named for him. During the makahiki festivals food plants were symbolically dropped from his net (HM 366-367). Several times Kamapuaʻa killed all of Chief ʻOlopana₁'s men except Makaliʻi, who as the sole survivor took the news to ʻOlopana₁. Later, when Makaliʻi had become chief of Kauaʻi, he was frightened by Kamapuaʻa's long chant of his victories; he then chanted Kama's name songs, and so his life was spared, but he was sent away to live in the mountains. (FS 198-203, 230-239). In one account (For. 5:364-365), the gods Kāne and Kanaloa sent messengers up (i luna) to ask Makaliʻi whether Kaulu, a noisy kava drinker, was man or god. Later Makaliʻi gave his nets to Kaulu so that he might entangle and kill Haumea. His name is given to the Pleiades. By some he was considered a navigator.
name of a gentle wind; it is said to permit loli to come out of their holes and feed.  lit., wind that feeds sea slug.
Macao, a city governed by Portugal, near Hong Kong.
name of a constellation in the Milky Way. lit., blinking eyes, twinkling eyes.
name of a star. lit., eye of the royal hawk.
name of a navigational star. lit., eyes drawing many.
name of a star. lit., bright eye.
name of a star or constellation.
name of a star, said to be in the Kaulua constellation.
name of a strong, blustering wind at Nuʻu-anu; to blow, of this wind.
name of a gentle breeze associated with Kōloa, Kauaʻi, Hāna, Maui (For. 5:97), and Kailua, Oʻahu.
name of a rain associated with Kahaluʻu, Oʻahu.
name of a star. lit., celestial shade.
name of a star, said to appear in the first night of the month Nana and to vanish after the night of Muku. lit., female power.

Manila hat, named for the city.

----------------------------------------
Manila
Manila.
Hawaiian name of a well-known Spanish immigrant, Francisco de Paula Marin, who knew Kamehameha for more than 25 years.

name of a chief of Kauaʻi... husband of Nae [or Na'e]kapuani (the daughter of Makaliʻi), and an ancestor of Kawelo. Kauaʻi is sometimes referred to poetically as Kauaʻi o Mano (RC 194), Kauaʻi o Manokalanipō (HM 141, 366) or Manō.
name of a star, perhaps related to Konamaukuku.
place name at Kīlauea Volcano, Hawaiʻi.
the highest mountain on Hawaiʻi. lit., snow mountain.
the second highest mountain on Hawaiʻi; a mountain and village on Molokaʻi. lit., long mountain.
name of a famous wind associated with Lahaina, Maui. also ʻA ʻa.
wind name. lit., Portuguese man-of-war Maʻaʻa.
a god of healing...  who was said to occupy certain trees, the wood of which counteracted the noxious effects of poison from the kālaipāhoa wood. lit., cured sickness.
a stroke in lua fighting. lit., Long-Hill (Pearl Harbor) loneliness.
star name. Melemele and Polapola were said to be twin stars, the former male and the latter female.

legendary race of small people who worked at night, building fish ponds, roads, temples; if the work was not finished in one night, it remained unfinished; also Melehune. see ʻeʻepa. (Luomala-1951) convincingly refutes the theory that Hawaiʻi was settled by Menehune before the arrival of the first Hawaiians.
name of a strong, gusty wind of Niʻihau. (UL 238).

underworld, ruler of underworld... A chief who was banished to the underworld because of his sins. There he became the ruler and the underworld was named for him. In some accounts, Milu was a chief at Waipiʻo, Hawaii, succeeding Wākea. Entrances to Milu were at Kahakuloa, Maui, and Moanalua, Oahu. In an Orpheus-like story, Hiku went to Milu to bring back his wife, Kāwelu, who had strangled herself in the belief that she was unloved (Emerson in (Malo 106)). In popular language, "going to Milu" was a phrase for death (FS 90-91). Milu enjoyed such games as kilu, kōnane, and lele koali. (Kam. 64:51–60) see Kūwahailo.
name of a land breeze that wafts out to sea at Puna, Hawaiʻi. lit., fragrant breeze, so named for the fragrance of pandanus.
name of a rain or wind associated with Puna, Hawaiʻi. lit., wind that wafts the fragrance of lehua blossoms.

a goddess who came with Pele from Kahiki and lived in Kaʻieʻie Channel between Kauaʻi and Oahu. She had two forms: one of a woman as beautiful as, a lehua tree laden with blossoms, the other of a red moano fish. When Māui tried to draw the islands together, Moano and others snagged his hook into a rock (Pōhakuokauaʻi) which was then pulled to Kaʻena Point. Māui caught Moano's fish body and laid it on a shrine. Her spirit returned to Kahiki, but it returned later to Kauaʻi, Oahu, and finally to ʻŌlaʻa, Hawaii. lit., great goatfish, the lehua blossom.
waterfall, Hālawa, Molokaʻi, and wind there.
name of a Hawaiian island. see song, hapenuia.
rain associated with Kahaluʻu, Oʻahu. (EM 61); also a wind name.
the son of a migrant from Kahiki and the father of Kila. lit., remain [on] heights.
thirtieth night of the moon, when it has entirely disappeared (muku).
name of a strong wind at Kawaihae, Hawaiʻi.
Castor or Pollux. The two together are called Kamāhana, Nāhōkūmāhana, Nāmāhoe. Individual names include Māhoe Hope, Māhoe Mua, Nānā Hope, Nānā Mua.
sixteenth day of the lunar month, night of the full moon.
star name, one of the twins, Castor or Pollux. lit., last twin.
month in the old lunar calendar, the eleventh (Hawaiʻi) or seventh (Oʻahu, Kauaʻi). also Hilina Mā: see month.
star name, one of the twins, Castor or Pollux. lit., first twin. (Probably Pollux, the brighter of the two, that rises before Māhoe Hope, which is probably Castor: (JM 15))
month in the old lunar calendar, the tenth (Hawaiʻi) or sixth (Oʻahu, Kauaʻi). also Hilina Ehu: see month.
name of a star; this star and Mākohi-lani were near the Pleiades, and were said to be patrons of fighters.
stroke in lua fighting. lit., the rising cloud bank preserves.
a stroke in lua fighting. lit., watch within.
a stroke in lua fighting. lit., watch without.
stroke in lua fighting. lit., watch opposition.
legendary fish guardian, Makapuʻu to Hanauma, Oʻahu.
wind, well known on Kauaʻi, said to blow from the northwest. lit., traveling Mālua.
trade wind, as on north Kauaʻi. lit., damp Mālua.
sea breeze accompanied by showers, known at Hilo. lit., Mālua fetching water. also Huehu, Mālualua Kiʻi Wai.
north wind, known at Maui, Molokaʻi, and Oʻahu.

name of a particular company of warriors of Kamehameha and the name of Kamehameha's famous law of the splintered paddle (lit., paddle fragment) which guaranteed the safety of the highways to all, as women, children, sick, and aged; the law was so called because it was said to have been formulated after Kamehameha had been struck on the head with a paddle while his foot was trapped in a crevice. The law is often called Māmala hoa. According to one account (Thrum-1906, 81–6) Kamehameha threw a stone at two attackers; it hit a noni tree, pierced one of the attackers and hit a precipice where it is still lodged. Kamehameha's supporters tortured and killed a "navigator" who had failed to guard Kamehameha properly by pulling a spear back and forth through his body. Kamehameha wept and formulated his law. lit., splintered paddle. cf. (Kam. 64:22).
name reported for both Venus and Jupiter. also Hoʻomānalo.
name of a star near the Pleiades.
name of a strong, blustering wind associated with Waiʻalae and Puʻuloa, Oʻahu.
twelfth day of the month and first of the Kāne taboo, liked for planting flowers because it was believed the flowers would be round and perfect like the moon on this night.
name of a mythical people; they were not tiny like the Menehune. lit., banana-eating Mū.
one of three stars in a triangle, the others being Polo ʻUla and Polo Ahi Lani; they may be Alpha, Beta, and Gamma Cassiopeiae. In one account Mūlehu is a variant name for Venus.
legendary people of Lāʻauhaelemai, Kauaʻi, often called Mū ʻai maiʻa, banana-eating Mu.
name of a star or constellation in the Milky way.
name of a star. lit., heart eager to rule as a lord.
a constellation, probably the Southern Cross.
name of an island between Kauaʻi and Midway.
the god of sleep. fig., sleep.
var. spelling of Nīpona, Nippon; Japanese.
name of one of the Hawaiian Islands; an inhabitant of Niʻihau Island. see saying, kīkū.
a rare name for the northeast tradewind (Moaʻe).
a goddess of lactation... called on to help nursing mothers and to wean infants. She was also called the wife of Keoloʻewa, a ruling chief of Molokai. lit., white heap.
place name and star name. lit., cool heights.
Marquesas Islands; Nukuhiva Island in the Marquesas; Marquesan.
constellation of the Big Dipper. lit., the seven.
name of a star, perhaps Venus.
the Pleiades. also Nāhuihuiamakaliʻi, the clusters of Pleiades.
constellation of five stars forming a circle; they are said to be near Nāhiku, the Big Dipper. lit., enclosure stars.
belt and sword in the constellation of Orion. lit., the darts.
Pleiades. lit., the bailers of Makaliʻi.
probably Pleiades.  lit., the nets of Makaliʻi.
name of a constellation. lit., the lines of the clinging ones.
Castor and Pollux, Gemini. lit., the twins.
legendary little people. lit., the silent ones.
the star Castor. cf. Māhana, Nānā Hope. According to some, both were the names of a single star. lit., look forward.
said to be a name for Eromanga Island in the southern New Hebrides; Boki sailed for here in 1829 to get sandalwood; his ship disappeared. lit., look at flowers.
name of a pool on Oʻahu over which the chief Kūaliʻi was said to have leaned to drink.
sea breeze at Kawaihae, Hawaiʻi; Waimea, Kauaʻi; and Kanaloa, Maui.
Pleiades. lit., the wives of Makaliʻi.
stroke in lua fighting. lit., the eight rainbows.
trickster demigod, younger brother of Kana, described as kolohe (mischievous) and maka kaha (mean-eyed).
rain name associated with Nāpili, West Maui.
name of a stroke in lua fighting. lit., make the cross, is good.
name of a Kauaʻi wind. lit., sand carrying.
legendary homeland of the god Kāne, a land of plenty.
name of the most populous of the Hawaiian Islands and the seat of Honolulu. The name has no meaning (see Oʻahu). see saying kau poʻohiwi, and epithets, Oʻahu (English-Hawaiian).
name of a star or for the Milky Way. lit., eastern long row.
wind off Waiʻanae, Oʻahu (PH 161), and associated with Naue, Kauaʻi (For. 5:97). lit., pandanus ensnarement.
name of the channel between Molokaʻi and Maui.
name of a wind at Waiʻanae, Oʻahu.
initial point of a genealogy line.
priests of Lono (Malo 159); ancient order of priests (AP).
a legendary land of plenty and joy, said to be on Hawaiʻi, where chiefs' children were raised; now a place name on several islands. lit., green cliff. see chant, pulelo and saying, glory.
place name in the Hilo District, famous in legend and song (see huluhulu₄, mūkīkī); place names also on other islands.
Board of Education, Department of Education (EH)
Board of Registration. lit., board to affix names.
Papa Mahi ʻAi ame Ulu Lāʻau
Papa o nā Kahu Kula o ke Kulanui
Board of Regents of the University.
rain name associated with Olowalu, West Maui.
probably the same as Haumea, and like Haumea, considered symbolic of the female principle; commonly cited as the wife of Wākea. lit., flat surface. see Hoʻohokuikalani
name of a star of astrologers, said to rise in the early morning during the month of Kaulua.
name of a star, said to appear early on the night of Muku.
one of the Line Islands Hawaiians dug guano, perhaps Baker Island. lit., exhausted. [Jarvis Island. - Ka Nupepa Kuokoa, Jan. 5, 1878: article by S. Kalua]
a star in the month of Ikiiki, an omen for chiefs.
a small bright star that appears on the night of Hilo in the month of Welo and stays all the month.
a star observed by priests, in the month of Kaulua and visible through the month of Ikiiki.
a star that appears in the night of Muku in the month of Māhoe Mua, and remains visible through the month of Māhoe Hope; it follows the star Ululoa, and was considered the latter's "servant."
a stroke in lua fighting. lit., deafening crackle.
rain name associated with Lahaina, Maui. lit., rain that moistens pili grass.

volcano goddess... The volcano goddess born as a flame in the mouth of Haumea. Epithets coupled with her name include Honuamea (reddish earth), Kawahine'aihonua (the earth eating woman), Kawahineokalua (the woman of the pit), and, rarely, Kawahineokaʻaʻahukeʻokeʻo (the woman with the white garment). Countless stories attribute rocks and land forms to Pele's wrath. Before settling at Kīlauea, she dug craters now extinct — Diamond Head, Punch Bowl, Koko Crater, Salt Lake, Haleakalā, and many others. She appeared at different times as fire, a wrinkled hag, a child, and a beautiful girl. She is sometimes called a malihini who came from Kahiki.
name of a wind associated with Hāmākua, Hawaiʻi.
name of a rain associated with Kaupō, Maui. lit., hide [at the] stone wall.

a demigod born at Wailua, Kauaʻi, of a crow (ʻalalā ) father, and with rat (ʻiole) and bat (ʻōpeʻapeʻa) sisters. He was carried out to sea and to Kou (Honolulu) where he won contests in rat-shooting and in riddling. He sometimes appeared as a rat. lit., Pikoi son of the crow.
wind associated with Kaʻawaloa, Hawaiʻi. lit., near pandanus.
name of a pair of stars, said to bring ʻōpelu fish.
a stroke in lua fighting. lit., clinging to fingernail.
a wind associated with Kona, Hawaiʻi.
same as ʻIkuwā, a month of storms; also said to be the name of a rain occurring in that month. lit., break forth in storms.

general name for supernatural dog after the time of Kamehameha I, said to have been taken from the name of Kamehameha's favorite dog, Boss (Eng.), which was deified and worshipped; name of a supernatural dog on Kauaʻi, said to have owned land at Lāwaʻi and Wahiawa (HM, p. 573). According to some, any supernatural animal.
star name, paired with the star Melemele.
snow goddess of Mauna Kea. lit., Bosom goddess.
name of a star, said to be associated with Mūlehu.

star names:
     Polo Ahi Lani  name of a star, said to be associated with Mūlehu₂...
     Polohilani var. of Polo Ahi Lani, a star...
     Polo ʻUla  same as Polo Ahi Lani, a star...
     Polo Wehi Lani  same as Polo Ahi Lani, a star...
name of a lua fighting stroke, said to be used by women as well as men.
name of a star. lit., low post.
rain said to occur in the month of Welo.

a rain associated with Kalihi, Oʻahu, and Hilo, Hawaiʻi . lit., adzelike head, said to be so called because this heavy rain forced the people to spend so much time sleeping that their heads were sharpened as though by an adze.
name of a cold, continuous rain.
name of a star. lit., fire flower.
rain name. probably same as Kaiāulu.
a lua fighting stroke. lit., the smoke blows, the birds rage.
Howland Island, a name used by Hawaiian guano diggers there in about 1856. lit., the ʻilima flower. see song, (Pukui-Korn 80–2).
the star Rigel, tutelary star of West Maui.
a lua fighting stroke. lit., the pig strikes body hair.

a Molokaʻi sorcery goddess... A Molokai sorcery goddess of possession with human and mudhen (ʻalae) forms. It was believed that if an ʻalae flew over a house crying at night, trouble would follow. lit., rising [as smoke] .
name of a legendary eel; according to one authority, a Conger cinereus eel. lit., red eel.
a tight-waisted dress, supposedly worn once by Portuguese.
the Greater Magellanic Cloud. lit., white butterfly.
the Lesser Magellanic Cloud. lit., dark butterfly.
Bureau of Emigration. lit., bureau for boarding ships.
name of a star in the constellation Kaulua.
rain famous at Hāmākua, Hawaiʻi. lit., [rain] remaining [near] house.
same as Puʻupele, the name of a wind at Mānā, Kauaʻi.
name of a famous cold wind at Kīlauea, Hawaiʻi and at Puna.
wind associated with Waipā, Kauaʻi.  lit., forested hill.
name of a star said to appear on the night of Hilo in the month of Hinaiaʻeleʻele.
name of a star said to appear on the night of Hoku in the month of Welehu.
name of a lua fighting stroke, perhaps from pāpala kāʻili ʻula, red snatching firebrand.
a gentle Kauaʻi wind with rain that reaches Niʻihau.
a wind similar to Pāpaʻa Inu Wai except that it blows in sunny weather, noted at East Maui.
name of a star observed by priests.
a star observed by priests in the month of Ikiiki. lit., chief-like darkness.
name of a star, said to be one of a large group resembling a double canoe. Pāʻao was a famous priest said to have conveyed a colony from Central Polynesia to Hawaiʻi.

a priest from Tahiti who landed at Puna, Hawaii. He built the heiau Moʻokini at Hawaiʻi, and is said to have introduced human sacrifice, walled heiaus, red-feather girdles as a sign of rank, taboo songs, the prostrating taboo, and the feather god Kāʻili. He made a return trip to Kahiki.

a demigod with an ulua fish form that was hooked by Māui in his efforts to unite the islands. Māui warned his older brothers, who were with him in the canoe, not to look back. But they did and saw a canoe bailer (kā) which they placed in the canoe. It changed into a beautiful woman, Hina-(i)-ke-kā. While they struggled to embrace her, the fish slipped away.
rain name. lit., tapa bundle, so-called because people bundled up tapa during rains to keep it from becoming wet.
Antarctic Circle. lit., south cold circle.
Arctic Circle. lit., north cold circle.
a rain famous at Kahaluʻu, Oʻahu. lit., surrounding pandanus.
Tropic of Capricorn. lit., southern cool circle.
Tropic of Cancer. lit., northern cool circle.
work on the chief's plantations, so called because this work was done on Fridays; the chiefs' plantation where the people worked on Fridays; to work thus.
name of a fine, cold rain. lit., rain by the līpoa seaweed.
a wind associated with Kīlauea, Hawaiʻi.
name of a rain at Nuʻuanu, Oʻahu. lit., rain amid the koa tree leaves.
a stroke in lua fighting. (containing reference to ocean dwellers (EH))
the planet Mercury. lit., following the chief [i.e., the sun].
a stroke in lua fighting. lit., the cliffs of great Tahiti are green.

name of a goddess of sorcery, said to have come from Kahiki... called by Emerson (PH 146) the arch-goddess of sorcery, she was invoked by Hiʻiaka in her prayers of resuscitation for Lohiʻau. (PH 144–7).
a wind associated with Waiākea, Hawaiʻi.
name of a stormy Maui wind.
site of the Moana Hotel, Waikīkī, Honolulu.
an old name for Howland Island. lit., kou tree grove.
name of a star, said to appear on the night of Muku in the month of Māhoe Mua.
a strong wind blowing from a given direction in each locality, as a strong southeast wind in Kaʻū and Puna, Hawaiʻi, and at Kāneʻohe, Oʻahu. lit., blowing hard.
(see (Gram. 2.9) for alternation of glottal stop and k)
a wind famous in song noted on Kauaʻi, West Maui, and Niʻihau; according to (Emerson) (UL 196), the trade wind.
the companion of Hiʻiakaikapoliopele on her trip to Kauaʻi to fetch Lohiʻau for Pele. lit., green woman.
a son of Hāloa noted for corruption and sin. lit., dishonor.
place name used as a direction marker in Honolulu. lit., spouting water.
cold wind associated with Mt. Kaʻala, Oʻahu, and the nearby place of the same name.
place names on Hawaiʻi, Kauaʻi, and Molokaʻi.
name of a star near the Pleiades, said to be a member of the group called Kaulua. It is also said to be a name of an ancient chief. lit., long stream.
a West Maui city, site of a late eighteenth century battle. lit., destructive water.
a place name. lit., reddish water.
star name, sometimes called the patron star of Hilo.
cool breeze famous at Waimea, Kauaʻi. lit., scooped water.
name of a wind, Honolua, Maui.
name of the highest mountain on Kauaʻi.
name of a pleasant breeze at Wailua, Kauaʻi. lit., water of cloud banks.
place names beginning with Wai-, river, stream.

a moʻo guardian in many stories. She had moʻo, human, spider, and eel forms. As guardian of Lāʻieikawai in Paliuli, she prepared for her a house thatched with feathers (HM 526, 529). As guardian of Hinakekā, or equated with her, she floated as a gourd in the sea and was taken into Wākea's canoe (HM 219).
a rain in Nuʻuanu and Mānoa Valleys and the name of a ridge separating Mānoa and Pālolo Valleys. see saying, puʻipuʻi.
wind name associated with Māla, Maui.
ancient Hawaiian month, corresponding approximately to November. see month.
a star name, perhaps same as Welo₅.
name of a month in the lunar calendar. see month.
name of a star used by navigators.
the mythical ancestor of all Hawaiians. (Kep. 61–7)... according to Hawaiian tradition, a man rather than a god (HM 294). see Haumea, Hoʻohokukalani, Papa, Waka. Probably lit., expanse.
Wales. Prince of Wales, Keiki aliʻi o Wāle.
to rise up; to raise the head; to come up from under water.

• a prolonged sound, 
   • wail; 
   • to prolong, 
   • stretch.
a small green fish resembling the hīnālea, used as pani (food or drink taken to finish a medical treatment) for certain diseases of children of the ʻea type.
Hawaiian stilt bird (Himantopus mexicanus knudseni), an endemic subspecies of stilt, formerly common on the main Hawaiian Islands, endangered.
to pant, to breathe hard with heat, as a dog.
syllables repeated in chants, usually at ends of verses, similar to ēhē; also ahana and ahana kōkō lele, both meaningless.
a taunting singsong teasing phrase, used especially by children, meaning "Oh! Oh! Aha! Shame on you! You are going to catch it!"; as a verb, to tease.
breeze; to blow or breathe gently. waft; softly blowing.
to pass fire from one candlenut to the next on a chain (koli) or candlenut torch. lit., to fire the torch.
fire fountain, firebrands thrown over cliffs at Kamaile, Kauaʻi. see ahi and chant, Kauahae.
volcano, volcanic fire. lit., fire destroying land.
fireworks (perhaps from Eng. scow [kao], as fireworks were first displayed from ships of explorers).
lazy, indolent; to shirk work, loiter.
long line, as with several hooks for deep-sea fishing or for sounding.
lashing on the pueo main purlin.
lashing fastening kaupaku roof to kua ʻiole, upper ridgepole.
better, well, well-being, fortunate, improved; to need (aho₃ + -na).

• patience; patient, 
   • enduring, 
   • long suffering; 
   • to tolerate. 
   • lit., great breath.    
see ex., lawe₂, makua.
line, cord, lashing, fishing line, thong, kite string.
it is better or preferable (used after e, sometimes in comparisons).
healthy, vigorous; strength and vigor, as of animal or plant; to grow rapidly, thrive.
to make two thicknesses by folding; to double up, fold, as paper or tapa.

to stone to death; slaughter by burying the victim under a pile of stones. Hākau, half brother of ʻUmi, was killed in this fashion (FS 141), and this method was used unsuccessfully against the hero Kawelo (FS 107).

• pestilence, epidemic, 
   • heaped up, as dead bodies.
abbreviation for ahupuaʻa₁, land division usually extending from the uplands to the sea...

land division usually extending from the uplands to the sea, so called because the boundary was marked by a heap (ahu) of stones surmounted by an image of a pig (puaʻa), or because a pig or other tribute was laid on the altar as tax to the chief. The landlord or owner of an ahupuaʻa might be a konohiki.
the altar on which the pig was laid as payment to the chief for use of the ahupuaʻaland.
exposed, conspicuous, prominent, obvious, in plain view; heaped up.
There now! So it's there after all!
There! I told you so! There it is!
depending on, only if, only when, whatever, whenever.
friend; friendly; to become a friend.
same as ʻaiā, ungodly; godless;  irreligious, unbelieving, careless of observance of taboos; wicked, wickedness.
coition; to have sexual relations, cohabit (frequently pronounced ei).

carefully, slowly. cf:
         akaʻai to eat slowly, carefully  (ʻai, to eat...)
         akahai modest, gentle...
         akahana to work carefully or slowly (hana, to work...)
         akahao to pick up carefully, as food (hao, to pick up...)
         akahele slow or moderate, cautious... (hele, to go...)
         akahoe to paddle carefully, silently (hoe, to paddle...)
         akaholo to sail or run cautiously (holo, to sail, run...)
         akakuʻu lessened, diminished... (kuʻu, to diminish, as stream water...)
         akalewa to sway the hips daintily... (lewa, to float, swing...)
         akaluli to move slowly, carefully (luli, to shake, sway...)
         akanahe careful, gentle in behavior and speech (nahe, soft, sweet...)
         akanoho to sit quietly, live cautiously (noho, to sit, reside...)
         akaʻōlelo to speak cautiously, deliberately, in moderation (ʻōlelo, to speak...)
clear, luminous, transparent, visible, manifest, plain, intelligible; thin, as cloth; shining, bright, distinct.
a white and very thin tapa.
a downy, thorny branching plant (Solanum aculeatissimum), 30 to 90 cm high, from tropical America. It bears round scarlet fruits 2.6 em in diameter, which are strung for leis.
modest, gentle, unassuming, unpretentious, unobtrusive, docile, decorous, meek, suave; meekness, modesty.
to pick up carefully, as food.
lessened, diminished, mitigated; to cease, abate, grow calm, stop, as wind, surf, rain, anger, grief, pain; settled, calmed, quieted, appeased.
the phenomenon known as the Specter of the Brocken, seen at Haleakalā Crater. lit., rainbow apparition.
the ghost or spirit of a living person seen by others, a sign of calamity. lit., many shadows.
string of multicolored glass beads. lit., bead reflections.
to sway the hips daintily, deliberately, and gracefully.
careful, gentle in behavior and speech.
to go here and there, vagabond; vagabond.
to eat slowly, carefully, cf. Easter ʻaka kai, eat more.

an endemic begonia (Hillebrandia sandwicensis), a succulent herb with oblique, rounded lobed leaves 10 to 20 cm in diameter and with sprays of small pink or white flowers, found only in shaded, damp ravines. Kauaʻi.
a tall endemic climber (Smilax sandwicensis) with tendrils and shiny, leathery, heart-shaped leaves; used for tying rafters.
a type of fine white tapa.
red sunset, looked upon as a sign that rain will clear. lit., red shadow.
to speak cautiously, deliberately, in moderation.
embryo at the moment of conception.
newly hatched fish in the stage in which its body is still transparent.
knuckles, as of hands or ankles; joints of the backbone; node and stalk of kava; kava slip for planting.
a lover of wisdom, seeker after knowledge, philosopher, scientist, scholar; philosophy, science; scientific. lit., to desire wisdom.
quick, ready, as to do a kindly, deed, helpful.
liver (more specific than ake). lit., firm liver.
to desire, wish, be eager, yearn [the emotions and intelligence were thought to be centered within the body].
a god to whom one appealed with offerings for help, as in fishing, farming, or killing an enemy. lit.. work god.
god sent on errands of destruction.
spirits, as of a recently dead kinsman, who were fed (hānai) offerings (such as food) and sent out to destroy an enemy.

the kauila, nīoi₂, and ʻohe "poison" woods of Molokaʻi, which were kept by sorcerers in their houses, wrapped in tapa, and to which food offerings were made daily; scraps of these woods were used as poison, and poison itself was sometimes called akua hānai.
a god to whom offerings and sacrifices were made.

similar to akua hānai₁,spirits sent out to destroy an enemy...; akua hānai₂,  scraps of woods used as poison...;  sent out in the shape of fireballs to kill, or inserted in a victim's food, water, or tobacco.
