stick image (general name); image wrapped in tapa; image consisting of a carved staff, with a tuft of feathers at the top, bound to its bearer by a sash (kāʻai₁) (Malo 80) and carried into battle; staff with a carved figure at the head, used in ceremonies to procure offspring.
flying god, usually a poison god sent to destroy, sometimes in the form of fireballs (pōpō ahi).

a tall image, especially an image of Lono carried on a circuit of the island during the makahiki, harvest festival; it was called loa, long, because of its "long" travels. The image consisted of a staff about two fathoms long. Pieces of pala fern, feather leis, and skins of the kaʻupu bird were fastened to a crosspiece tied near the top of the staff, in the center of which was a tiny carved head. A long and white tapa banner was attached to the crosspiece. ((Malo 143–5), but see (Malo text, chapter 36, sections 22–4)) Tribute was collected. also Lono Makua.
foreign god, epithet often applied to Pele because she had come from a foreign land.
a spirit that takes possession of people and speaks through them as a medium.
the god of nightmares; a god who carried persons to distant places in their sleep, especially if they had eaten certain fish, as the weke.
last and slow-moving image in a procession during kauila nui ceremonies.

similar to akua loa (a tall image, especially an image of Lono carried on a circuit of the island during the makahiki), except that it was taken to a poko₃ (a small division of a district, sometimes the personal lands of a chief)
image representing the god of sports that accompanied the akua loa on its circuit, to preside at the sport festivals.
a god that inspires or possesses people.
spirit eater of scraps, designation of a god sent on errands of destruction by sorcerers.
a spirit that destroys its keeper; a god sent on an evil errand who returns to destroy his keeper rather than the victim; any evil practice, as excessive drinking, gossiping.
spirit eater of filth. same as akua ʻai hamu.
supernatural with dual roles as akua to unrelated persons and ʻaumakua to relatives, as formerly the four major gods to high ranking chiefs, and later only as Pele, Hiʻiaka, and Laka to mortals.
"it" in a game of tag or hide-and-seek.
big-eyed or goggle-eyed scad fish (Trachurops crumenophthalmus), Stages of growth are pāʻāʻā, halalū or hahalalū, and akule.
to wake up early for no reason
sea course, path where one must swim past a projecting cliff.
cut off or unfinished road, dead-end road. fig., an incomplete rainbow, rainbow fragment
orbit of the stars, circular road.
sheer trail as for climbing a cliff.

fast, quickly. cf.
     alaheo, gone, departed   (heo depart in haste)
      alamimo, quick, fast   (mimo deft...)
     alapine₁, quick, fast   (pinepine often)
     alawiki, to hurry; quick, fast   (wiki quick)

• plank bridge, 
   • rough road over ravines or chasms, 
   • trestle, 
   • ladder.
type of braid used in the pāpale ʻie.
mountain ladder or steps cut into a cliff.
railway, railroad track. lit., iron road.

a large native shrub or small tree (Canthium odoratum; synonym Plectronia odorata) with shiny leaves and small, fragrant, white flowers. The wood is hard and was formerly used in making the ʻōʻō digging stick; also used medically.
mock orange (Murraya paniculata), an ornamental hedge plant with shiny, dark-green leaves, small fragrant white flowers, and red berries.
hem or finished border of a plaited mat or hat.
marine railway. lit., road to pull ships.

• a frequented and well-known path; to frequent such; 
   • to tread or trample, as on a taboo being broken. And.
small thin surfboard, as of breadfruit or koa wood, and heavier than the olo board.
place for climbing a cliff, usually with ropes.
a low native shrub (Pelea waialealae), found only on high, wet parts of Kauaʻi.
long tattoo stripe. lit., tooth path.

brown seaweeds (Dictyota spp.), regularly divided into narrow segments. They are so bitter that they will taint other seaweeds put with them and can be eaten but little and by some are considered poisonous. Medical kahunas used them in small quantities to treat asthma. This name is sometimes qualified by the terms kai and ʻula. Also maka and false līpoa.

an Oʻahu tree (Pelea sandwicensis or P. oahuensis), with oblong, fragrant leaves (like the mokihana of Kauaʻi), which were used for scenting tapa. The bark was used for medicine. Also other species of Pelea.
pathway of the navigator stars; star course followed by navigators. Probably also hōkū ʻai ʻāina.
belly of a fish, considered choice.
stairs, steps, ladder, stile, doorstep, ascent, scale (musical).
body sores; to have such sores; affected with dry rot, as taro.
dividing, branching, as of winds and lineages.
light of early dawn, sunset glow. lit., flaming road.
dark lines on stomach of a pregnant woman, converging near the navel. lit., burned path.
upland bird, reported to be the young of the ʻanianiau, and on Kauaʻi, the ʻamakihi.
to swallow whole, as a fish or shrimp.
Heiau or temple that had no lele altar.
type of taro patch built on artificial mounds, known near Hiloas kipi; mucky claylike soil, as in this type of patch.
river ford; place on a trail where one swims or wades across a stream.
red dust in a road, red dust.
to draw, pull, attract, as a magnet.
to rise up, arise, get up, come forward.
there (same as the more frequent lā and -la). cf. e lākou ala, e lauala, e (verb) ala.
wounded, pierced; wound, sore. Less common than pōaleale.
a fish, said to be short for hīnālea, or a kind of hīnālea.
paralysis of the tongue, believed sometimes caused by a kahuna. Also alelo pehu, alelo pelu, lelo puʻu
a kind of introduced flower (no data).
meat of the sea egg or sea urchin (wana), so called because of resemblance to a tongue.
concave curve of the lower portion of the lei palaoa, whale-tooth pendant, suggestive of a tongue.
point at the tip of a paddle.
a lowland perennial weed (Boerhaavia repens), with long, thin, prostrate branches, bearing small leaves and flowers. The swollen roots were used medicinally, acting as a diuretic. Anena on Niʻihau.
hollow or cavern on the sea floor.
an endemic mountain plant (Plantago princeps), 60 cm to 2 m high, rarely branching, stem woody, with long narrow leaves at top; related to the laukahi.
to wait, stop; before; usually as a command: Stop! Wait a minute!
presiding officer, ruling officer; chairman, viceroy.
military officer, officer of army or navy.
power behind the throne. lit., supplementary king.
male chief, king; husband (polite, not said of one's own husband or to him).
offspring of a high chiefess and commoner (or lesser chief) father.
lesser chiefs who served other chiefs.
an exalted chief (probably from pūʻoʻa, tower).
chiefess, queen; wife (polite, not said of one's own wife or to her).

the ornamental cannas (Canna indica, forms and hybrids), large tropical American herbs, with large oval or narrow leaves and large red or red and yellow flowers. The round black seeds are worn in leis and are also placed in fruit shells of the laʻamia for hula rattles. Cannas are both cultivated and wild in Hawaiʻi.
in the presence of chiefs; royal court.
squilla (Pseudosquilla ciliata, Lysiosquilla maculata), highly desired as food. Also Squilla sp.
loved and served by many persons, as a chief or favorite child; esteemed.
tapa made from māmaki mixed with wauke.
may you be loved or greeted, greetings (to one person).
pitiless, merciless, ungrateful, without love or affection.

love of the land or of one's country, patriotism; the name of a Hawaiian-language newspaper published 1893–1920; aloha ʻāina is a very old concept, to judge from the many sayings (perhaps thousands) illustrating deep love of the land. (Aloha ʻāina) in (PN 268–9) cf. the song Kaulana nā Pua (EM 62–4).
name given to the kāmole plant used in hana aloha sorcery. lit., mutual love.
single weft in plaiting; mat of a single thickness, with only one shiny side. lit., single side.
a red bird reported by Kepelino (no data).
two-sided, two-faced; facing one another, as cliffs on opposite sides of a valley.
double weft in plaiting; plaiting with a reversible side, with two thicknesses.
belly of a fish, choice to Hawaiians.
combined, acting together; to cooperate, act together.

• to follow, pursue, chase; 
   • to run, as for political office.
appropriation of property by force, as practiced by some chiefs on their travels; to do so
outrigger float; port hull of a double canoe, so called because it replaces the float.
to carry a burden on the shoulders, to lift weights; a burden. fig., responsibility.
a stick for carrying burdens on the shoulder.
to raise or mount high, as waves; high, raised.
surveying, to measure the surface of the earth.
tempo marker in music; Maelzel's metronome marker.
scales, balance; to weigh. lit., pound (Eng.) measure.
thermometer, for taking temperatures; to take temperature. lit., fever (Eng.) measure.
thermometer, measurement of heat; to measure heat.
without equal, unsurpassed, immeasureable, incomparable (in this sense, similar, to launa ʻole and lua ʻole), limitless, unlimited, never satisfied.
seismograph. lit. machine to measure earthquakes.
period of ten days; for ten days; to pass ten days.
large moana, a fish from 30 to 80 cm long.
congregation, audience, assembly, gathering, crowd; to assemble.
distance, faraway space, beyond the horizon.

fathom: formerly the distance between tips of longest fingers of a man, measured with arms extended on each side; Catholic writers equated anana with one meter; to count by this measurement or by fathoms.
boundary, circumference, perimeter; to encircle, go around.
to have enough or too much, satisfied, satiated, surfeited.
following verbs indicating a single event, whether a command or a statement, whether completed or incompleted.
the breath of life, passing of a breeze.
to wave or beckon, as with the hand, fan.
magnifying glass, microscope, telescope. lit., glass to enlarge vision.
electric-light bulb. lit., electric light glass.

• mirror, 
   • glass; 
   • clear, transparent, 
   • obvious.   
Several types of aniani are listed below.

• cool, refreshing; to blow softly, gently. 
   • fig., to travel swiftly.
individual presiding over the ʻume game.
time (in songs, and usually before ahiahi, rarely before kakahiaka).
cool, soft fragrance, as of upland forests; sweetness; to be cool, fragrant, and sweet.
cold, influenza; to have a cold.
long cloud; high or distant cloud; stratus cloud along the horizon. fig., a distinguished person.

a small seaside shrub (Wikstroemia sp.). The root bark is used externally for sores, and stems and bark of branches for coughs. Branches and leaves are mixed with rasped seeds of Barringtonia asiatica (syn. B. speciosa) to stupefy fish.
to think or behave reasonably; human enlightment, civilization; rational.
firmament, sky, blue vault of heaven.

any kind of a cloud, including ʻōpua, but specifically, high clouds that when wind-blown scud along (kaʻa). cf: 
   aokū, rain cloud, mist
   ao loa, long cloud; high or distant cloud...
   ao ʻōnohi, cloud with rainbow (ʻōnohi) colors. 
   aouli, firmament, sky, blue vault of heaven. 
   ʻōpua, puffy clouds, as banked up near the horizon
   pālāmoa, pāpalamoa, thick, dense, as clouds
   puapuaʻa, plural of puaʻa₃, bank of clouds...
to be careful, beware, watch out.
the exact image of (preceded by a ʻe).
orbit, as of stars and planets.
gold bracelet; formerly a gold ring.
hill, as of sweet potatoes; bunch, as of taro; to hill up plants.
iron hoop or band, named for the king's guard under the monarchy.

• circle, circuit, hoop, loop, band, 
   • bracelet, hoop-shaped earring, ring, 
   • girdle, belt, 
   • to span, reach around, 
   • embrace, put an arm around, clasp. 
Many compounds with apo are listed below.
union of the molar or cheekbone with the temporal bone.
file, rasp; to smooth or sharpen with a file.
a shellfish resembling the hīhīwai, found in brackish water.

• to snap or snatch with the teeth; snatching. 
   • fig., to destroy, ravage, ruin.
this word is related to uahi, smoke. One source says it refers to lowly or humble persons. (Malo 109) says it may refer to a distant relationship.
ghost-ridden; haunted or unfriendly land. lit., ghost bile. cf. (Isa. 13.9) .
a variety of ʻoʻopu goby fish found in both brackish and fresh water.
soon, by-and-by, presently, shortly, just. cf. auaneʻi₂

• probably, 
   • merely, 
   • probably not, 
   • possibly, 
   • doubtful.
same as au₁, period of time, era...; to walk lightly and swiftly.
an unknown herb, the bark and leaves of which were used as medicine.
to go looking from place to place without any definite course, to drift or sail aimlessly, drifting.
to turn off the course, wander, deviate.
to overturn, overthrow, upset; to till.
outhouse, as for storing canoes; shed, shelter.

• even, 
   • smooth,
   • clear. 
   • fig., suave and pleasant in speech and manner.
deep coral bed with overlapping ledges where fishes hide.
to pitch and toss; to raise, lift.
to gather leaves to wrap fish in for cooking, as leaves of pōhuehue, mānewanewa, lauaʻe, ti; to frighten fish into a net with leaves.
to fly, as a frightened flock of birds.
large-mouthed net placed at the wings of the papa hului net to receive fish; used in deep water.

• to float off in the air, as miasma; 
   • evil spirits thought to attend graves.
fresh water mixed with noni juice, drunk after kava.
shelter or shed, as for canoes; outhouse, temporary house; tabernacle.
some representatives of an endemic genus (Isodendrion), members of the violet family. They are small shrubs beating greenish-white or reddish flowers, which have equal petals and none spurred.
according to (Kep) and (Kam), a relationship extending back 24 generations.
fishing with a pula stick or pūlale to drive fish into a net.
destitute, especially of the rich who lose ever everything.
paper nautilus (Argonauta argo). lit., fleet of canoes with two sails.
overcome by intense emotion, as love, grief.
passing of much time on a piece of land, as an old family.
to set, as a net or fish trap.
Hedyotis acuminata, a native shrub (coffee family), with small green flowers, and unpleasant-smelling, ovate or narrower leaves.
current; to flow, as a current.

• movement, motion; to move, stir; 
   • eddy, 
   • tide, 
   • drift, float, 
   • walk, 
   • hurry, 
   • succession or train, as of thought, trend.
small sweet potatoes of poor quality that grow from the vine.
a herring-like fish, sometimes called tenpounder or tarpon (Elops hawaiensis); according to some, a medium-sized awa fish.
good spirits, as the messengers of Kāne, who guarded people from evil ghosts and managed the rain, winds, and weather.
to bind securely, fasten, as of the marriage tie.
place where bones of chiefs were hidden, as in a cave, lit., eternal harbor.
port, harbor, cove; channel or passage, as through a reef.
milkfish (Chanos chanos). Stages of growth are pua awa (puawa), young; awa ʻaua, medium size; awa, commercial size; awa kalamoho, very large.
drip of poi; an insult to the chiefs of Hawaiʻi, playing on the name of their chiefs, Keawe, with implication that poi is excreted in a sticky chain.

• tenacious, 
   • sticky, adhesive; glueyness,
   • threadlike,  threads.
a root running horizontally that produces roots below and above; a rhizome, creeping root.

• small root, rootlet, 
   • vein, artery, nerve, tendon, muscle. 
   • fig., womb, offspring.
just now, lately; nearby, not far; ordinary, insignificant.
mixing of a dark or brilliant color with a lighter one, as feathers in a lei; of dark hair of a young person with streaks of gray; to mix, as drinks.
a kind of banana with green and white striped leaves and fruits.

several native trees, the soapberry (Sapindus saponaria f. inaequalis), and all species of Zanthoxylum (also known as Fagara, Zanthoxylum having yellowish wood formerly used for digging sticks and spears); seeds of all (largest in the soapberry) are black, round, and used for leis.
replacement of e in songs (commonly written a e, but a glottal stop is pronounced before ʻe).

• bright as moonlight; brightness, 
   • fair, 
   • white, 
   • clear, clearness
   • pure,
   • brilliant, shining;
a native tree or shrub (Streblus sandwicensis [Pseudomorus sandwicensis and P. brunoniana are synonyms]), with narrow-ovate leaves, and milky sap; a member of the fig family.
replacing i often in songs; usually written a i.
to teach while traveling; to act as itinerant teacher, preacher, missionary.
reader, primer; to learn or teach to read.
astronomy, astronomer; to teach or learn astronomy.
spelling book; to learn or teach spelling.
manual of punctuation; to learn or teach punctuation.
instruction, education; to teach or learn writing.
grammar, instruction in grammar; to teach or learn grammar.
replacing o, of, and ʻo, subject marker, in songs.
swordfish, sailfish, marlin, spearfish (Istiophoridae). See sayings, laʻa₂, ʻoloʻolo₃.
particles indicating imperative/intentive mood and accompanying subordinate verbs (ai in this case is the anaphoric ai).
particles indicating imperfect aspect and future tense and accompanying subordinate verbs. The nei indicates action here or now. See (Gram. 5.2).
similar to e lākou nei, you there (usually affectionate), but persons addressed are farther away.
you (pl.), you there (usually affectionate). (Shortened vocative e + pronoun lākou + zero demon.)
(this is sometimes said today as a chant ending, but is probably an innovation.)
air, breath, air current. Some confusion exists in the uses of eaea, ʻeaʻea, and ʻeʻaʻeʻa.
a smell, as of seaweed; to smell.

• sovereignty, 
   • rule, independence. 
    [Lā Hoʻihoʻi Ea, literally the day sovereignty was restored, a holiday celebrated in the Kingdom of Hawaiʻi. Set on July 31, modern observations of this day include ceremonies taking place at different sites around Hawaiʻi, including a key commemoration at Thomas Square in Honolulu.]

• life, spirit (Isa. 42.5) .
   • air,  breeze, 
   • breath, respiration, 
   • vapor, gas; fumes, as of tobacco;  
This ea, as well as ea₁,₃,₄, is sometimes pronounced or sung ʻea.
to rise, go up, raise, become erect.
to laugh merrily, giggle in glee; laughter.
syllables repeated for musical effect at end of verses, similar to ēhē.
carved parallel or undulating lines on a tapa beater and on tapa.
name recorded for adult stage of hāpuʻu fish.

• animation varying from fury and storm to power and majesty, animated, animation. 
   • violent; violence
   • anger, fury; furious
   • powerful
   • majesty.
healthy, vigorous. Less used than ahuahu.
a kind of rock, used for adzes.
water or water mixed with fragrant herbs used in sprinkling or gently rubbing a patient to revive him from fainting.
var. name for ʻōlapa₂, Cheirodendron trees.
here, here it is; you over there, you.
var. of eia, especially before words beginning with a-.
rather frequent variation of the anaphoric ai (ai₃) in fast speech, but seldom if ever found so in printed form.
a stench that draws flies; bad-smelling.
a Molokaʻi name for ʻūlei, a shrub.
to return, go backward, withdraw, back up.
to go backward with stooped back, as from the presence of a chief.
to lose weight rapidly, as due to sickness.
an addition of water, as for mixing poi. Kauaʻi.

• to lose, be defeated, beaten (if followed immediately by an animate subject and then by i-iā marking agent); 
   • to win, beat; winning, victory (in other environments).
part of a fish's tail above and below the cleft.
spelling occasionally found for e, part. + u, plural prefix (see (For. 5:507)).
yes, I am here (in answer to a call by name, or to a name chant in one's honor).
to board a ship; ship passenger; immigrant.
to rise up frequently, as in water; to bob up and down.
by, by means of (follows a pas/imp.).
hibiscus. lit., Hawaiian flag, from having red petals striped with white.
carnation (Dianthus caryophyllus), petals red with white stripes, formerly a great favorite with Hawaiians.

a native variety of taro in the piko group, characterized by having the two basal lobes of the leaf blade separated up to the piko (point of joining with the leaf stem); a hardy taro often grown commercially for poi, formerly common at Kaʻanapali, Maui, where strong winds tore the leaves (hence haehae).
-na₁ form with hae₁,₂,₃; wildness; barking; tearing.
wild, fierce, vicious, furious, savage, ferocious; fury, rage; to rage.
to bark (Isa. 56.10) , growl, snap, as a dog; to chirp noisily or scold, as a mynah bird.
flag, banner (perhaps so called because a piece of torn [hae] tapa was used as a banner).
net spacer or mesh stick, gauge used in making meshes in nets, made of wood, turtle shell, bone, bamboo, whale rib, coconut shell, or metal.
small sweet potatoes removed in thinning a hill. Kaʻū.
bird hunter, fowler; to hunt birds.
empty, void; somewhat deflated, as a balloon; half rotten, as wood, taro. fig., hungry.
to hurl a blow by swinging from the shoulders.

• to offer a prayer or sacrifice; 
   • to lay before.
to build, as by laying bricks.
to break in two. fig., bad luck.
to break into pieces; to break off, as to thin sweet potato vines.
painful swelling, as in the groin.
lacking in flesh, thin; to fail, of an invalid.
to clear, smooth; to purge, as the bowels.
day sacrifice; to sacrifice by daylight.
food offering; to offer vegetable food.

simulative prefix similar to haʻa-, similar in meaning to the causative/simulative hoʻo-... see 
     haikea, same as hākea₁, pale... (kea₁, white, clear...)
      hailawe, to exchange, barter... (lawe₁, to take, transport, carry, bring, haul...)
     hailepo, ash-gray pallor; to have this pallor... (lepo₁, dirt, earth, ground, filth...)
     hailuku, to stone. fig., to hurt the feelings... (luku, to massacre, destroy, slaughter...)
     haipule,  religious, devout, pious, reverent... (pule₁, to pray, worship, say grace...)
     haiʻula, same as hāʻula, reddish... (ʻula₁, red, scarlet...)
     haiwā, to plant far apart, as taro, coconut... (wa₄, space, interval...)

• to gather, crowd, flock; 
   • in great numbers, as ripening fruit.

to prevent the gods from hearing a rival's curses by acting insane (eating poison, going naked), thus diverting the god's curses to himself and freeing the victim; with his superior mana he turns the curses away from himself and on to the rival sorcerer (Kam. 64:140–1); to prevent gods from hearing by offering herbs and medicine (And).
severe cramps, said to have often proved fatal.
ash-gray pallor; to have this pallor.
one of the sting rays, perhaps hīhīmanu.
a shellfish resembling the wana, but with short spines, possibly Tripneustes or Echinometra.

a small native fern (Schizaea robusta) found in high mountain wet areas believed to be the plant form of the sorcery goddess Pua; sometimes used as a psychological remedy to ward off the evil influence of Pua.  lit., Pua's memory. Hawaiʻi.

said by some Hawaiians to be a native variety of pineapple; plant spreading vinelike; leaves with thorny edges; fruit plain green when unripe, yellow when ripe, small, fragrant, good-tasting; pieces of the skin were used for hat leis. lit., white hala.

native trees (Dracaena [Pleomele] spp) in the lily family, with narrow leaves in tufts at branch ends and with clustered round yellow fruits. (Neal 205–6). This was one of the five standard plants used in the hula altar to Laka. see more under palai (Neal 12).

an indigenous variety of pandanus, with keys 4 cm long, canary-yellow and small; head small, about 15 by 12 cm., used in medical prescription and for exorcising evil spirits. It was much prized for leis.

the pandanus or screw pine (Pandanus odoratissimus), native from southern Asia east to Hawaiʻi, growing at low altitudes, both cultivated and wild. It is a tree with many branches, which are tipped with spiral tufts of long narrow, spine-edged leaves; its base is supported by a clump of slanting aerial roots. The pineapple-shaped fruits are borne on female trees whereas the spikes of fragrant, pollenbearing flowers are borne separately on male trees. Many uses: leaves (lau hala) for mats, baskets, hats; the yellow to red fruit sections for leis, brushes; male flowers to scent tapa, their leaflike bracts to plait mats (see hīnano). (Neal 51) The aerial root (uleule) tip is a good source of vitamin B and cooked in ti leaves was used medicinally, although unpleasant tasting. The tree is called pū hala. The hala lei is much liked today but formerly was not worn on important ventures because hala also means failure. For the same reason some persons will not compose songs about hala. Types of hala are listed below.
a close family friend, house with friends.

It was formerly used both medicinally and in religious ceremonies, as for dedicating new fish nets. According to (HP 17), it is a domesticated form of wild ʻāweu. a lowland tree (Hibiscus tiliaceus), found in many warm countries, some spreading horizontally over the ground forming impenetrable thickets, and some trained on trellises. The leaves are rounded and heart-shaped, the flowers cup-shaped, with five large petals that change through the day from yellow to dull-red. Formerly the light, tough wood served for outriggers of canoes, the bast for rope, the sap and flowers for medicine. (Neal 559–60). Of the two varieties of hau, a rare erect one (hau oheohe) was grown for its bast and a creeping one (hau) was planted for wind-breaks. (HP 196)

• a prefix similar in meaning to the causative/simulative hoʻo-. 
   • before short vowels and glottal stop the form is usually hā-, as hāinu, to give to drink, and hāʻawe, to carry. 
   • before consonants, both haʻa- and hā- occur, as haʻalele and hākuʻi. 
   • before glottal stop plus a long vowel, ha- occurs, as haʻāpuka. 
   • for a few bases, derivatives with both haʻa- and hoʻo occur, as haʻakoʻo and hoʻokoʻo, which have the same meanings; with a few bases, meanings differ, as haʻalele and hoʻolele. 
   • a few bases with haʻa- may form another derivative with hoʻo-, as inu, hāinu, and hoʻohāinu; heo, haʻaheo, hoʻohaʻaheo. 
   • before colors the meaning is "-ish, somewhat," as hākea, haʻakea, hāʻeleʻele, hāuliuli. 
   • for clear understanding, delete haʻa- and look up the base.

burst of laughter, guffaw; to guffaw.
a sacred place, as one where a priest stayed in seclusion to await a message from the gods, usually a small house on the heiau. (UL 74.)

pre-Christian place of worship, shrine; some heiau were elaborately constructed stone platforms, others simple earth terraces. Many are preserved today. Several types are listed below. In (Isa. 15.2) , heiau is a high place of worship.
heiau where fish were offered to insure good fishing.
heiau where offerings were made to insure rain.
heiau where first fruits were offered to insure further growth. lit., heiau for the increase of food crops.

heiau for stopping rain, or (less frequently) for bringing rain. One such heiau named Imukālua-ua (rain-baking oven) was in the Kaunakakai quadrangle, Molokaʻi; a land section in Puna, Hawaiʻi, also has this name. Rain in leaf packages is said to have been baked in an oven.
small temporary heiau covered with tapa stained green (maʻo), used for the hoʻoulu ʻai ceremony to bring food.
heiau where human sacrifices were offered.
a heiau used for services to bring success in war.
piece of hair, tooth, fingernail, small bone, or the like of a deceased beloved, kept and offered food in order to please the spirit of the deceased.
redup. of hei₁, net, snare, stratagem, ruse...; hei₂, string figure, cat's cradle...;  hei₃, motion of hands and fingers, especially of the dying...; to festoon, drape.
helper or apprentice to a priest.
string figure, cat's cradle; to make such. Many kinds are listed by (Dickey).
motion of hands and fingers, especially of the dying, (Some persons did not make string figures, hei, at night because of the association of the figures with the motions of death.)

• adept, deft; 
   • to absorb, as knowledge or skill.
water oozing from a cliff and trickling down.

• anchor, stone anchor, to anchor, anchored
   • towline, tow
   • line for fastening boats;  make fast
   • warp
   • taut, stretched
to come upon, happen, befall, strike.
top gourd in a hula gourd drum.
feathered top of an ʻulīʻulī, hula rattle.
nail, pin, rack, as for hanging objects in a house.
thunder; to thunder. fig., passion, rage.
redness of the eyelids; rawness, as of scraped skin; to be red or raw.

Hula step: one foot is placed at about a 45-degree angle to the front and side, with the weight on the opposite hip and with that knee bent; the foot is then returned to the original position and the step is repeated with the other foot; to dance thus.
to go wrong, take the wrong path, go astray, err.
to go suddenly, early, or for no apparent reason.
to tie or bind beforehand, as in preparation for a journey.
younger brother or sister; descendant of a younger brother or sister; to go behind.
to go from house to house, gad.
to go by fits and starts, jerk.
to go or come far; to go with no hope of returning.
to go to a place for the first time or as a stranger.
to travel in the mountains; mountain climber.
older sibling, descendant of an older sibling, senior.
to go naked; to go without fixed purpose or far and wide; to go empty-handed; to go without recompense.
quick step, quick time; to go fast.
to walk, go on foot, hike; pedestrian. (Hawaiian pidgin ‘walk feet’ is probably a loan translation.)
to cut up, divide; divided; filled with ruts, as a road.
a rare native variety of dry-land taro, with dark purplish petioles and white corms; grown on Hawaiʻi.

• when, 
   • by the time that 
   (usually followed by ā).

following other bases, imparting idea of 
   • everywhere, 
   • here and there, 
   • continuously.
introduced, sweet-scented heliotrope (Heliotropium arborescens syn. H. corymbosum).
to move back and forth rapidly; jerky pushing or sawing motion.
double number; dual number, as in grammar.
exclusive plural, as in Hawaiian grammar.
inclusive plural, as in Hawaiian grammar.
to count or recite in order or consecutively.
to count by, as helu pālua, to count by twos; helu pākolu, to count by threes; helu pāʻumi, to count by tens.
counting game with chants; to play this game.
list of the nights of the moon in the old Hawaiian calendar; to count the nights.
uneven totals, as ten bushels and three pecks.
even numbers and totals, without fractions.
to take turns reading, read in turn.
number, count, total sum, amount; grade or mark (evaluation).
grade or mark, as in school; number of a grade (class), enumeration.
arithmetic, score, reckoning, account; serial; volume (in a series); numbered.
to scratch the earth, as a hen; to dig with the fingers; to paw the earth, as an angry bull.
to grumble, list offenses or complaints, especially about lack of gratitude or appreciation.
want, need, necessity; lacking, destitute (Oihk. 22.23) , needy.
perfect, faultless, flawless, holy, immaculate, saintly, pure in heart; complete; perfection, virtue, goodness, holiness; angel, person without fault.
faint, scanty, feeble, hungry, gasping, as of one near death.
to sound indistinctly, as a voice.
shoo, be off, scat (perhaps from Eng. move).
buttocks; mons pubis; hollow of the thigh; nakedness.
inner side of the thighs where they join the body on either side of the genitals; groins.
to laugh at, ridicule, mock, tease, snicker, giggle; mockery, laughter.
same as heo₁ and pōheoheo, knob.
knob of any kind, as of a door; end of the penis, prepuce.

• idiot, moron, imbecile; feebleminded, moronic.
   • partial paralysis of the vocal organs causing indistinct articulation;
fine bits of broken or ground glass; mercury on glass made into a mirror.
a great many, very, vast, in great quantities.
Is it wrong to? Then why not?
to the point of satiety; to be in great quantities; to do excessively.
stained red, inflamed, reddened; flattened and destroyed, as by lava; blood red; a blood sacrifice, as hog or man.
to imprint with spots, stains; smeared, as with red earth.

• to ride a hōlua sled; the hōlua course;
   • fig.., an expression of pride in descent from certain chiefly families at Waipiʻo, Hawaiʻi, who were famous for their skill with the hōlua sled.
flow of blood, hemorrhage, menstrual flow.
a variety of large red octopus (Octopus ornatus); it was rarely eaten because of its bitter taste, but was sometimes used as medicine.
squid beginning to decompose, with a pinkish color and a bad odor, liked by some.
season when nehu fish run; to run in schools, of nehu.
tiny, young octopus that clings to rocks along sea pools, especially in certain seasons.
to surf toward the mouth of a stream or up the stream.
an octopus settled on the ocean floor with tentacles spread out.
a long-headed, long-tentacled octopus (Octopus ornatus), very tough, tenderized only by much pounding; now called the night octopus. lit., long-headed octopus.
breast disease, with caking and great pain during nursing.

see also. heʻe₆ 'to flee'
   • to slide, slip,
   • surf,

• to melt, soften; 
   • flow, 
   • drip, 
   • to skim, as milk.
to hang down, as fruit; to sag; to bear breadfruit.
line that supports the mast, stay.

a reedlike grass, a bent grass (Agrostis avenacea, synonyms A. retrofracta and Calamagrostis forsteri), originally found in Australia, and now found through Polynesia; Panicum heupueo on Niʻihau. lit., owl hoot.
probable Hawaiian name for pili uka, a grass.
hoot, as of an owl; to croak, hoot.
deep-throated sounds made in Hawaiian chants and prayers; to chant thus.
same as the more common hiaʻā, indisposed to sleep, wakeful, sleepless...
a little sleep, nap; to take a nap.
to oversleep, sleep deeply; death, eternal sleep.
depression or hole, as under water.
pleased with, delighted with; delightful, pleasing.

• greatly pleased or delighted, most delightful; 
   • appetite for delicious food.
indisposed to sleep, wakeful, sleepless; insomnia.
redup. of hie, attractive, distinguished, dignified, noble, becoming...; superb.
kind of soft porous stone used to smooth and polish utensils; it is harder than the ʻana stone, which is used on wood.
net made of strong cord used for shark fishing.
a plant with small yellow flowers.

the swamp fern (Ceratopteris thalictroides), an edible, somewhat succulent fern, distributed through the tropics. It grows in mud or water, as around taro patches, in tufts about 30 cm high. The fronds are triangular and are finely divided into long, narrow parts. Young fronds are eaten with fresh-water shrimps.

• entangled, interwoven, involved, rank, snarled, snarl, entanglement, kink, 
   • perplexed, hampered, obscure and difficult to understand (Kep. 167); 
   • thicket, 
   • difficulty, problem, trouble.
lawsuit or case before the court, trial.
to come or go, of many people.
redup. and intensifier of hina, to fall.
name of a legendary koa tree on Kauaʻi that was said to have no trunk.
soft whistling sound, gust or draft of wind; to whistle.

• a dream or vision (Kin. 15–1) , as while dozing; to dream while dozing; 
   • to whistle or sough, as wind.

• to entangle, intertwine, intermingle; entanglement, 
   • creep, 
   • spread, 
   • web, 
   • snare.
to tilt back, as the head.
portion of the sky immediately above the horizon.
all right, O.K., certainly, surely, it can be done.
to come accidentally, alone, or without any particular purpose or reason.
impossible, unable, can't or unable to do; inability, regrets.
names of cardinal directions, stars, and portions of the sky, perhaps because of movement (hiki₃) of the sun. see below.
to aim carefully, as with stone, spear, or gun.
spittle passed from a dying master, according to the belief that his knowledge was thereby handed on.
large Hawaiian couch. lit., possible to mount.
to fetch repeatedly or a little at a time.
to spread, as mist; to rain, especially a slanting rain.
to jump or start from shock, to gasp; shock, perturbation.
to force one's way, as through a crowd or undergrowth.
quickly, speedily, suddenly, prompt, quickly done; possible to do quickly; doubletime (military command).
probably the same as ikiʻalamea, a disease.
to fetch, carry back and forth (less used than lawe).
tattoo brand on the forehead of a kauā outcast, or on the forehead of the caught seducer of a high chief's wife. (see (Malo 70, figure 1))
to reel, lean or tilt sideways.
tangled, confused; entanglement, confusion; to become entangled; to trip or fall.
a three-strand braid; to braid such.
to wander or grope aimlessly in the dark.
in devious ways; to ramble; be indirect.
dark red or brown (less dark than hili₄).
mixed, snarled, entangled; to mix, snarl.

• to believe, trust; trust, confidence.
   • to lean on, rely on;
sound or call of a wind instrument, as the conch shell.
square braid of eight or sixteen strands.
ailment of the bowels or stomach, accompanied by gas pains.
to braid or plait, as a lei  or candlenuts; a braid, plaiting, string.
to turn aside, deviate, miss the way, wander, stray.
to whip, smite, thrash, switch, bat; batter, as in baseball; stroke, as in fighting.
bark used in dyeing, as hili kukui, hili kōlea, hili noni; the dark-brown dye made from this bark; a tapa dyed with hili; to dye with hili.
to lengthen a speech or story by inserting new matter; to embroider or spin out a tale.
to twist, braid, spin; twisted, braided; threadlike; faint streak of light.

various species of reef fishes of the genus Coris. The name hilu may be qualified by the terms ʻeleʻele, lauwili, melemele, moelola, pano (probably same as uli), pāniʻo, pilikoʻa (Paracirrhites forsteri, hawkfish), ʻula, uli. See saying, noʻenoʻe₂.
quiet, reserved, well-behaved, decorous, unobtrusive, easygoing; such a person (a child born to a woman who craved hilu fish during her pregnancy was thought to be of this desirable type).
to lie down to sleep; to lie low, as of smoke; to drop dead.
to fall together, of several; to topple.
to begin to gray, of hair.
a native Hawaiian plant of the water-leaf family (Nama sandwicensis). Niʻihau. cf. (Neal 712).
dusty miller (Artemisia stelleriana), a perennial herb in the daisy family, from northeastern Asia and eastern North America. The leaves and stems have a white, velvety covering and are aromatic.

florida moss (Tillandsia usneoides), an air plant, growing on tree branches and hanging baskets, forming masses of gray, thread-like stems and leaves. It is often substituted for the heliotrope (below) as the flower of Kahoʻolawe, and so called.  Also ʻāhinahina and ʻumiʻumi o Dole, Dole's Whiskers.

native heliotrope (Heliotropium anomalum var. argenteum), a low, spreading beach plant, with narrow, clustered, silvery leaves and small, white, fragrant flowers. As designated by the Territorial legislature in 1923, it represents Kahoʻolawe in the leis of the islands; it is used for tea and medicine.  Called nohonoho puʻuone on Niʻihau.
native geraniums (Geranium cuneatum var. tridens and other native silvery geraniums), shrubs or small trees of the high mountains, with ovate, toothed leaves and red or white flowers.
a variety of sugar cane, gray-green with a rosy flush, the whole covered with a wax bloom; pith dark brown; looks like lahi₂.

type of stone laid near the coral pile (umu) to attract fish; it was flat on one side and rounded on the other, and was believed to attract manini and young of other fish which resembled it in color. lit., white gray.
young of ʻoʻopu, a fish, formerly caught in nets and greatly relished.  See saying, pā ʻili.
a rare native variety of upland taro, with green leaves, reddish leaf juncture (piko), dark-green petioles, and white corm. Perhaps same as lauloa uliuli.
italics, probably so called because italics slant.
to blow in a straight course, of wind.
a variety of land shell. see hinihini konouli, hinihini kua mauna.
cooked greens, as of ʻāheahea, pōpolo, pakai.

intensification of hinu,  smooth and polished, lustrous, slick
   • bright, shining, lustrous, 
   • glossy, 
   • glittering, as of polished stones or shells; 
   • splendid; splendor.
same as maiʻa ʻeleʻele or ʻeleʻele, a mountain banana with shiny black trunk.
a native variety of upland taro.
to jibber jabber in the white man's language, so called because English seemed full of whistling (hiohio), sibilant sounds.
to whistle softly; to blow softly, draw in the breath, as of one eating hot food.
lure for trolling, said to be named for its whistling sound tripping over the water.
a sweep or gust of wind; to blow in gusts.
inside corners of a house, said to be so named because ghosts came whistling in at the corners.
resting place, as in the shelter of a tree or cave.
a game something like checkers, played on a board with five squares.
to elevate, hoist, as by block and tackle.
stones used in games of kōnane, kinipeki, and āneo, usually polished and flat.
esteemed chief; beloved child or favorite; royal favorite.
coal-black, entirely black, solid-black. (A puaʻa hiwa might have a few white hairs, but none at all were on a puaʻa hiwa paʻa.)
precious, beloved, esteemed, petted, darling, indulged; favorite.
an all-black pig with white hoofs and white tips of tail, ears, and nose.
entirely black, as of pigs offered to the gods, a desirable blackness contrasting with uli and ʻeleʻele, which have pejorative connotations. see polohiwa and its associations with the god Kāne₂.
a term qualifying coconuts and kava.
sharp ridge of a mountain. cf. more common kuahiwi.
to fall sideways, lean, slant, slope, incline, leaning, oblique, diagonal.
shuttle or needle for making a fish net, sometimes of bone.
to stir, as a fire; to signal with the hands.
stems by which tubers are attached to vines.
to make fire with the fire-plow; the act of making fire thus.
shuttle or needle for making nets; to knot or fasten the meshes of a net; to form a network; to bind, as house rafters.
hook used for kala, a fish, and baited with kala, a seaweed.
a rare variety of taro with bronze-red leaf and stem, used in medicine.
carried in the arms, as a beloved child.
carried on the shoulders, as a beloved child.
to nurse or care for, as an infant; to admire, exalt, praise, extol in poetry; praise.
to carry, tend, and cherish a beloved child (lei ).
to bear a grandchild in the arms; to be a grandparent (a term of pride and affection).
to care for a child; to instruct a child.
to tend, feed, cherish, as a child.

• to hold or carry in the arms, as a child;    • to bear;    • to nurse or tend a child (Hawaiians did not carry children unrelated to them, and commoners did not touch a chief's child; carrying a child symbolized love, kinship, and affection). cf:
    Hiʻiaka, first part of the names of the twelve younger sisters of the goddess Pele...
    hiʻialo, carried in the arms, as a beloved child...
    hiʻikua, carried on the shoulders, as a beloved child...
    hiʻilani, to nurse or care for, as an infant...
    hiʻilei, to carry, tend, and cherish a beloved child...
    hiʻimoʻopuna, to bear a grandchild in the arms...
    hiʻipaka, to care for a child...
    hiʻipoi, to tend, feed, cherish, as a child...
to level off, as a flower bed.

• features, as of a face or landscape; 
   • sight, aspect.
to sleep, lie at ease, lounge, relax (this word sometimes replaces moe in poetry because moe suggests the sleep of death).
general appearance, as of a person; impression.
a single fishtail. fig., limited knowledge.
canoe stern. fig., a straight tree suitable for a canoe.
last bits of odds and ends; remnants of matting strips that must be cut off after plaiting is finished; ends of knots in plaiting; wispy end of a braid.

fishtail fern (Nephrolepis biserrata cv. furcans), a kind of sword fern, with forked divisions (pinnae). In Kaʻū, leis are made by combining pinnae of this fern (or whole frond) with flower sprays of wāpine (lemon verbena).
a fresh-water ʻoʻopu fish with a pinkish tail (hiʻu kole). It is taboo to some because it is believed related to the moʻo lizard gods.
whole fish used as bait for trolling.

water purification festivities on the second night of the month of Welehu (near the end of the year). The people bathed and frolicked in the sea or stream after midnight, then put on their finest tapa and ornaments for feasting and games.
water-tailed," said of one allegedly descended from a shark.
a kind of ʻahi, a tuna fish. lit., thin tail.
hind part or tail section of a fish, considered less delicious than the head or front section. See saying, pau₁.
to motion with the hands in a way destructive to the addressee.
marker of the caus/sim.; same as hoʻo-, but commonly found before words beginning with a glottal stop followed by a long vowel, as ʻāpuka, hoʻāpuka.
companion of a chief, fellow chief, chief descended from the god Kāne. fig., the gods.
traveling companion, fellow traveler. (In (Ios. 14.8)  "kou hoa hele" seems to be the Hawaiian translation of "my brethren.")
companion of a god, godly companion.
consultant, counselor, adviser, one with whom one confers and deliberates.
companion or contemporary of equal status.
same as hoa aliʻi, companion of a chief, fellow chief, chief descended from the god Kāne...
fellow worker, especially one helping to rear a child.
companion with whom one converses or consults.
a rounded tapa beater (also called hohoa, pepehi); rapid beating, striking, as of tapa or pandanus leaves; a stick beater for washing clothes. fig., bad-tempered.
joining, suture, joint. cf. hoa₂, and below.
bracelet of tusks of hog or dog.
disease of the abdomen, perhaps appendicitis, rupture (followed by a qualifier). see hoaka ʻīpuka hale, hoaka kākala. Other qualifiers reported are hāwele, kū, kū kahi, kū lua.
hone, whetstone, grindstone; to rub, grind.
to brandish, as a whip; to threaten.
tenant, caretaker, as on a kuleana.

• to tie, bind, 
   • secure, 
   • rig; rigging, 
   • lashing.
to strike with a stick or club; to club; a club.
a paddle with a blade narrower than the hoe nanue. lit., pointed paddle.
a type of paddle named for nenue fish, with broad and round blade.
steering paddle or oar, rudder, helm.
probably same as ʻēkaha ʻula fern, but according to some it is Elaphoglossum pellucidum, a smaller Elaphoglossum than the ʻēkaha ʻula. lit., Māui's paddle.
to pierce the ear lobes with acid.
a name for a Niʻihau pāwehe design in plaiting.
a plaintive prolonged sound, as of the nose flute.
to stir, poke, as a fire.
a soft sweet sound, as of song; to sound softly, rustle, sough, as the wind
to use a douche or enema; enema, medicine, injection, abortion.
to draw in the breath and expel it with a whistling sound, as when tired.
a bird reported by (Kep) as being the size of the ʻōʻō and black and gray.
a native fern (Dryopteris glabra) with rather finely divided fronds.
to spread out, unfold, unfurl, as tapa, mats, clouds, wings; to extend, stretch, diffuse.
to snore, snort, bray, heehaw, splash, gurgle, breathe hard, draw in mucus.

a native vine (Smilax sandwicensis), growing wild in the mountains; the leaves are heart-shaped, shiny, with longitudinal veins, much like the hoi but bearing tendrils; the roots are tuberous and not palatable.
Niʻihau name of a sea tern.

bitter yam (Dioscorea bulbifera, synonym D. sativa), a vine with cylindrical stem, heart-shaped leaves, small tuberous root, round aerial tubers. The tubers, used only in times of famine, need long washing to make them fit to eat. Called piʻoi on Kauaʻi. (HP 167), (Neal 230).
to strain kava; a kava strainer.
to squeeze, strain, as kava or liquids through fibers.
fat, fleshy, as thighs, buttocks, or calf.

• nape of the neck, shoulders (Puk. 12.34) ; 
   • main stem of a vine (Kep. 157).
to drug fish with ʻauhuhu (a small legume with pods used for poisoning fish). Niʻihau.
to groove or carve figures in the iʻe tapa beater.
to strip aerial roots of the ʻieʻie vine for baskets or plaiting.
to strip flesh from the bones, as formerly done with the dead, fig., to tell evil of one's relatives or reveal confidences.
to mix different feathers in a lei ; mingling, as feathers.
Holy Roller [disparaging and offensive term for a member of a Pentacostal sect].
to squirm, twist, turn, fidget; to caress passionately.
rippled surface of the sea, as caused by fish; undulation or vibration ...
immature and inferior, as breadfruit falling prematurely.
to sprout, as plants or a youth's beard.
to ask indirectly, seek to open conversation, search.
to run to and fro; bustle.
to progress, advance, surpass, go ahead; progress, advancement; successful.
to ride in a car or carriage.
to trot, as a horse; to jounce.

• to run, sail, move in two ways. 
   • fig., hypocrite; deceitful.
to pass off successfully, succeed, accomplish; successful; success.
to sail or travel around, circumnavigate; everywhere.
reckless, mad running; to tear madly, as a frightened horse; to speed recklessly, as an auto.
to ride horseback while wearing the sarong known as pāʻū; a pāʻū rider.
food bundle, especially ti-leaf bundle of hard poi.
to run about in a panic...
to ice skate, ski. lit., ice run.
to dart this way and that, as children at play; to veer at an angle, miss.
to go for a drive or ride. see song in (EM 53–4).
to gossip, slander, bear tales, tattle; tattler, talebearer, spreader of gossip.
a net into which fish run (holoholo) after being frightened; to fish with this net.
an old Hawaiian game of kicking a ball to which feathers were attached; to play this game.
to glance off, fly off obliquely, miss, fail to hit the mark. lit., run edge.
sailor; to sail to foreign lands.
seaman, seafarer; to sail on the sea; sea voyage or cruise.
to run or sail swiftly; headlong.
upper edge of an ʻōpelu fish net.
to run here and there; helter-skelter.

a loose, seamed dress with a yoke and usually with a train, patterned after the Mother Hubbards of the missionaries. cf. the muʻumuʻu, which formerly was not yoked and has no train or seam. Both garments are frequently made of gaily patterned material.
sailor, passenger, anyone who sails; to sail, take a sail or ocean trip.
rush or torrent, as of water; to rush, break forth, overflow. fig., overwhelming.
a long fitted dress, a combination of holokū and muʻumuʻu, a name probably coined after World War II.
a double bar to show the end of a piece of music.
a pain that nearly shuts off (pani) the breath.
to spread, overrun, prevail, overcome, control, defeat; everywhere, completely.
draft, air current, as in the mountains.
water ditch or course; to run in such courses; watery.
form or mold, as for making adobe bricks.
trough, especially vessel in which kava was mixed; oblong box, coffin, chest, cradle; furrow, as for planting sugar cane.
shuttle into which the bobbin of a sewing machine is slipped after it is filled with thread.

• to swim like a fish; 
   • to get the bends;  the bends, caisson disease.
   • to drown, 
   • to sink;   •
decided, determined, agreed upon, settled, approved, passed, enacted.
running hula step to the side; similar to kāholo except that the feet are not necessarily brought together
a long bundle, as of hard poi.
to sew, as a break in a gourd calabash.
holes in edge of a canoe, through which lashings were passed to hold a canoe cover in place.

diagonal pole or strut attached to the inner side of the roof framework and extending obliquely from the upper end of a rafter at one corner to the lower end of the rafter at the other corner; diagonal brace. see illus. 1, illus. 4
loss of a pebble in the kōnane game.
to blossom, as a flower or adolescent growing into maturity. Kaʻū.
to hold a canoe to its course in a rough sea.
beat of paddle on canoe side, as in rhythmic paddling while fish are driven into a net.
home rule; the name of the political party composed of native Hawaiians formed in the early years of Hawaiʻi as a territory. This party ended in 1912 after Kuhiō was elected delegate to Congress.
honeysuckle, a low, twining shrub (Lonicera japonica), from East Asia, with shortstemmed, oval leaves and fragrant tubular flowers that open white and turn yellow.
to throw a kiss; such a kiss.
a "puzzling" smell: said if the smell is out of place, as that of gardenias in a canoe at sea, interpreted as a warning of danger.
to kiss or smell repeatedly, sniff.
a loud kiss; to kiss loudly.
name of a tapa dyed with turmeric and worn as a sarong.
to smell, sniff, scent; a scent.
to touch, as a match to a combustible.

wild spiderflower (Gynandropsis gynandra), a cosmopolitan tropical hairy annual weed, native to Africa, in the caper family, 30 to 90 cm high, leaves five-parted; flowers spider-like, white with a purple tinge; fruit narrow, cylindrical capsule with many seeds.
the basket grass (Oplismenus hirtellus), a creeping grass that originated in America, called kukui because it is often found under kukui trees.
a variety of honohono₂ [wandering Jew, dayflower]
wandering Jew or zebrina, an ornamental, now naturalized, native to Mexico (Zebrina pendula).

the wandering Jew or dayflower (Commelina diffusa), known in many temperate and tropical countries, a creeping weed, rooting at the joints, and bearing grasslike, ovate leaves and small bright-blue flowers. Also honohono wai, and mākolokolo.

a very active former of caus/sim. derivatives. hoʻo- is treated as a prefix because it occurs only before bases; unlike prefixes, however, it takes the stress of a word, as does the following base; thus hoʻouna, to send, bears stress on the u and on the first o. hoʻo- usually precedes stems beginning with the vowels i- and u- and all the consonants except the glottal stop. important meanings follow...

to cause baldness; to shear the hair completely
complete defeat, as in card games, whitewash (keep opponent scoreless, slang)
to pass oneself off as a native son; like a native son
to pulverize, cut into little pieces.
to put an end to, terminate, conclude, annul, finish, stop; end.
to cause a scab to form, etc.
caus/sim of ʻōkomo, to insert, include; to calk, as a ship; to inlay...
redup. of hoʻōkomo caus/sim of ʻōkomo
to trip someone; to stumble or pretend to stumble
to cause to squat, crouch, perch; to crouch, perch
to restore to life, revive, resurrect
to save, heal, cure, spare; salvation; healer; savior...
small piece of tapa; tapa in general (Kauaʻi).
to cause to turn, shut, etc
caus/sim of ʻōlohe₁, bare, naked, barren; hairless, as a dog; bald; destitute, needy...
to denude. caus/sim of ʻōlohelohe, redup. of ʻōlohe₁ bare, naked, barren; hairless..
to cast a heavy shade; overcast
redup. of hoʻōmalu, to cast a heavy shade...
caus/sim of ōmamaka, same as ʻōmakamaka  redup. of ʻōmaka₁; to leaf out or bud afresh...

to cause to be stooped, bent, bowlegged; to imitate the walk of a bowlegged person
to impart fragrance; attractive, sweet, alluring
pumice; to rub and polish with sand

to spot or print with colors, as tapa
caus/sim of ʻōnoʻonou, to force upon...
to litter, make rubbish, strew, soil, make untidy
to cause a cramp, numbness, etc
to make young, freshen, refresh, rejuvenate; to act young
caus/sim of ʻōpulepule₁, moronic, somewhat crazy, psychotic. see pule and ex., ʻōhewahewa...
to cause to enter, put or dip in, thrust in, insert; to reach in
to provide food for a journey
to behave as one crazy; to cause craziness
to act like the tattler bird
to stir up, inspire, excite, taunt. also hoʻoulu
caus/sim of uōuō, redup. of uō bellow, roar...
a leading note in music, the major seventh of any scale, a semitone below the tonic.
combination, as of a safe. lit., number to make move.
also said of a sweet potato produced from the extended vine as distinguished from the product in the hill.
fallen fruit or seed. fig., friendless, uncared for by parents or chief; bastard, illegitimate child (modern); foetus lost through miscarriage.
ʻōhiʻa or ʻōhiʻa ʻai fruit uses as medicine (Kam. 64:103, 141); perhaps also a kind of wood.
small or inferior fruit; runt; small, puny.
notes in music; words of a song.
offering to a Congregational church of the first earnings in a new job or undertaking; offerings in gratitude for a particular success, as a big fish catch. lit., first fruit.
name of the hinahina root when used in hana aloha, love sorcery.
large fruit; to be fruitful, productive.
consonant. lit., letter joined in pronunciation.
date. lit., fruit of pāma, date palm.
grape, grapes (Vitis spp.). lit., wine (Eng.) fruit.
egg with a very soft shell.
child born out of wedlock, that is accepted by the husband or wife of the parent and treated as his own. lit., strange fruit. Kaʻū.
an affront to a family ʻaumakua god.
pill, tablet. lit., seed to swallow.

a small native naupaka (Scaevola kilaueae) found only on dry lava near Kīlauea Volcano. It does not exceed a height of 80 cm, has narrow, thick leaves, dull-yellow flowers, and small black fruits that were used to dye tapa.
rare name for the beach naupaka (Scaevola) plant.
interrogation to incriminate, ensnare, or obtain information by roundabout methods, to question or quiz indirectly.
fruitful, productive, prolific; to bear many fruits; to lay many eggs.

a vulgar gesture of contempt made by thrusting the thumb between index and middle fingers with the fist clenched, or the fist held up to the face and the eyelid drawn down. With the gesture one sometimes said, "Eia kāu ʻo ka huahua," "Here's your huahua gesture."
travels, a long trip; to keep traveling.
night procession or parade, especially the night procession of ghosts that is sometimes called ʻoiʻo.
clear as crystal, bright, dazzling, white, shining, flashing.
full and plump, as a healthy person; well proportioned, as a properly built canoe.
a variety of banana. lit., many fruits.
bright, polished, clean, pure, white, glittering, gleaming; morally pure.
musk, as used in making perfume.
tiny, yolkless egg. lit., wind egg.
round-ended bone entering the hip socket.
type of house with thatch purlins separated by a width of three fingers.

orange trumpet or sweetheart vine (Pyrostegia venusta syn. Bignonia venusta, B. ignea), an ornamental climber from Brazil, bearing early in the year many deep-orange flowers, hence chestnut-colored or light brown. lit. ripe fruit.
bones of the side of the head; side of the head.
collection of dew or rain water, pool.
boiling up, opening, uncovering: to gush forth, as lava.
to churn water, as a ship propeller

the red sandalwood tree (Adenanthera pavonina), from parts of tropical Asia and Malaysia, of moderate height and with rather widespreading branches. The tree is planted in parks, and its round, lens-shaped, red seeds are used for leis, and their long, yellow-lined pods for decorative arrangements.
round object, as pill or bead.

• result, effect; 
   • credit, as for a university course.
the bulging of the broadest part of a paddle blade.
a variety of gourd with a short beak.
water gourd shaped like an hourglass. lit., owl water gourd.
gourd water container with constriction about the middle.
type of bitter gourd, as used for utensils.
container or bag for liquids made of animal skin.
a wild passionflower (Passiflora suberosa) with small greenish-yellow flowers, small three-lobed or undivided leaves, and blackish fruits 1.3 cm in diameter.  lit., introduced huehue.
tail end, as of a strip of pandanus plaiting.
a native climber (Cocculus ferrandianus), with oval leaves and bluish one-seeded fruits. The stems were used for twine and for funnel-mouthed fish traps. (Neal 354.) Also hue ʻie.
chilled, benumbed, as of one shivering in this wind.
tail end, especially of a junior line of a lineage.
Australian bluegrass, Andropogon sericeus. lit., cat tail. Niʻihau.
sting, as of a scorpion, lit., bitter tail.

a small shrub (Buddleja asiatica), native of southeastern Asia to Java, growing wild in Hawaiʻi, related to the summer lilac. It has narrow leaves and small white flowers growing in long narrow clusters. lit., dog tail.
tail, as of dog, cat, or pig; train of a dress; tail-end, last. fig., inferior.
a wheezing sound, as of asthmatic persons; a prolonged shrill cry.
gourd, water calabash, any narrow-necked vessel for holding water, flask.
a type of hula dancing, usually at the end of a program, a kind of ʻai ʻami with a revolving of the hips as fast as the drummer can beat time, to see who can dance longest; to dance thus.
a way of connecting net sections by, interlocking meshes.
possibly a redup. of hue₂, fast.
to filch repeatedly, to steal in company.
to meet as equals, as two beautiful persons.
Hawaiian hula by many persons; to hula, of many.
lifting, tossing about, trotting, sporting, leaping, twisting.
redup. of hunehune and hune₁,₂; fine, dainty; stripped of all property.
hula dance by many; to dance the hula, of many.
to seek, turn, of many and repeatedly.
bristling, tousled, as feathers, fur, body hair.
to rise, as fur of an angry dog.
skin eruption on animals, as hog, dog; to have such.
a wood borer. fig., slanderer, defamer. lit., borer that digs wood.
probably a redup. of huʻe; to cease, quit.

• a wood-boring insect, termite; 
   • worm-eaten, rotten.
to pet, cherish, as animal pets.
short-tempered, peevish, cantankerous, angry without cause.
credit union. lit., society [for] loaning money.
united in one; in accord and agreement.
girded in malo or pāʻū tightly fastened with a single hitch.
any secret society or fraternity, as the Masons; Masonic; to meet secretly.
Chorus of Papa, a prayer for the purification of women uttered in the early morning at the Hale o Papa, house of Papa, a temple reserved for women.
to mix, unite, blend, assemble, combine, mingle. see ʻAmelika Hui Pū ʻIa.
to gather together like a flock of kōlea birds. fig., to gather together to help one another in time of trouble.
mixed, mingled, united, joined; to pool together, as to buy cooperatively.

• to absolve entirely, absolution;
   • forgive all faults, excuse, pardon, 
   • atonement, 
   • cleanse and purify morally; ceremonial cleansing.    cf. (Malo 199).
mixed, confused, haphazard, blurred; mix-up, confusion, jumble; to mix.
to mix or jumble, make disagreeing statements, put several stories into one. (hui₂ + -kaʻi, transitivizer).
disc wheel of a sewing machine.
stitch regulator of a sewing machine.
large wheel; flywheel, as of a sewing machine.
purchase price, as at an auction.
geometric figure. See huinahā, huinakolu, and others.
figure with four equal sides but oblique angles, rhombus.
quadrangle with only two sides parallel, trapezoid.
joining of two hands, especially in hand wrestling (uma).
raft. lit., collection of floating logs.
raft. lit., collection of floating boards.
pool, meeting place of two or more streams.
unit, cluster; military detail or detachment.
angle; corner, as of a house or street; crossroads, intersection, junction, juncture.
sharp, shrill sounds; to make such shrill cries.
wooden peg used in mending bowls.
kind of hard, black stone used for maika stones.
a kind of stone, as used for making maika stones.
a prayer on the morning after ʻanāʻanā sorcery.  (Pronunciation uncertain: perhaps huʻi.)
to join, unite, combine, mix, come together with; combination. See hui pū and saying, nāwao₁.
cluster, as of grapes or coconuts; bunch, as of bananas.
small uniting stick in a thatched roof, supporting rod for purlins.
one who has long served a chief.
hook, as on a door, shoes, clothes; to hook.
to pull or work together, cooperate.
to draw water; one who draws water.
to jerk, pull hard or suddenly.
fine-meshed net used for fish fry.
to disagree, quarrel; disagreement; not cooperative, headstrong, obstinate.
tug-of-war game; to play the game.
a seine; to fish with the seine. lit., pull ropes (lau).
a hula step: one foot steps to the side, the other foot is pulled toward it so that the heels almost touch, and then is taken to the opposite side.
soft, tender, as cooked meat that pulls apart when picked up.
twisted, drawn at the mouth, as a result of illness.
protuberance, lump, projection, elevation, jutting out, heap; to protrude, jut.

a kind of fast hula that increases to a frenzy, said to have been named originally for a mele maʻi named Pahua [pahua₁] (shoved). Emerson (UL 183–5) calls it a stick dance and gives an example. To perform this dance.
name of chest-slapping hulas performed for Kalākaua's coronation.
sacred dance in honor of the goddess Pele.
Hula in which the dancer imitates the motions of a turtle.
dance of the images in which the dancers postured stiffly like images; to dance thus. Kauaʻi.
a dance with love forfeits, similar to those in the kilu and ʻume games.
altar hula, any hula taught with ceremonies and an altar, contrasting with hula ʻauana.
sitting dance with gestures of hands and swaying of torso
sitting chant dance; the performer beats the gourd drum (ipu) and chants.
any interpretive hula, so called since the days of Kalākaua; lit., joined hula, i.e., old and new steps were joined together .

the punch (kuʻi) hula of Molokaʻi, an ancient, fast dance with stamping, heel twisting, thigh slapping, dipping of knees, doubling of fists as in boxing, vigorous gestures imitative of such pursuits as dragging fish nets, and unaccompanied by instruments. This dance originated on Molokaʻi, an island famous for sports. Many of the songs contain taunts, as a laʻa kō kū i ke aʻu, now you are jabbed by the swordfish. cf. hula kuʻi under kuʻi, joined.
a kneeling hula imitative of the kōlea, plover.
name of hulas performed for the coronation of Kalākaua, probably stick hulas.
dance with a thin flexible stick which the squatting dancer beats time as by striking the floor.
name of hulas performed for Kalākaua's coronation.
any sitting hula; to perform such.
dance to drum beat, perhaps formerly called ʻai haʻa (UL 103)
dance in which the dancers use the papa hehi, treadle boards; this dance is said to have originated on Niʻihau.
a spider dance with stiff legs, dancers hopped, right foot forward and left in reverse; then opposite, keeping time with a boisterous chant and with hands fluttering vigorously.
a hula dance in which the hips sway from side to side in imitation of a fat hog's waddling. Also ʻami puaʻa.
informal hula without ceremony or offering, contrasted with the hula kuahu; modern hula.
Hula in which smooth water-worn stones are used as clappers or castanets; the pebble hula.
a hula imitative of the movements of a dog.
name of hulas performed for Kalākaua's coronation.
ballrom dancing with partners, American dancing, ball; massed hula dancing; to dance.
ceremonial killing of a pig and offering it to the gods during the long ceremonies dedicating a luakini temple.
to jump for joy, cavort with happiness.

• shining,  to shine,
   • glittering, glitter, sparkle, 
   • glossy, 
   • reflect light.
   • slippery;
a kind of loli, sea cucumber.

same as hulā, 
   • to prod, pry, 
   • uproot, 
   • pierce and penetrate, 
   • expel, 
   • reject...
place where it is necessary to swim past a cliff that blocks passage along a beach or coast; sheer cliff where the sea beats.
song or chant used for the hula; to sing or chant for a hula.
to twitch, as a muscle or eyelid; to palpitate, throb.
repeated motions or lifting; to seesaw.
intensifier of hulei; to toss and pitch, trot, swing.
a kind of soft pumice stone.
to turn toward; to face one another.
diligent in work; to seek work.
profound study of earth, geology; to do such. cf. (RC 433).

• to turn back; 
   • inverse, as in math.
profound studies of any kind, moral philosophy, social science, anthropology; to do such.
to turn one's back, refuse to help, ignore; one who does so, as one who is offended.
back section, as back house wall.
to turn in two directions or twice; to shift, as the wind; unstable, shifting.
to seek an opinion; to change an opinion.
to overturn completely; to search everywhere; said sometimes as equivalent to modern "bottoms up", toast, instead of the vulgar "ōkole maluna".
to overturn, turn upside down, overthrow.
to remove the bitterness, especially to pour off the bitter liquid and add fresh water to the preparation of arrowroot (pia).
to think of the past, recall the past.
to seek into the depths of a matter, to describe fully; description.
ornamental comb decorated with feathers, with ornaments turned towards the back.

• a variety of large gourd or calabash, used as receptacle for tapa or garments, or for food offerings. 
   • fig., a woman, mother, wife.
to find enough material goods, as food.

• dazzling light, 
   • vibration, undulation; 
   • to blaze, sparkle, dazzle, glare, 
   • vibrate, 
   • swell.
name of a reddish-brown honey-sucking bird (no data). lit., banana seeker.

• turning, turning place, 
   • overturning,
   • reversing, 
   • frontage.
second mate of a vessel. lit., binnacle turner.
to join together in great numbers to cooperate; to act with unanimity, as a political party.
strong, as the sea. [see (Gram. 8.7.2): huli-ā-mahi 'turn like a strong (cock)'; i.e., cooperation, strength. see mahi₂: strong, energetic, as a worker. moa mahi, fighting cock.]
to lean over to one side, tilt, turn to the side.
section, as of a town, place, or house.
taro top, as used for planting; shoot, as of wauke (see ʻae₇).
royal favorite and loved one; royal feather.
long tail feathers, as of a rooster.
the precious few living blood relatives of the grandparent's generation (a term of affection and pride).
precious parent or relative of the parent's generation.
green seaweeds (Caulerpa spp.), growing like land plants, with roots, prostrate stems, and leaflike divided fronds; not edible.
body hair, animal hair, or feathers standing on end.

a small, matted, red seaweed (Spyridia spinella), its many branches covered with short bristles. It is rather common in shallow water near shore. It is eaten in South Hawaiʻi, but not generally elsewhere.
an esteemed, beloved person well cared for. lit., choice one not rejected.
a fine, red seaweed (Centroceras clavulatum), forming short, dense, regularly branching tufts, with tiny forked tips; not edible. lit., dog fur.
fine, branching, edible brown seaweeds (Ectocarpus spp.), forming short, olive-brown clumps.
a fine, branching, green seaweed (Cladophora nitida), forming flexible, long, bright-green tufts; said to be edible.
a fine, feathery, green, fresh-water alga (Stigeoclonium amoenum), found in streams and ditches; said to be edible.
a fine, unbranched, green seaweed (Chaetomorpha antennina), looking much like hulu ʻīlio₃.
a fine, nonedible, brown seaweed (Sphacelaria tribuloides), densely tufted, shorter and darker brown than Ectocarpus.
an irregularly branching, dark-red seaweed (Grateloupia falicina) with many narrow segments. It is commonly eaten and is sold in some markets.
a green, velvety, carpet-like mountain moss. The spore cases rise above the plants. lit., fur like a dog's.
body hair, hair of eyelashes, fleece (Lunk. 6.37) , wool, fur; hairy.
frayed, splintered, rough, not smooth, shaggy, bristling, feathery.
down or fuzz on plant stems, rootlet.
a kind of bag fish net; to drag such a net.
to take or grab, as winnings.
tick used for mattresses and pillow covers, so called because they were stuffed with bird feathers.

the Hawaiian mistletoes (Korthalsella spp. formerly called Viscum), small plants perching on trees and extracting part of their food from them. They have flat or cylindrical jointed green stems. lit., chicken feathers.

a moss said to grow only in Pālolo Valley, Honolulu, named for Kaʻauhelemoa, a legendary cock defeated in battle by a hen. She pulled out his feathers, which fell and became this moss. It is used in leis.
light brown, bay, as a horse.
beard hanging from the breast of mature turkey males. lit., hog hair.
a pig that is reddish-colored about the hams. lit., ʻiwi bird feather.
scrubbing or painting brush, formerly made of a coconut husk.
esteemed, choice, precious; esteemed older relative, as of parents or grandparents' generations. (This meaning may be connected with the value attached to featherwork.)
fur, wool, fleece, human body hair (contrasting with lauoho, head hair).
hackle; fishhook with barb on the outside.
muscle attaching a bivalve to rocks.
seal, named for its valuable fur.

• to prod, pry, 
   • uproot, 
   • pierce and penetrate, 
   • expel, 
   • reject
a girding on of a loincloth; part of the loins covered by the malo.
back stitching; to sew with back stiching.
chain stitch; to make chain stitches.
to sew in a diagonal line.
pinktail durgon (Melichthys vidua). lit., red-tailed triggerfish.
bridled triggerfish (Sufflamen fraenatus). lit., urine triggerfish, so called because of its odor.
a variety of humuhumu fish (Balistes bursa). lit., humuhumu with leis on its chest.
black triggerfish (Melichthys niger), used as fuel when fuel was scarce.

varieties of humuhumu (Rhinecanthus aculeatus, R. rectangulus). lit., humuhumu with a snout like a pig. [In l984, the reef triggerfish (Rhinecanthus rectangulus) was selected as the official State Fish of Hawai‘i after a popular vote and the approval of the State Legislature.  The State Fish’s official term of office lasted five years, and there was no re-election campaign.  In May of 2006 Governor Linda Lingle signed a bill that permanently established the humuhumunukunukuāpua‘a as the State Fish of Hawai’i.]
to sew, of many or continuously.

trigger fish. The name humuhumu is qualified by the following terms (in addition to those listed separately as identified): kapa or kapu, lei , māneʻoneʻo (said to be irritating to the mouth), ʻuwīʻuwī (thought by some to be the young of the māneʻoneʻo).
a variety of taro with coloring like that of the humuhumu (fish); the leaf stem is pink at base, dark-purple midway and green above.
a dark-colored birthmark, believed to be the result of the pregnant mother's eating humuhumu (fish).
pattern in pāwehe plaiting, said to consist of a continuous row of red lozenges with their lateral angles touching.
to sew to a backing, as feather leis.
lock stitch, a stitch that does not loosen easily; to sew thus.
red jasper stone, as used for adzes.
hole by which parts of a hook were bound together.
a battle unit, either a single individual or a group of men; host of an army.
waste and refuse of olonā after the fiber is cleaned.
a species of Hypnea, a seaweed. lit., brittle huna.
a particle, as ua, e, i in Hawaiian.
white-flowered beach morning-glory (Ipomea stolonifera; synonym, I. acetosaefolia), distributed in tropical regions, with oblong to lyre-shaped leaves, and white flowers with yellow centers.
sanderling (Calidris alba), a small winter migrant to Hawaiʻi, cinnamon brown with dark markings. lit., sea foam, so called from the bird's habit of following close behind receding waves.
a kind of tapa with white and yellow dots.
van of an army, front ranks.
minute particle, grain, crumb, gram, speck, tiny bit, scrap, minutia; small, little, powdery. (This word is similar to hune₂.)
hidden secret; hidden. cf. huna₁, a stative usually following nouns, and the transitive verb hūnā.
common, fine, red seaweeds (Hypnea spp.), irregularly and more or less densely branching, thorny looking; eaten cooked, furnishes a good colloid when boiled.
redup. and intensification of hune₂, very fine, delicate.
bits, as of news, gossip; minutia.
to hide frequently or be hidden by many persons; secretly.
collection; catch, as of fish. (This rare word is not clear.)
envy, jealousy; envious, jealous; to stir up trouble due to envy.
taboo borders, as of a taboo place, or of the taboo enclosure where hula was taught.
trimmings or borders of a garment; hem of a dress.
sea foam; crest of a wave breaking into foam.
a coarse, weedy native dock (Rumex albescens) in the buckwheat family.
to scatter dust, especially a method of fighting with a club or spear in which the opponent was blinded by stirring up dust; to hit an underhanded blow.
pile, as of mats or tapa.
small hula graduating exercises held at noon outside in the dust (lepo).
heavy end of a coconut frond.
water trough or pipe, aqueduct, flume. rain gutter (HE)
hereditary stalk; established people with inherited land.
to grope here and there, feel.

a native tree lobelia (Cyanea leptostegia), found only on Kauaʻi. The trunk is slender, unbranched, to 12 m high, and bears a crown of narrow leaves that are up to 60 cm long. The many flowers are purplish-red, the fruits yellow berries.
a native shrubby lobelia (Cyanea horrida), from Maui, with thorny branches and rough, lobed leaves.
manta ray, sea devil, family Mobulidae (Manta alfredi). lit., two mouths (two flap-like appendages extend forward on each side of the mouth).
to catch fish with the hands, as in crevices.
salt bed or pool; to gather salt.

a native lobelia (Clermontia clermontioides), found only in high mountains of Kauaʻi, a shrub or small tree with many branches; oblong and narrow leaves; greenish-purple, curved flowers; and sweet, edible yellow berries. lit., hāhā, food of the birds, so called because the thick sap was used for catching birds.
to grope, feel, as with the hands.
trap made of twigs and small branches, for fresh-water fish.

lobelias. see 
     hāhāʻaiakamanu, a native lobelia, (Clermontia clermontioides), Kauaʻi...
     hāhā lua, a native tree lobelia, (Cyanea leptostegia), Kauaʻi...
     hāhā nui, a native shrubby lobelia (Cyanea horrida), Maui...
Kauaʻi name for ʻapeʻape, all endemic species of Gunnera, huge leafed forest perennial herbs, with thick, prostrate stems rising at the tip to about 120 cm.
debilitated, weak, as from age or sickness.
decaying, as taro in the field or a few days after cooking.
hole for inserting mast in a canoe.
to protrude, as bones or cliff ridges.
pin, nail, spike; to fasten, nail.
to observe closely, spy on, reconnoiter, snoop, eavesdrop.
parched, as a blemished bread-fruit; unhealthy condition of a banana when the skin adheres to the pulp, supposedly after the plant has been touched by the ʻākōlea fern.
to steam, as by placing fish, meat, or vegetables in a sealed calabash with hot stones and a little hot water.
pock-marked, as by smallpox; ravaged, as by leprosy; coarse, rough, lumpy, pitted; mossgrown.
dark, thick, as clouds. fig., intense, as love.
to beat, pound, pummel; to echo, reverberate; to flutter, palpitate, thump; to puff, as smoke.
to carve out a pathway, as a passage through coral or as a water course.
ancient type of sitting wrestling, the object being to topple over the opponent; to wrestle thus.
to bend low (For. 4:283); to travel far.
steaming decoction of herbs, as prescribed for sickness.
to place under, lift up from beneath; to give an enema, douche.
yellowish, pale yellow; to bleach, as tapa.
toilet paper or anything so used; to wipe, as with toilet paper.
to bud, spring forth; to shed a shell, as a crab.
sundial shell, members of the Architectonicidae family.
