   • incline, 
   • have regard.
to spread over pili grass, said poetically of a rain shower.
long stalk, poetic name for lauloa taro.
a type of prayer. (For. 6:37) lit., long breath.
puddle, pool, pond; to form a pool.
peering; place from which to peer, place to peer at, lookout.
to well with tears, form pools.
to make sturdy, as a banana plant (a word used in ancient prayers).

• hollow, dip, furrow, groove, pit; 
   • pitted, full of holes.

• to ambush, lie in wait, waylay, 
   • spy, 
   • provoke trouble.
a sea urchin with longer spines than those of the wana.
tapa-beater design, said to resemble a pandanus lei  and consisting of interlocked triangles.
tapa-beater design. The panels between the hāluʻa lines are enhanced by regularly spaced small triangles. lit., sharktooth hāluʻa.
a tapa-beater design. The triangles of the niho manō pattern are bordered by oblique lines pāwehe.
a tapa-beater pattern with circular motifs (pūpū).
stripe, ripple; striped, ridged, seamed, streaked, wrinkled.
pattern on the surface of a tapa beater or tapa. This term may follow types of beaters, as koʻeau hāluʻa, mole hāluʻa, pūʻili hāluʻa. It also precedes types of beaters, as listed below.
to peer, as with the hands shading the eyes; to peep.
offering for a pastor, of Congregationalists. lit., feeding pastor.
to renew offerings on a kuahu altar; one who does so.
to feed, give food to; food provider.
title of the bearer of an image, who ate the food offered to the god.
to make a pet of an animal; to care for well, as a pet; cherished plans, pet projects.
Hawaiʻi island word for mānai, needle for stringing leis...
younger brother or sister; the last-born.
childbearing, prolific, fertile, having many children; mother of one's children, wife.
first-born child, especially the eldest living member of the senior branch of a family; senior, older brother or sister.
reincarnation; to be born repeatedly, as Haumea, an earth mother.  lit., repeated birth.
peculiar or unusual birth; born with a strange sign or mark.

• to fall, as a building; to collapse, 
   • slide, slip.

to snore, to talk with nasalized sounds; blurred, as sound.
surging, swollen; choppy, as the sea; slippery muddy.
ridgepost supporting each end of the ridgepole.
to carry or lift, as an invalid unable to raise himself in bed or walk.
to carry sugar cane bundles on the back, as formerly done by plantation workers.

a native variety of banana with trunk of medium height, the fruit maturing within it, about two-thirds of the way up. The fruits are small, finger length, and ten or less; their skin is yellow, and the flesh yellow, sweet, and edible raw. (HP 175), (Neal 250).

• to grope, feel the way, 
   • reach for, 
   • extend out; 
   • to experience, feel.    
['iniʻini in example changed to ʻiniʻiniki to match cited text. see note at ʻiniʻini.]
stick for catching ʻio hawks; the crosspieces were gummed and a live bird was tied as a decoy.
short, as a piece of wood or clouds.
a medicinal plant (no data); a kind of fiber used for nets.
to collect, gather together in haste or indiscriminately and usually for oneself.
crane (for moving objects); bucket attached to a crane.
spring, pool, puddle fig., child, as representing continuation of life.
an endemic tree fern (Cibotium chamissoi, formerly called C. menziesii) much like the hāpuʻu and also known as hāpuʻu, but bearing stiff blackish hairs on the frond stems.
Dryopteris paleacea var. fusco-atra, a much smaller endemic fern (not a tree) with dark hairs at stems' base.
young hāpuʻu ferns that have not yet developed trunks.
a mound, as for playing marbles.

the plant is said to be distinguished by its leaf stems: yellow-green above, and dark brownish on lower half. The corms yield good light-colored poi, the leaves good greens. This name is qualified by the terms ʻeleʻele, keʻokeʻo, and maoli.
grouper, a fish (Epinephelus quernus). The young stage is hāpu ʻupuʻu or ʻāpu ʻupuʻu.
budding. fig., child, baby; young, as of squid (rare).
a variety of taro, also hāpuʻupuʻu, that may be qualified by the colors ʻeleʻele,hāuliuli (favored by planters), kea or keʻokeʻo, lena, and ʻulaʻula.
a variety of hāuliuli, a fish. lit., eel hāuliuli.
a fish (Gempylus serpens), sometimes called the snake mackerel.

• small fish with formerly transparent body beginning to darken; 
   • embryo of human or animal.
stroke or thrust of the war club.
a line, as used in lashing a mat canoe cover; to add a new weft in plaiting.
to generate steam in an earth oven by pouring on water (Kep. 163); to purify with water.
temporary long, gabled house in which priestesses assembled for purification ceremonies.
nut of the loulu, native palm, considered delicious to eat; also the tree itself.
a small, fine, red seaweed (Polysiphonia spp.), consisting of branching filaments forming dense tufts.
to wallow in troughs, as a rough sea.

• a sea urchin (Tripneustes gratilla). 
   • fig., of no character or substance, perhaps so used because of the sayings below. 
   Varieties of sea urchin are qualified by the terms maoli (natural) and poʻo hina (gray-head).
a kind of stone, used as sinkers for octopus lures.
white lime, as used for dressing hair and turning the hair brown.

• glowing. 
   • fig., distinguished, honored (used after hano).
unskilled, awkward, clumsy, incompetent, blundering; blunder, incompetence.
a variety of sweet potato used to make beer.

   • rippling.
to begin to turn yellow, as ripening mango or papaya.
short strips of wauke bark, as used for tapa.
sections or divisions following in the procession after a high chief.
to carry a burden on the back, pack; a bundle or burden so carried, backpack.

a tumbling game: a player lies face down, reaches back and grasps his ankles, pulling them back and up to form a loop; the second player, lying at right angles to the first, slips his arm in that loop and tumbles the player over his head; to play this game.
dirty, drab; smudged, as by smoke.
kind of tapa wrapped about images.

stem of a gourd leaf, as used in medicine.

name in some localities for hāʻukeʻuke, sea urchin.
an edible variety of sea urchin (Colobocentrotus atratus). The teeth were used for medicine. (KL. line 23) Varieties are qualified by the terms kau pali (cliff-perching), kai ʻina, and ʻulaʻula.
to miss, fall or lag behind.
a variety of sweet potato. lit., fallen from the sky.
a freshwater alga found in taro patches.
redup of hāʻule₁ to fall, drop..., hāʻule₂ to lose, fail... hāʻule₃ to begin to do...

• to lose, loss, defeat.

to breathe, exhale; to breathe upon, as kava after praying and before prognosticating; breath, life.
stalk that supports the leaf and enfolds the stem of certain plants, as taro, sugar cane; layers in a banana stump.
trough, ditch, sluice; to form a ditch or trough.
stick or furrowed stone used as a sinker, with hooks attached.

a native tree (Eugenia [Syzygium] sandwicensis), with red, edible fruit about 8.5 mm. in diameter, related to the mountain apple, ʻōhiʻa ʻai. The bark was used to color tapa black. also ʻōhiʻa hā, and pāʻihi (on Maui).
fourth note in the musical scale, fa.
a boil, running sore; ulcerous; botch (KJV) boils (RSV).
pale yellow, of the domesticated ʻilima flower.
a variety of sweet potato usually called ʻuala hēʻī.
upper part of a crab's leg.
poi from the center or core of taro, formerly reserved for chiefs, as it had not come into contact with dirt.
edges of the mouth of the square uhu (parrot fish) net.
hollow container in which canoe paint was mixed.
to cast for bonito; bonito casting.
dysentery caused by eating laulele greens; name of a famine during the sandalwood-cutting days when farms were neglected and the people lived on laulele greens.
various sting rays (Dasyatidae) and eagle rays (Actobatus narinari).
endemic grainy snail (Neritinu graposa), in both fresh and brackish water, eaten both cooked and raw.  also wī, if in fresh water.
a pelagic grapsid crab, probably Grapsus tenuicrustatus.
a tide in the high-tide zone.
gibberish; to talk gibberish; to speak a foreign language, especially English.
binding, tying; to tie, bind, make fast.
careless, shiftless (named for the people of Hīlea village, Kaʻū, Hawaiʻi, reported to have brought poorly prepared poi to a chief).
thin, fine, as hair. Probably obsolete except in names.
thin, feeble, weak, spindling, slender, puny, debilitated.
a round basket or container, as braided around a calabash.
a saddle wrasse up to 20 cm. long (Thalassoma duperreyi).
a blacktail wrasse up to about 18 cm. long (Thalassoma ballieui). lit., old-lady wrasse.
yellowtail coris, Coris gaimard, up to 46 cm.

small- to moderate-sized, brightly colored wrasses, family Labridae. 
   • In addition to those listed below, hīnālea may be qualified by the terms ʻeleʻele, līpoa, lolo, nīʻau, nuku ʻiʻiwi, nuku ʻiʻiwi ʻula, nuku ʻiʻiwi uli, nuku loa, nuku loa ʻeleʻele. cf. ʻōpule. 
   • hīnālea was eaten raw as an aftertaste for kava. It was prepared in the iʻa hoʻomelu fashion with kukui nuts and chili pepper [nīoi]; 
   • as this had a somewhat offensive smell, the phrase ipu kai hīnālea, dish of hīnālea sauce, was applied rudely to one with unpleasant breath, especially if he had the iʻa kui, nasal discharge.
knot, bond, fastening; to tie a knot.
tied bundle, purse (Sol. 1.14) , (Isa. 3.22) ; to bundle up.
to cast or troll, as for bonito, ʻahi, and kala.
caus/sim. marker before glottal stop and short vowel or before long vowel or vowels, as ʻike, hōʻike, ʻā, hōʻā, hōʻāʻā.

caus/sim of ʻailolo₁, ceremony usually marking the end of training, so called because the student ate (ʻai) a portion of the head, and especially the brains (lolo), of a fish, dog, or hog offered to the gods; to partake of the ceremony...
caus/sim of ʻalalā₁, to bawl, bleat, squeal, cry, caw, yelp, wail, scream; such noises...

a design on Niʻhau mats. lit., falling star.

a small native tree (Ochrosia compta) related to the hao (Rauvolfia) and closely resembling it, but the leaves thicker, the yellow flowers fragrant, and the twinned fruits yellow and much larger. Formerly, bark and roots yielded a yellow dye for tapa.
tapa dyed with hōlei; to dye thus.
same as hoʻoleʻoleʻo agitated, stormy, tempestuous; rising and falling as waves

emotionally excited, as with hate, love, lust.

a perennial herb (Lagenophora maviensis), found only in marshy high parts of West Maui. The leaves form a basal rosette, from which rises a stalk bearing a round daisy-like flower head with yellow center and white rays.
marker of the caus/sim.; same as hoʻo-; occasionally found before words beginning with i-, as ikaika, hōʻikaika.

a native fern (Dryopteris stegnogrammoides syn. Stegnogramma sandwicensis), resembling the kikawaiō, having large pinnate fronds, but the tip tapering to a point instead of forming a separate lobe. Young fronds are eaten raw, like those of the hōʻiʻo.

a large native fern (Diplazium [Athyrium] arnottii) with subdivided fronds. The young fronds are eaten raw, much liked with raw fresh-water shrimps or with salted salmon. Only Orientals cook this fern. It was formerly sold in the market. It will not grow at low altitudes. cf. pohole, the Maui name. (HP 214), (Neal 25).

heart or heavy core of a tree.
directional and reflexive pair. iho + demon. -la.

a favorite and common native variety of banana, eaten raw or cooked. The fruit bunches are small, the skin thin, ripening yellow, the flesh salmonpink. (HP 115). This was one of the few bananas permitted women. Also hilahila. lit., yellow core.
collective terms for inner layers of white sleeping tapas below the kilohana.
block used in plaiting a hat to give shape to the crown.
down, below. Iho + demon. la is pronounced and written as a single word, ihola.
same part. and reference as above but with reflexive meaning, often following words describing activities of the body, as eating, drinking, thinking.
same part. and reference as above, with meaning "self" personally.
same part. and reference as iho₆,₇,₈, but used with words of time, usually present or future, but past if followed by nei.
to snore or speak with nasalized sounds.
same as kilu₃, unpleasant musty odor, and iʻakui, nasal discharge; ozena (EH)
tilted nose, pug nose. fig., haughty, snobbish, snooty, contemptuous.
canoe with a large bow, hollowed from the large end of a log instead of from the butt end, as was customary.
to snore with prolonged sounds; such snoring. lit., moaning nose.
scab nose, an insulting term for a lunkhead.
elevated nose, fig., scornful, haughty, aloof, contemptuous, disdainful, snobbish, snooty.
to breathe with difficulty due to partial obstruction of the nostrils, as of one with a cold.
gourd nose, said of one with superficial knowledge or lack of skill, perhaps so called because one floats like a gourd rather than descends to the depths of knowledge (ihupani). stupid.
to wrinkle up the nose, as to show scorn.
possibly a syphilitic saddlenose or damage from leprosy.  lit., no nose.
to snore with short puffs; such snoring. lit., gurgling nose.
name of an odoriferous tree or shrub.
rising upward, as the prow of a canoe. fig., scornful.
expert, wise person, wisdom. lit., closed nose, perhaps referring to deep diving and hence profound knowledge.
a variety of rarely cultivated bunana, wild in forests of Kauaʻi and Hawaiʻi, with short, slender green trunk, and yellow fruit with yellow flesh, edible only when cooked.
prow or bow of a canoe or ship. nose of a plane (HE)
stifling heat and humidity; acute discomfort, pain, grief, suffering; to be weary, stifling, sultry, stuffy.
a kind of stone, as used for making maika stones.
a pestilence said to have come in the reign of Waia, believed the same as the ʻōkuʻu disease of 1804.
name given for a disease, probably stomach ulcers.
visiting place in a grass house.
officer, as in a society. Several types are listed below.
chief of rank below the hoa aliʻi descendants of Kāne₂; chiefs of this rank could rule as mōʻī but were not considered divine. But cf. mōʻī₁.
genealogy of chiefs of the hoa aliʻi class (descendants of Kāne₂), the highest of all.
to offer a prayer of thanksgiving; such a prayer.
changing colors of an octopus skin.
a tattletale, talebearer, gossip; to tattle, gossip.

an endemic woody plant (Wilkesia gymnoxiphium), related to the ʻāhinahina or silversword, found only in western mountains of Kauaʻi. It is 1 to 4 m high, unbranched, the stems ending in clumps of long narrow leaves.

• stricken with awe, reverence, 
   • dread (PH 33); 
   • overcome, 
   • thrilled, as by beauty.
unexpected rain, as from a sunny sky; to rain thus.
place where a stream goes underground.
grave, tomb, sepulcher, cemetery, mausoleum, plot in a cemetery.
horseweeds (Conyza spp.), tall, slender coarse weeds of the daisy family, established in Hawaiʻi; used medicinally. One species is laniwela.
name reported for a green fresh-water moss.

befall, to fall upon, as 
   • sorrow, 
   • responsibility, 
   • blessings (Kanl. 28.2) , 
   • curses (Kanl. 28.15) .
wormy, maggoty; sprouting, germinating. Sorcerers cursed by saying that maggots would eat a victim's body
maggot, grub, worm; to creep, as worms, to be beset by maggots.
oven in which hau wood was heated (hana) to be bent for a canoe outrigger.
oven with food intended as an offering to appease (hoʻomaʻalili) a god.
oven for baking a long time; oven for baking human sacrifice.

oven used as a sweat bath: the hot rocks of the oven were covered with a thick layer of greenery (as ginger, maile, ti); the patient lay here and was covered with more leaves and tapa; the treatment was said to last ten days and included prayers; its purpose was to remove the influence of sorcery. lit., long oven [with idea that a long life would follow].
Hawaiian oven built above the ground, with an opening through which wood could be stoked (pao).
rock and coral fish trap; the fisherman might insert a branch into an opening at one side to frighten the fish into a surrounding net.
Let me see! Show it to me!
to pry, as with a lever.
to vary or modulate the tone of voice; to sound, as from a distance.
in! (Cry of children in a marble game when the marble is "in" a hole.)
nickname, fictitious name, pet name, pen name, alias, assumed name...
dream name, as a name for an infant believed received in a dream; it was thought that if such a name were not given, the child would be sickly or die.
esteemed name, especially of a chief. lit., fragrant name.
a name given to a child by a supernatural voice, usually heard just before the child's birth; a voice name.
namesake.  (in fast speech often preceded by ke)

an affectionate term for affinal relatives, or in-laws of in-laws, or relatives usually not related by blood; inoa may be followed by a kinship term indicative of generation (as moʻopuna, kaikamahine, keiki, makua, kupuna), or of the common relative (as puluna, hūnōna.) A grandchild's spouse's relatives united by affection to the speaker might thus be called inoa moʻopuna. Similarly the cousins of a puluna (parents-in-law of an offspring) might be inoa puluna, and the cousins or in-laws of a parent might be inoa makua. The relationship might also extend to close family friends.  (in fast speech often preceded by ke)
name chant or song. (in fast speech often preceded by ke)
to drink rum or other alcoholic drink; one who drinks.
to drink but a little, sip.
short rib extending upward from the tip of a paddle, on the forward surface.
rounded grooves in carving, as in kukui nuts used in necklaces; depression made by stitches in quilting; grooved.
to make love (less used than hoʻoipoipo).
iron pot; kettle or saucepan of any sort, skillet, whether glass, aluminum, or enamel. lit., iron container.
gourd drum with a top section (heke).
gourd drum consisting of a single gourd without a top section.
gourd containing fisherman's gear and bait, or a traveler's possessions, lit., traveling container.
finger bowl. lit., container wash hand.
dance drum made of two gourds sewed together.
a variety of watermelon with a slightly fuzzy (huluhulu) skin, and with whitish or pale-pink pulp; it is edible but not greatly liked; it formerly grew wild at Kaʻū.

• a dish for meat or any dish deep enough to hold gravy (kai); gravy boat. 
   • fig., lowland areas, often an affectionate term and with a connotation of bountiful sea food.    
cf. also hīnālea.
container for sacred objects; gourd calabash covered with a sennit net and suspended by a handle composed of four cords; food offerings were placed inside for the god Lono.

the cup of gold (Solandra hartwegi, often called S. guttata), a large climbing shrub from Mexico, with long-stemmed, oblong leaves. The large, showy, fragrant flowers bloom in winter, are about 23 cm long, goblet-shaped with five shallow lobes, and are yellow with five narrow purple longitudinal streaks. lit., golden (Eng.) container.
incense burner, censer. lit., container burning fragrance.
churn. lit., container for pounding butter.
earthenware pot, clay pot, vessel of earth (Oihk. 15.12) , potter's vessel (Hal. 2.9) ; chamber pot. lit., dirt container.
a variety of gourd with nonbitter pulp.  lit., sweet gourd.
a large container; the great bronze laver in Solomon's temple.
a variety of watermelon with fruit like that of ipu poʻo kanaka, but ovoid and larger.
gourd drum. lit., gourd to beat.
a variety of watermelon with round, small fruit, smooth skin, and red pulp.  lit., human head melon.
a variety of cantaloupe. lit., feast melon.
washbasin. fig., chiefs' genealogists who were supposed to keep the characters of their masters clean.
gourd drum. (This word is actually ipu uai [uwai], movable gourd.)
watermelon, melon. lit., melon to eat raw.
lit., melon to eat in mouth.
scrap bowl, slop basin, refuse container.
calabash or vessel for food or food offering.
container for perfume or other fragrant matter. lit., fragrant gourd.
large gourd calabash in which food was offered to the ʻaumakua family gods.
washbasin; container of water for a bath.
a variety of gourd (Lagenaria siceraria) with bitter-tasting pulp, used medicinally. Its strong odor is eradicated by soaking in sea water.
a kind of introduced muskmelon (Cucumis melo).
speaking gourd, a gourd containing pebbles and other objects used in divination; oracle.
lantern. lit., light for going at night.
shell container of the hiwa green coconut used in ceremonies honoring the god Kāne.
a variety of taro used as offering to the gods; it may be qualified by the terms kea and ʻulaʻula.
an agricultural heiau; a heiau where ceremonies seeking to obtain rain were held.
shell of the yellow-husked or lelo coconut.
wood rollers laid under a canoe being hauled to prevent it from being scratched or damaged.

the watermelon (Citrullus lanatus), a wide-spreading vine from tropical Africa, with large, lobed leaves and yellow flowers. It is grown for its edible fruits, which are round or oblong, green or green with light stripes, and full of sweet, juicy, rose-colored pulp surrounding flat, black seeds, The watermelon was introduced to Hawaiʻi about 1792 and thrived until the melon fly arrived about 1910. Among many varieties that were developed were three outstanding ones: ipu huluhulu, ipu poʻo kanaka, and ipu oloolo. Today watermelons are again cultivated successfully because the fruits are commonly wrapped in paper or cloth during early stages.
general name for vessel or container, as dish, mug, calabash, pot, cup, utensil, urn, bowl, basin, pipe.
drum consisting of a single gourd or made of two large gourds of unequal size joined together.
a deified bone of an ancestor, an ʻunihipili.
hyoid bone at the base of the tongue. lit., tongue bone.
hard, upper part of pandanus key.
rock or shoal projecting on a coral reef. lit., earth shell.
bone forming the posterior segment of the skull.
hipbone; round bone fitting into a socket.
spines on dorsal fins of fish.
strong bones; possessing strong bones, strength.
ischium, seat bone; spines on a fish fin.
spines on ventral fins of fish.
bone of the anterior part of the skull, forming the skeleton of the forehead.
a tall bone. fig., a tall person.
stem and midrib of a ti leaf.
midrib of a blade of pili grass.
double or united bone of arm of leg.
hollow bone, as the eye socket; socket at the joint into which a round end of a bone fits.
humerus or bone of the upper arm. lit., pillow bone.
wife (so-called because Eve is said to have been taken from Adam's rib); assistant leader in a hula troupe.
two bones between the occipital and frontal bones forming a part of the top and sides of the cranium; parietal bone.
near and trusted relative of a chief who attended to his personal needs and possessions, and executed private orders; family.
measure of length from the collarbone to the tip of the middle finger with the arm extended; yard.
kind of adze. lit., fang bone.
design on a tapa beater and on tapa consisting of a herringbone figure with a long ridge in the center; design in plaited hat braids, as forming the pāpale ʻie. lit., eel bone.
shell, as of coconut, candlenut, gourd egg, shellfish.
remnants, pieces, as of coral in a lime pit after lime is extracted by burning, or as pieces of broken glass.
stones or earth ridge marking land boundary.
midrib, as of pili grass or ti leaf.
him, her; to him, to her; because of or due to him or her (the particle iā and ia, he, her; see i₁).
while he or she, as soon as he or she, at the time that he or she (the particle iā and ia, he, she; see i₅).
same as the particle iā and replacing i₅ before proper nouns.
an introduced fish (Ophiocephalus striatus) found in rice or taro patches and streams. lit., Chinese fish.
pearl oyster, once numerous at Pearl Harbor. lit., sea creature that silences the voice, so called for a taboo of silence maintained by fishermen there.
fish or relish eaten after kava. (For. 6:503) Usually called pūpū.
mosquito fish (Gambusia affinis), introduced from Texas after 1905.
goldfish (Carassius auratus), introduced from China or Japan in the time of Kaʻahumanu. lit., red fish.
white-marked goldfish. lit., white-finned red fish.
probably the introduced carp (Cyprinus carpio). lit., dark-red fish.

ozena, a discharge of fetid matter from the nostril accompanied by vile smell; if a pregnant woman strung out fish (iʻa kui) to dry, it was believed that if some of the fish spoiled, her future offspring would acquire the affliction.
embalmed body, mummy; to embalm, stuff.
any food eaten as a relish with the staple (poi, taro, sweet potato, breadfruit), including meat, vegetable, or even salt.
tapa beater. For types of beaters, see (Buck 169–79) and pepehi₂ and hoʻopaʻi₂. A beater with a smooth surface was used finally (hoʻōki) to smooth out the cloth.
tapa beater, as used to finish the tapa. lit., finishing-beating mallet.
kind of brown tapa made at Waipiʻo, Hawaiʻi. lit., tapa beater with ridges of long stripes.
so that not, in order not.
preceding subordinate verbs and marking completed or past action and state or condition; sometimes the anaphoric ai follows the verb or verb phrase.
preceding subordinate verbs and marking imperative/exhortative mood and purpose.
while, at the time that, when, no sooner than, as soon as (replaced by iā in the same contexts as i₁).
marker of k-words (definite articles, possessives, demonstratives), with meaning singular/definite.
name of a legendary koa tree on Kauaʻi said to consist of branches without a trunk. lit., the creeping tangle.
contraction ka mea i, the one who did. cf. ka₁; ke, the one who will or should.
i ka ua mea..... due to (the thing known as)...
cessation or lack of appetite or desire.
refuse or rubbish, waste, excrement (cf. kūkae); refuse from fibers, as of olonā;. raw bast and refuse of the wauke plant after soaking.
to cut or engrave in copper or brass; a worker in copper or brass; engraver.
to draw or paint a picture or draw plants; artist.
reference mark in writing or printing to direct attention, as asterisk, dagger, arrow, blaze.
famine during wartime, with persons seeking food at night for fear of being seen. lit., cut leap about night.
to turn and then go straight for a long distance; long detour or digression.
dash (punctuation mark). lit., mark to rest.
to make a cross or X, especially in black magic (the victim becomes gravely or mortally ill by stepping on or over the mark); to crisscross; a cross or X.
fat or muscle on the shoulder blade. lit., shoulder fat.
to subincise or circumcise (less used than kahe ule or Biblical ʻoki poepoe). lit., slit penis.
circumference, parentheses, brackets. lit., mark embrace.
young growth stage of the fish ʻamaʻama, about a hand's length.
multiplication sign, crisscross mark; slanting lines.
bracket combining two items, as male and female voices in music; tenor clef; plus sign in arithmetic. lit., joining mark.
strings securing upper part of the net surrounding a calabash (kōkō).
plant said to have been used for medicine (no data).
small stone larger than a pebble.
roaring sound, as of wind, rain, or rushing waters; to roar.
macron (the line used over vowels to indicate longer sound duration).
to turn off one's course; to go where one pleases, trespass.
a unit of measure, usually said to be about 2.5 m, but in (FS 97) called fifteen feet (4.5 m).
sanctified stone used by at priest in ʻanāʻanā sorcery.
to exhibit wrath or displeasure due to jealousy.
a stone brought before a priest in sorcery prayers.
to interrupt, break into a conversation.
cutting, drawing of a line; turning point.
tangent of a circle. lit., line that touches.
taboo on menstruating women, restricting them to the menstruating house. lit., place of dark night.
circumference of a circle. lit. mark surround.
a kind of ʻahi, a tuna. It is small, has a long pectoral fin, and reaches about 35 kilos in weight. lit., dark-striped.
the sport of hurling lightweight hau wood spears; to hurl such spears. lit., hurl hau wood.
to catch edible locusts by striking (kā) the dew (hau) on bushes.
cumulus clouds, often colored, thought to be a sign of rain.
sensual dream (sickness or bad luck, as in fishing, was believed to follow shortly); to have sexual relations in a dream.
place (often followed by a qualifier, as kahakai, kahaone, kahawai, and used without ke, as hele i kahakai, go to the beach); in legends, a hot dry shore. (PH 74, 84); (FS 173).
stage of a foetus in which limbs begin to develop.
flow of blood, hemorrhage; to have such.
to subincise or circumcise. lit., cut penis.
method of fishing with a large net placed in deep water where fish fed or where bait had been strewn; to fish thus.
a method of birdcatching: all save a few lehua blossoms were plucked and the remaining flowers were gummed so that birds would be stuck; to catch birds thus.
species of small colored shells, found particularly on Niʻihau; perhaps so called because the shells were used by chiefs.
to flow like water. fig., to move in great crowds.
to cut or slit longitudinally; to subincise or circumcise.
to stretch out smooth by rubbing, as in making tapa. lit., rub stretch out.
fine-toothed comb, as used for removing dandruff or head lice (ʻuku).
high-backed comb with long prongs (ʻō) such as worn by the Spanish.
back or side comb used hold hair in place. lit., comb to pin down.
to give generously or lavishly with the heart and not with expectation of return.
to have lost the red glow of dawn.
to rise higher, of the sun, to a stage between kahikole and kau i ka lolo (noon).
fire builder; to build and tend a fire.
one who takes care of an image or a god; priest.
royal guardian in the family of a high chief.
deputy or regent in the days of the monarchy. lit., government caretaker.
one who tends a child, as a nurse.
person who cared for the chief's excrement so that it would not fall into the possession of a sorcerer.
high chief's trusted attendant of royal blood who had charge of his tobacco and pipes; he lighted them and drew a few puffs before presenting them to the chief. lit., guardian of tobacco (Eng.)
herdsman, keeper of cattle, cattle owner, rancher; to care for cattle.
oven tender; to tend an oven.
one in charge of water rights and division, water master.
trustee, executor. lit., custodian of wealth or property.
to cook taro or vegetable food; to keep the store of such food; to make poi; a keeper or cook. same as kahu umu or kahūmu.
master or practitioner of sorcery and counter sorcery. see ex., ʻanāʻanā.
the high chief who attended an infant chief, carried him, and sat him on his lap (ʻūhā). Also ʻūhā.
subject, as of a discussion, basis for work; foundation principles, is a political platform; work site.
radio broadcasting station. lit., site for making voice fly.
meeting place. lit., site for shelter.
battleground; place used for competitive sports or contests. lit., site for attack.
fire station. lit., place quench fire.
any ball-playing area, as a base-ball diamond, football field, tennis court.
place of happiness, comfort, pleasure (named for Maliʻo, a mythical woman renowned for entertaining with music and for her ability in love magic).
terra firma, the solid earth. fig., security.
stadium; playground or athletic field of any kind. lit., site for play.
ignoramus, one without background, trade, profession, knowledge; to be such.
base of a quilt on which the pattern (lau) is appliquéd; this base is above the layer of cotton or wool. The pili is below it.
to offer food and prayers to a god or to the spirit of a deified person.
revolution, revolutionist; to over-throw the government. Also hoʻokahuli aupuni.
crescent-shaped disposition of soldiers on a battlefield.

malevolent sorcerer, as one who inflicts illness by gesture, as rubbing his own head to give the victim a severe headache or head injury. Sometimes the victim might imitate tha gesture and send the affliction back to the sorcerer.
priest who increased population by praying for pregnancy.
a priest who functioned in ceremonies for the deification of a king (Malo 105) or who detected symptoms of sorcery in one sick or dead (HP 72: 322).
an expert who diagnoses, as sickness or pain, by feeling the body...
priest or expert who observed the skies for omens.
caretaker of images, who wrapped, oiled, and stored them, and carried them into battle ahead of the chief.
medical doctor, medical practitioner, healer. lit., curing expert.
a priest who induced spirits to possess a patient so that he might then drive the spirits out, thus curing the patient. lit., spirit priest.
high priest and councilor to a high chief; office of councilor.
sorcerer who practices black magic and counter sorcery, as one who prays a person to death.

honored attendant, guardian, nurse, keeper of ʻunihipili bones, regent, keeper, administrator, warden, caretaker, master, mistress; pastor, minister, reverend, or preacher of a church; one who has a dog, cat, pig, or other pet. According to (Emerson 2), kahu "implies the most intimate and confidential relations between the god and its guardian or keeper, while the word kahuna suggests more of the professional relation of the priest to the community." cf. kahu hipa, kahu hoʻoponopono, kahu mālama, kahu waiwai, and ex., ʻanāʻanā.
to tend or cook at an oven fire; to build an oven fire; to burn, as lime in a pit; one who tends an oven, a cook. fig., to seethe with hot rage.
tidal wave. lit., sea of Pele.
an extreme low tide with reef exposed. lit., dry sea.
raging sea so dangerous that man cannot survive. lit., supernatural sea.
rising or high tide. lit., encircling sea.
sea where a moving current is visible. lit., current sea.
rising tide; sea washing higher on land than usual. lit., rising sea.
taboo place along the shore where outcasts (kauwā) or breakers of certain taboos were drowned that they might be offered as sacrifices; one such place was at Kewalo in Honolulu. lit., slippery sea.
any place in the sea or on the reef where a footing may be obtained. lit., sea walk upright.
sauce, as made of crushed shrimp and coconut cream. lit., red sauce.
calm sea water, especially as left to evaporate in a pool so as to form a crust of salt.
flowing sea, especially one that goes through a sluice gate into fish ponds.
salt water and ʻōlena root used to remove evil influences. lit., freeing salt water.
shallow sea within the reef, lagoon. lit., reef sea.
fat sauce, as made from the liver of the parrot fish (uhu) and eaten with the flesh of the fish.
sea too shallow to float a canoe but good for seeking shellfish. lit., thumping sea, because the canoe thumps the coral.
a rough sea with undercurrent, as pulling back and forth on a beach, undertow.
tide beginning to flow in. lit., shooting sea.
lower sea, i.e., western sea, where the sun sets...
very dark ocean water.  lit., fire charcoal sea.
sea where octopuses are caught with lure, fig., the deep sea.
sea at a point or cape.
quiet sea, as in a calm cove; low tide.
low tide, as when much of the reef is exposed. lit., dry sea.
receding sea, especially immediately before a tidal wave. lit., shrinking sea.
gravy. lit., sauce to sop up.
high sea, high tide, full sea, spring tide.
high or rising tide, high waves.
sea with meeting diagonal waves, said figuratively, of Pearl Harbor lochs. lit., sea blowing diagonally.
a sand-dune sea, said either of a sea at very low tide which leaves the sand exposed, or of a rough sea that washes up sand dunes.
sea at full tide, mounting sea.
calm, gentle sea. lit., feminine sea.
a poetic expression referring to the channels between the islands; always follows nā. Eight is a formulistic number.
sea-urchin sauce (the crushed shells were placed in salted water; afterwards the liquid was usually strained and added to the flesh of the ʻina).
lavender, reddish-purple, so called because of the color of the sauce.
water of purification composed of sea water or water with salt and ʻōlena (turmeric root); to purify thus.
breaking sea, breakers, whitecaps. lit., resounding sea.
prefix to six kinship terms used as terms of reference: kaikaina, kaikoʻeke, kaikuaʻana, kaikunāne, kaikuahine, kaikamahine.
weakened and watery fluid, as coffee, thinned-down milk; to be watery.
indolent, lazy, unskilled; such a person.
hard type of rock, used for adzes.
name of a long prayer used after the kauila celebration at a temple dedication, probably short for poʻo kea, white head or bleached skull, since the sea water (kai) used was held in a skull.
to walk with feet far apart, as an infant; to straddle, as on a horse.
to take life philosophically as it comes, sometimes in poverty, sometimes in wealth.
a type of stone (no data). lit., the snout of the pig.
relative of a junior sibling line.
creeping with age; aged (a proper name in some legends for an old hag).
white sea foam, especially as washed up on a beach.
enema composed of sea water and raw crushed kukui nuts. Also kaikuehu and kaīkū.
brother-in-law or male cousin-in-law of a male; sister-in-law or female cousin-in-law of a female.
countryman; backwoodsman; sparsely inhabited place; countrified, rustic. lit., back person.
cultivated patch; bank of taro patch.
guards posted at the entrance to the hale nauā enclosure (Malo 191) Emerson (Malo 200) lists this as kaikuone.
thyme (Thymus vulgaris), from southern Europe, a small plant with small leaves, in the mint family, used to flavor food.
middle tide, when the tide begins to recede (And); perhaps also similar to kaiʻokia.
central part of a canoe, just aft of the point where the forward outrigger boom is attached to the hull (perhaps from kā i nā liu, bail the bilge).
name of a mother ʻuaʻu, bird.
possession of an altar by a god.
Why not; I thought, presumed, or assumed (but it was not so).
name of a long prayer in a temple service.
calm, tranquil sea.  fig., peace of mind.
a plant mentioned in poetry, as ka nani o ka pua kaioʻe, the beauty of the kaioʻe blossoms; a lizard god of the same name is associated with this plant.
to go back and forth, swing or move back and forth or up and down; to sway the hips in walking; to pitch, as of waves.
to sit in silence, as at a meeting. cf. mū, silence.
bonito lure made of shell; bone fishhook; barbless deep-sea hook composed of two small hooks.
sea too deep to walk in lit., swimming sea.
separated by sea, spared, set apart, separated (see kānāwai).
ceremony of tying fine white tapa (ʻoloa) as a malo on an image.
similar to keu. My, how much! How very! How terrific!
idle chatter; to talk idly; to wander aimlessly.
bow for shooting arrows; crossbow; the shooting of a bow; bent, as a bow; to shoot, as a bow.
a sweet potato, usually qualified by the terms ʻili paheʻe, smooth skin, or ʻili pohole o Keawe, scraped skin of Keawe.
to step lightly or softly; to do quietly; to run lightly.
poor quality, as of taro not fit for poi.
iron hoop, iron from a hoop.
name given for a kind of kala, a fish.
creepy sensation due to either cold or fright; to have goose flesh, shuddery feeling.
noisy; to make repeated noises, to talk incessantly; pealing, ringing, squeaking.
a plant disease in hot areas, 1857.
to roll, whirl, turn over; to revolve, as a wheel; to turn aside, deviate; rolling, turning, etc.
a series of precipices; consisting of such.
scarce, sparse, rare, few, uncommon; seldom, rarely; precious (1 Sam. 3.1, in sense of rare) .
sequence, one of a series, branch, success.
arched; curving from end to end, as the top of a canoe.

chants with mixed or garbled words, for and by chiefs, with inserted syllables and some secret words (as: nohouwō o luhunā, nohouwō o lahalō, for: noʻu ʻo luna, noʻu ʻo lalo, mine are the chiefs, mine are the commoners); to use this language; play language used for amusement and intrigue; code.
to slip back and forth; to mix, shuffle.
a native variety of sweet potato; the name may be qualified by the term ʻeleʻele.
sorcery to free a victim from power of the hana aloha, love inducing sorcery. lit., to free love.

• house gable;
   • plaiting design, as in braids for hats.
to go forth issuing a proclamation or making an announcement, lit., traveling proclamation.
to give away in an insane manner, as would a crazy person.
same as mākole mākōpiʻi and kalemakapiʻi, mosses.
a kind of kala, a fish.
a variety of kala, a fish.
a black caterpillar with a red dot at the base of the head, probably the sweet potato sphinx moth (Herse cingulata). It is destructive, especially of sweet potato leaves.
a kala fish staying with ʻōpelu schools; when fishermen see it, they know ʻōpelu are near.
atonement, remission of sins; to pardon, absolve from sin, ransom. lit., forgive sin.
to call out an announcement or proclamation, announce.
removal of taboo on fruits of land and sea, as during makahiki harvest ceremonies.
to carve, cut, hew, hoe, etc., a little at a time; to whittle.
to pick entangled debris, as brownish seaweed, from a fish net.

redup. of kala₁, to loosen, untie, free, release...; kala₄, rough, as sharkskin...
   • craggy, thorny, knotty. 
   • fig., rough in language, rude, harsh
calico; variegated in color, as of croton leaves, or of a pinto horse spotted with several colors; printed cotton cloth (modern); said also of scars left after impetigo.
under control of a mysterious or supernatural power; magic.
to release, undo, as evil by prayer.
a variety of taro; corm white, yielding gray poi; perhaps originated in Kalalau, Kauaʻi.
to go quickly, briskly, without noticing anyone; to walk or talk in a brisk, haughty way; proud; such activity.
level, even, smooth, as a cliff, calm sea, or sheer surface.
a kind of awa, a fish.
cliffbrake (Pellaea ternifolia), a short, slender fern, the fronds with short, paired, narrow divisions. It grows in dry, sunny places, as at Kīlauea Volcano. Also kalamoho lau liʻi.
a grass once used for house thatch. Also ʻemoloa and kāwelu.
a person so lazy that he will work only when watched; to work only when watched.
division of land smaller than a moku or district; county.
kind of stone used for octopus lures.
a kind of Zebrasoma, a fish.
club, society; club in a deck of cards.
to mop the floor, to club.
the introduced salsify or oyster plant (Tragopogon porrifolius).
crown, corona, diadem,  cf. also pua kalaunu.

see limu kala, common, long, brown seaweeds... [This is the kala riddle given by Mary Kawena Pukui in The Hawaiian Planter, Volume 1, by E.S. Craighill Handy: "The kala of the upland [a kala berry], the kala in between [pua kala; beach poppy], the kala of the sea [limu kala; kala seaweed]" (p.216).] (Neal 367)
a sweet potato. Kinds are qualified by the colors keʻokeʻo and poni.
to proclaim, announce; proclamation, public crier, announcer...

surgeonfish, unicorn fish, Teuthidae; Naso hexacanthus, N. unicornis, N. brevirostris. Varieties are qualified by the terms holo ihu loa (long nose running), lemu (buttocks), liʻiliʻi (also pahi kaua), lōlō, maoli, moe, palaholo.
long ago (usually followed by loa, wale, kahiko; [idiom] when preceded by ʻaʻole, ʻaʻoe, or ʻeʻoe, it means "quite a while ago," or, "for quite a long time."

watery residue on poi-pounding board, which was used to treat kou and milo wood to be made into utensils, as it was believed to draw out the acid remaining in wood after soaking in the sea; also used to massage babies' bodies lightly in order to strengthen them.
to choke; to whoop in coughing; whooping cough.
name of the fourth growth stage of the ʻōpakapaka, a fish, about 60 cm long or more.
a red- or yellow-flowered succulent (Kalanchoe blossfeldiana), a recent introduction.
to turn toward, listen to, heed respectfully (probably kā-, causative + lele, ʻleap’ +-i, transitivizer).
to stretch, as the hide of an animal to be dried; taut.
to sally over; to raise a bet, as in card games.
watery, nearly liquid, as thin poi.
a tree or plant used in medicine.

a native tree (Elaeocarpus bifidus), with long-stemmed, ovate leaves and greenish flowers, formerly used for fire making and constructing grass houses, the bark for cordage. It belongs to the linden family.
a variety of sweet potato. The name may be qualified by lau keʻokeʻo, white-leafed, and ʻulaʻula, red.

a wild, weedy euphorbia, or wild spurge (Euphorbia heterophylla var. cyathophora), a tropical American herb about 30 cm high, with green, oval leaves, but with floral leaves white or pink at the base; used medicinally as a purgative.
a gusty breeze, perhaps a proper name.
cauliflower (Brassica oleracea var. botrytis). same as kāpiki pua, the common name.
caladium (Caladium bicolor), a tropical American herb, an aroid grown in gardens for the many color forms of its heart-shaped leaves. lit., calico taro.
conversational prayer (informal appeal and not a memorized prayer or chant); to pray thus.
papyrus (Cyperus papyrus), a large African sedge, growing in water.
some other large sedges (as species of Scirpus), if growing in water.
a kind of rush or grass like kaluhā sedges, famous on Kauaʻi.
fine gauze-like tapa made on Kauaʻi, reserved for chiefs.
a land term of uncertain meaning and pronunciation commonly used in Kona, Hawaiʻi, in about 1848. Perhaps ulu is ʻulu, breadfruit.
husband or wife by whom one has had children; woman who has borne a child.
son, boy, male child; masculine gender (rare).
two children reared together, two close companions.
to tie sennit, to bind securely, to form a loop to support a netted calabash; the loop itself; a belt.
strength, energy, firmness of resolution, fixedness of purpose.
wonderful, astonishing, marvelous, wondrous, surprising, remarkable, incomprehensible.
a far-reaching, strong or heavy branch, the main branch.

the art of righting a capsized canoe; one man swims under the canoe with a line tied to the attachments of each outrigger boom (ʻiako) and the outrigger (ama); he pulls on the line while others press down on the ama to bring it down under the canoe to right it; water remaining in the canoe is dashed out by jerking the canoe back and forth. lit., tie for turning canoe.
to impose a general taboo. lit., to tie the multitude.
name of the sacred sennit cord used in taboo services; name of this rigid taboo. lit., bind, tie, obey.
tomato (Lycopersicon esculentum). The word used today is ʻōhiʻa.
the sky just below the zenith.
child of a chief; a petted child. fig., finicky, fussy.
yellow, yellow-hued; tapa dyed yellow with ʻōlena.
to look over and reject, to examine and refuse to accept.
slugs and snails in general; Eulota similaris, a snail. lit., sea-slug child.

the false kamani or tropical almond (Terminalia catappa), a tree from the East Indies grown widely in the tropics for ornament, shade, timber, and edible nuts. It thrives along sandy shores. lit., introduced kamani.

a large tree (Calophyllum inophyllum), at home on shores of the Indian and western Pacific Oceans, with shiny, oblong leaves to 20 cm long, white flowers much like orange blossoms, and globose green fruits about 2.5 cm in diameter. The wood is hard and was formerly made into calabashes. Also kamanu, tamanu.
smooth, shiny, polished, as of kamani wood.
an amberfish or rainbow runner (Elagatis bipinnulatus), known also as sea salmon.
a straggling native shrub (Hedyotis fluviatilis var. kamapuaana), found in Punaluʻu Valley, Oʻahu, where the pig god stole chickens.
gadabout who goes from house to house seeking favors, one who lives on others favors; to do this. lit., door boy.
selective, difficult to please. lit., person [who] chooses.

child, person.      hoʻokama, to adopt a child or adult one loves, but for whom one might not have the exclusive care (An older adult of either sex might be adopted thus. A child so adopted, termed keiki hoʻokama, is somewhat comparable to a godchild. An adult so adopted might be called kaikuaʻana hoʻokama, kaikaina hoʻokama, kaikuahine hoʻokama, kaikunāne hoʻokama.)
to bind, tie, wrap. Used in ʻanāʻanā sorcery, this term had three meanings: (1) to seize, bind, make fast; (2) name of a god to whom the appeal was made; (3) the victim. see

chameleon (RSV), mole (KJV).  (Oihk. 11.30)  Jackson's chameleon (Chamaeleo jacksoni) has been noted on Oʻahu since 1972, the green anole lizard (Anolis carolinensis porcatus) since, 1950; this is also commonly called chameleon. (McKeown 28–33).
princess (short for kama aliʻi wahine, female, chiefly child).

relieved after a struggle; feeling of ease or relief after surviving sickness or danger; joy over escape; rest after violent exertion or danger; breathless arrival; refuge; one convalescing or resting after sickness or danger; to convalesce or rest; to find refuge. cf. aho, breath, (For. 4:71).
adult, mature person; to behave or speak as an adult; to become adult, or to obtain the strength and maturity of an adult.
name used by the medical kahuna for ʻuhaloa, a weed. lit., tall person.
the ʻilima flower used medicinally.  lit., good person.
after end of the float of a canoe.
to deceive, mislead, feign, act the hypocrite; deceitful.
to stagger, zigzag, walk like a drunkard or very sick person.
young stage of the hou, a fish.
priests of Kū serving in the luakini temple, said to be named for the first such priest.
stubborn, sulky. cf. more common nuha.
an early growth stage of the fish ʻahi; it is lighter in color. see ʻahi kananā, he aha sananā, and nanā.
uneven, as a surface of a table or road.

small endemic trees (Broussaisia arguta), with large, oval, toothed leaves, in the saxifrage family; the small flowers and berries are arranged in wide, convex clusters. The flowers of one form have bluish-green petals; of another, red, another white, An old belief was that eating the fruit helped in fecundity; the increase of chiefs was compared to a fruiting kanawao. Varieties are qualified by the colors keʻokeʻo and ʻulaʻula.
var. name for nāwao₁, a taro.
hard, striped pebble, found in streams and used in slingshots and as sinkers.
tens (usually compounded with numbers from three to nine to indicate 30 to 90).

that follows perfective verb marker i and poss. o, and is followed by directionals; it is preceded by negatives. Also see kaʻe₂. extremely, beyond compare, without limit (in both favorable and pejorative senses).
horizontal support in houses for carrying poles (ʻauamo).
loss of appetite; to have no appetite; distaste for food.
combination of the juices of ʻōlena root and mānienie grass used medicinally.
to fluff out the feathers, as birds do in hot weather.
to hold a marble at a line just before shooting.
sound of a loud explosion or blow; bang, as of a gun.
sudden loud sound, as the report of a rifle or pop of a paper bag, loud cry of a bird; to sound thus.
long drawn-out peal of a bell; to ring thus, reverberate.
to become a grandparent, the state of being a grandparent; grandchild's wail.

• hard, ringing sound, as of tree or log being struck. 
   fig., hard wood.
same as kaniʻāʻau, to mourn, grieve, moan, wail, cry; to wander about in grief and affliction.
half-step interval in music, a minor second.
redup. of kani, sound or noise of any kind...; chattering, noisy, jingle.

• jack-knife, from the sound of opening and shutting (rare); 
   • knife made of hoop iron.
dirge, lamentation, chant of mourning, lament; to chant, wail, mourn. (Bib.)
aged person; aged, so old that one walks with a cane [a favorite metaphor]. lit., sounding cane.
tolling of a bell, dingdong, sound of clashing objects; to toll, clang, clash.
same as kaʻikōkō,  one so old that he is carried in a net; bedridden, probably by analogy with kanikoʻo, aged person; aged, so old that one walks with a cane.
to recover from sickness, perhaps a var. of kāninonino.
whole-step interval in music, a major second.
lump under the skin; to raise a lump.
to purse the lips, as in disapproval or disagreement.
infantryman, infantry, lit., sound of feet.
to giggle or laugh softly, as with delight.

• sigh, moan, bemoan;
   • sorrow, grief,
   • complaint of troubles and pains; to complain,  
   • to coo, mourn, as a mourning dove. 
lit., sound groan.
to mourn, grieve, moan, wail, cry; to wander about in grief and affliction.
Adam's apple, larynx, trachea, neck, throat. lit., hard neck.
groan, moan, grunt; to cause grunting, moaning, groaning, as from pain; to exclaim "mh" (a prolonged "m" sound) as in delight; such an exclamation; to cause such an exclamation.
to satisfy a need, particularly thirst; to drink.
the shaft to which the presser foot is attached on a sewing machine.
to whack, bang, smack, as of a blow; to receive such a resounding blow.
roaring, vibrating sound, as of distant thunder.
large physically, both tall and stout; husky.
to smooth down, as the wet, ruffled feathers of a bird; to preen; to tamp and smooth.
satyr (1941 Bible has kao hihiu). lit., human goat.
pressure foot (part of a sewing machine).
snare of coconut midrib and fiber, used for ʻaʻama, a crab.
border of the sea, seashore, seaside, coast; sometimes interpreted as west or komohana.
clothing in general. lit., kapa to put on.
leaf covering, as placed over a corpse in a pit.
blanket, quilt, bedspread (general name); sleeping tapa.
filthy rags; tapa worn by women in the menstruation hut (hale peʻa).
lined quilt that is not padded, formerly used as a top sheet (old-time Hawaiians did not put a bottom sheet on top or vice versa, due to strict taboos concerning body contact). lit., clinging tapa.
patchwork or crazy quilt of varied color or design. lit., patch quilt.
padded quilt, comforter. lit., pad covering.
sackcloth, as worn by mourners in the Bible. lit., despicable clothing.
quilt with appliquéd designs. lit., piece tapa.
a tapa formerly made at Waimea, Kauaʻi.
to splash, as raindrops on water.
splashing, spattering, as fish being driven into a net; fluttering, flapping. fig., agitated, worried, disturbed (formerly said mostly on Kauaʻi and Oʻahu).
raised place in the heiau where images and offerings were placed, and where the invisible gods were thought to dwell.
to call, term, give a name to.
to rustle, rattle, splash, as rain.
to go on hands and knees before high royalty; to act humbly.
kind of malo dyed one color on one side, and another color on the other side (the wind often blows and exposes [kapeke] the color on the reverse side).
ceremonial sea bath for purification, purification by sea water, as after contact with a corpse or by women after menstruation.
a taboo requiring lesser persons to keep their distance from a chief. lit., taboo stand far away.
a ritual for the god Lono-i-ka-ʻou-aliʻi (Lono at the chiefly supremacy).  lit., torch taboo.
a ritual for the god Lono-i-ka-ʻou-aliʻi. lit., loulu palm taboo.
taboo requiring everyone to sit in the presence of a chief, or when his food container, bath water, and other articles were carried by.
taboo with the privilege of killing people. lit., taboo burn people.
taboo of wohi chiefs, including exemption from the prostration taboo.
a taboo on wearing another's clothing unless the relationship was very close. lit., skin taboo.
sacred rituals for cutting an ʻōhiʻa log and dragging (kō) it to the coast to be made into a canoe.
kerosene stove. lit., steam oil stove.
small stone container in which the sorcerer burned his "bait" (hair, spittle, etc., of his victim).
footprint of a god (see kapuaʻi₁). fig., foot of the rainbow.
design on tapa beater consisting of a series of Gothic arches. lit., wild duck tracks.
a modern Molokaʻi name for the pala fern; the bases of the frond stems suggest a horse's hoof (kapuaʻi lio).
part of the canoe float where the outrigger boom (ʻiako) is joined; the after one is the kapuaʻi hope.
the many taboos inherited from chiefly ancestors or from the gods; person with many taboos.
dignity, regal appearance, noble bearing, entitled to respect and reverence, difficult of access because of rank, dignity, and station.
to purify by sprinkling with salt water (kava, ordinarily taboo to women, might be made noa or free of taboo by sprinkling the place in this fashion; usually termed pī kai).
a cry proclaiming a taboo on the approach of a sacred personage or as part of a ceremony; the announcer of this taboo (Kep. 139) and the stick he bears (Ii 41).

• season after season;  
   • fig., always and forever.
to fall or lie on a slant, as rain; slanting.
to legislate, make or enact laws; legislator, lawmaker, legislation; legal.
to sell leis; to hang leis.

• to scatter here and there in small quantities; 
   • to divide or distribute small amounts.
growing in a tree; to be in a tree; all kinds of epiphytic plants.
anything placed on the shoulder, as a cloak or musket; to place on the shoulders, to shoulder.
to place flowers, especially on graves.
to put or place for no reason; to ride free of charge; to ride bareback.
to hang conspicuously a tapa as a taboo sign; to hoist a tapa banner as indication that the makahikiceremonies had begun. lit., hang rag.
a single generation from father to son.
too short, as a dress; to hang short.
cavalry; cavalry war. lit., horse war.
to look or move straight ahead: to gaze.
first harvest of small sweet potatoes, others being left to grow larger.
a boisterous person who speaks loudly and gestures wildly, making a spectacle of himself.
the southern sky where the star Lipo may be seen; the rising of the star Lipo. Variants are kauana Lepo, kauana Lewa, and kauana Liolio-iWawau.
kind of soft, reddish porous stone used for polishing and smoothing and as sinker for octopus lure.
Var. spellings of kauwele and kauwelu.

group of houses comprising a Hawaiian home, formerly consisting of men's eating house, women's eating house, sleeping house, cook-house, canoe house, etc. Term was later used even if the home included but a single house, and is sometimes used for hamlet or settlement. It is used without an article.  lit., plural house.
to move up and down as the waves, or as in dancing; to undulate.

• tangled, snarled, of vines. 
   • fig., in trouble.
lashing, as of thatching sticks to house post.
to fasten horizontal thatching sticks and plates of a house with rope.
to open, unfold, as a tapa; to expand, as a flower in bloom.
to lose consciousness, as in an epileptic seizure; heart attack, stroke.
to pursue in order to harm, chase, to run after, run and fetch.
spelling, orthography; to write down, note. lit., place word.
house ridgepole, main ridge pole. see illus. 1, illus. 2, illus. 4
gathering of fish in schools near the surface of the sea.
temple ceremonies, during which images were readorned with feathers.

a native tree in the buckthorn family (Colubrina oppositifolia), found only on Oʻahu and Hawaiʻi, with opposite leaves, ovate and to 15 cm long. 
   • Its hard wood was valued for spears and tools, and was not reputed to be poisonous.     Called oʻa on Maui.

• taboo ceremony consecrating a temple; 
   • ceremonial readorning of images with feathers.
a kind of black, tough sugar cane.
canoe with a single outrigger float.
class of chiefs of lesser rank than the high chief, the father a high chief and the mother of lower rank but not a commoner.
tap-tap, as of tattoo needle when it pierces the skin.
heap of stones used as a temporary altar.
bird snare; to set or fix a bird snare.
to depend on; one depended on (kau, to place + -kaʻi, transitivizer).
to continue or persevere in a straight course.
short for kau ʻokoʻa, to place separately; to separate.
to walk with a cane (koʻo); to lean on, rely on, depend on. fig., old and infirm.
candlestick, lamp stand. lit., place light.
drawstring, rope or cord to pull on.
clothesline. lit., line to dry clothes.
lacings, cords as those by which the coconut knee drum (pūniu hula) was tied to the high of the player.
line from forward outrigger boom (ʻiako) to prow to strengthen the boom in storms.
rope to tether, as horse, cow, or pig.
cord on which flowers are strung into a lei; cluster of fruit or flowers growing together on a stem like a lei; streamer.
line running from the prow of a canoe to the after end, used to lash the ʻahu, or mat, used for protection from high seas. lit., old woman line.
lacing, as for shoes or corset.
rope made of willow or other green bark or branch. lit., green cord.
sheet from boom to after outrigger boom (ʻiako hope).
line, as to raise a sail. lit., sliding line.
line holding in place the canoe pāʻū, cover.
bridle, reins; to bridle. lit., mouth chain
line extending from sail tip to the ʻiako, boom, on the edge of the canoe.
leather rope, lassoing rope, lariat, strap.
strong outrigger lashing used on deepwater canoes, probably so called because of the hardness of ʻōhiʻa wood.
the position of the moon; the traditional lunar calendar.
place where canoes stop, as while fishing.
resting place of Kāne, said to be on the islet of Kaʻula off Niʻihau; also a poetic name for the west.
a squid (family Sepiolidae), Euprymna scolopes. lit., resting mūheʻe.
heir by word-of-mouth rather than by written will; to make a will verbally; a verbal will.
resting place, place to put things, placement; restful, quiet (kau, to place + -lana, nominalizer).
to rely on the chief, to support the chief, to put confidence in the chief.
cloudless, standing out clearly, plainly seen.
to hang up, as to dry in the sun. (kau, to hang + laʻi, transitivizer).

to talk too much of one's family affairs or ancestors, to tell the cherished stories, and chants of one's ancestors (a taunt to those who reveal too much of the Hawaiian past). lit., to dry out the bones, meaning to expose the bones of the ancestors, a crime.
to sun, bleach in the sun; sun bath; to talk too much of family and ancestors (cf. kaulaʻi iwi).
too high; too short, as a dress. fig., insecure, infirm.
to take flight; soaring, on the wing.
exclamation, stress; to accent in music.
extraordinary, over and above the ordinary, extra, added on, additional, supplemental, random, excess.
an ʻoʻopu fish found in brackish water. lit., the long penis.

• to urge, exhort, enjoin, 
   • advise, 
   • command. 
    lit., to place the voice.

• equality, equal, 
   • equation, 
   • equity, 
   • justice; just; dispense justice; 
   • impartial; treat fairly and impartially, 
   • mutual, parallel; 
   • to balance evenly, 
   • make alike, 
   • be in a similar situation, 
   • to arrive at the same time (For. 4:293); par.
to ask frequently, tease; importunate, annoying.

• to observe closely, 
   • to direct attention to, 
   • aim at.
to harness or put two horses together.

• double canoe, 
   • pair, span, yoke, 
   • two of a kind; 
   • to put together or pair, to yoke or harness together, 
   • to double in quantity; 
   • coupled. 
   • fig., two-natured.
to decorate, adorn, especially with greenery.
taboo ceremony in honor of the akua loa, long god, of the makahiki festival.
ledge, step, jog, as on a cliff. [Elbert lists this form as varying with kaunu in his 1982 l-n doublets list (JPS Lexical Diffusion...) possibly the source of kaulu₇ ?]

all species of an endemic genus (Pteralyxia), small trees related to maile, found only on Oʻahu and Kauaʻi, resembling hōeli (Ochrosia) with its shiny, oblong leaves. Fruits are paired, red, ovoid, and each contains one large winged seed.
same as āulu₅, and lonomea, Sapindus oahuensis, a tree.
to show off, play the dandy
very heavily laden; bearing a heavy load, especially of one drenched with water. fig., extremely sad.
sacrifice, offering; to make a sacrifice or offering.
similar to kau ka maka, to desire, to long to see, to think of fondly (ON 1613).
ocean sunfish (Mola mola). lit., big eyes placed.
to overlook faults of others. lit., to place shade.
paper mulberry too old to be used for tapa.
method of catching birds by tying a caterpillar and a stick at one end of a string; when the bird swallows the caterpillar the stick lodges in his throat.
stick about 10 cm long with holes down its middle, used to hold gunwales in place while they are being sewed on with sennit.
to splice, mend a fracture with a splint; to fasten canoe gunwale; wooden canoe clamp.
to point out or determine boundaries of a moʻo land division.
too short; shrinking away, as in distaste.
lit., mālolo (flying fish) kaunaʻoa, so called because this plant was spread over mālolo caught in a canoe to keep them from escaping. Sometimes called mālolo or pōlolo.

a greenish-yellow dodder vine (Cassytha filiformis), belonging to the laurel family, cosmopolitan in the tropics. It is coarser than the native orange dodder (Cuscuta sandwichiana). lit., swollen kaunaʻoa.

a native dodder (Cuscuta sandwichiana), belonging to the morning-glory family, a leafless, parasitic vine, growing densely on other plants. The numerous, slender, orange stems are used for orange leis to represent the island of Lānaʻi, as designated by the Territorial legislature in 1923.

a mollusk (Vermetidae). In adult stage it becomes solidly fixed to rocks; cuts resulting from stepping on it are considered deadly poisonous by Hawaiians. The mollusk was believed somehow related to the dodder.
a coarse, tough seaweed (Galaxaura rugosa), calcified and inedible, resembling kaunaʻoa₁ in being yellow to gold in color.
voice used in choral singing, e.g. countertenor or alto.
holding on precariously. lit., resting on the edges.
pole set up as indicative of taboo.
common var. of kaupoku, ridgepole, highest point, roof, ceiling, attic...
fence or boundary between one patch of land (waena) and another.
to draw the color line; to show race prejudice. lit., to make a skin boundary.

• to limit, restrict, moderate, limitation, ration.
   • mark a border or boundary, 
   • set a deadline; deadline.

• scales, 
   • weight; to weigh. 
   • fig., to consider, judge, estimate.
   lit., place pound (Eng.).
an edible brown seaweed (Chnoospora pacifica), with many slender branches.
beloved wife or friend, beloved friendship united in such close relationship. lit., place clinging.
second ridgepole placed above the main ridgepole. lit., rat ridgepole.
sport: swimming or diving for half-submerged objects, formerly gourds, today noni or citric fruits or green coconuts or papayas; to play this game.
lasso suspended from bough or gate to trap cattle.
humble, timid and cringing, crushed; to walk in a feeble, wobbly manner, as a sick or aged person.
to put forward, of a paddle.
a variety of native bananas, perhaps named for the place on Maui.
some, a little, a few; something; some place.
covering of ti leaves made with the stems tied together, and the leaves spread out fanwise, formerly used on the oven, replaced today by gunny sacks.
ruffle for the neck, as worn by Elizabethans.
grass, weeds hanging over fresh water.
spelling used in letters by Queen Emma for kauoha, order, command...

outcast, pariah, slave, untouchable, menial; a caste which lived apart and was drawn on for human sacrifices (these traditional meanings carried great opprobrium). Later it was used in the Bible and in formal correspondence to translate servant. Lesser chiefs who served higher chiefs were called kauā maoli (see aliʻi poʻe kauā). see haʻalele loa₂, lauʻī pekepeke, makawela, and below for insulting names for kauā, and pejorative -a and (Malo 68–72).
any type of kauā who works hard, vassal. lit., oppressed kauā.
Kauā branded with dot in the middle of the forehead. lit., dotted outcast.
Kauā with tattooed label on temples. lit., outcast surrounded forehead.
to carry a person supported by arms over the shoulders of two persons, as one drunk or sick, or for one person to half carry and half drag another person. lit., place like a kite.
to drag a canoe, especially if unfinished, from the mountain forest to the shore to be finished.
high shelf or place where chiefs hung or placed (kau) their clothes.
to express admiration or praise of a chief, as in chant.
to drag, haul, draw along, tow.
yolk or white of an egg.
loud type of prayer, usually at makahiki festivals. cf. wōwō, hoʻokāwōwō.
to dig up the past, to review the past.
an office in the king's train (And); unarmed spy in enemy country (Malo 202, Emerson note).
to loiter about the door of a house as though desiring food gifts; one who does so. lit., placed [at the] door.
indicating plural, much less used than nā and mau except in the compounds kauhale, kaukolu, kauwahi.
expressing superlative, preceded by hoʻi or mai hoʻi.
a sacred chant, as Hiʻiaka's chants of affectionate greeting to persons, hills, and landmarks; a chant of sacrifice to a deity; to chant thus.

a method of feeding children or high-born persons as a special honor; the recipient held back his head and opened his mouth; the morsel of poi was dropped into his mouth; much enjoyed by children as a game.
center tapa under which the stone was hidden in the game of pūhenehene.
bonito, little tunny (Euthynnus yaito). Sometimes called pohopoho. Growth stages are kīnaʻu (immature), ʻāhua, and kawakawa (adult).
damp, wet with cold, moist with fog, humid; wet, as in a cold sweat. cf. ū (moist), maʻū, koʻū.
leaping place, as a precipice from which a swimmer leaps into a pool.
to assassinate, strike in the dark, kill and rob.
to work or act slowly and in moderation, as in paddling a canoe or farming; slow, lingering, as disease.
Sphyraena helleri, a smaller relative of the kākū, a fish. see saying, hauhili.
a variety of mountain sweet potato. It has heart-shaped leaves and hard tubers, and is very sweet.
to clatter, as dishes; to roar, as a sudden downpour; to snap or crackle; such a roaring, clatter, crackling.
savoy, common cabbage with curled leaves.
seedling; thrifty young plant; sucker, shoot from a parent stalk; to multiply and thrive, as a plant or people. fig., progeny. See hoʻohua kawowo.
of displeasure, vexation, annoyance, prolonged to indicate greater force.
passenger conveyance. lit., vehicle carrying passengers.
horse-drawn trolley car. lit., five-cent vehicle.
bicycle, tricycle. lit., vehicle press feet.
any two-wheeled vehicle, as cart or buggy.
fire engine, fire truck (KAN). lit., vehicle extinguish fire.
to wield a war club; to send a curse by playing with seeming innocence with four or five sticks held in the hand.

• to fall in (military command), 
   • to serve others
to wipe dry, as dishes with a cloth.
to rise in station, to come up from under; to rule others.
siege of sickness, a long or chronic illness; to suffer such.
to change, as the wind or an idea.
to turn around loosely, as a screw or peg that does not fit; loose, unsteady.
truck, baggage car, baggage or freight vehicle. baggage cart (airport) (HE)
to turn or roll freely, independently, or without control.
train, railroad, locomotive engine. lit., fire wagon.
to struggle; to pant, as for breath.
feeble, near death; to labor for breath.
fellow, chap, wretch, person. slang. (possibly Tahitian, but see mahumahu, ʻōkole kaʻaka).
actively and gainfully employed, successful; to make progress.
to have enough, especially of material goods; ample.
tough, stringy, as of banana trees; viscid, gluey.
same as hiʻu wīwī, an ʻahi, a fish.
to open, as the eyes; open, watching.
rare variant of koʻa, coral head, fishing grounds.
period of mourning, especially wailing in grief; to mourn and wail.
to sail to leeward. fig., full of lies, underhanded, deceitful.
those about a chief; members of the royal court.
to sway, reel; to fly or soar, as birds.
to drift, sail off and on.
to bruise; to pelt, as rain.
intrepid, fearless, as of one unafraid to brave the elements; bravery.
to sail or turn against the wind. fig., to dominate; overbearing.
to decoy, especially to attract uhu fish with a live uhu decoy; to proselyte.
an elevated place; sleeping place in a grass house.
legend, tale, novel, romance, usually fanciful; fiction; tell a fanciful tale.
to finish or complete, as a canoe; to put on the last touches.
red or reddish-brown, due to being smoked, especially of fish, or of the stem of sugar-cane tassel to be used in a dart.
attractive, of a child (children born in the month of Kaʻaona were thought to be attractive and lovable).
to spread wings or tail feathers.
to fold over, as a bundle.
castor bean, more commonly known as kolī or pāʻaila.
a deep-sea fish said to resemble the moano.
hack (carriage). lit., bent vehicle, so called because of the top.
taboo night in the ruling chief's heiau during October.
to make a tour, go around, surround, encircle, rotate, revolve, travel; circuit.
the hula step now called "around the island": the dancer pivots on the ball of one foot in a complete circle; the other foot takes four or more steps to complete the circuit; to do this step.

• to toss from side to side, as a restless child in bed; 
   • in spasms.
forty. [traditional 4-based counting: kāuna 4; kaʻau 40; lau 400; mano 4,000; kini 40,000; lehu 400,000] ("used in counting fish" (Alexander 1864:14))
to repeat, do over and over.

• to turn, twist,    • writhe as in pain;    • to knead, as bread (Ier. 7.18) .    • (ʻŌpelu fish that form a vertical wall as they swim, flapping to maintain this unusual position, are said to kaʻawili).
perfumer (RSV), apothecary (KJV). More commonly kāwili lāʻau.
to roll along with a rustling sound (ʻowē). fig., a person with no property or means of support.
to wipe dry with a cloth, as dishes. Kaʻū.
selvage of cloth. lit., solid edge.
idiom following ʻaʻole and possessive o.  For a similar idiom, see kana₂, extremely, beyond compare...
to walk, move, proceed, walk in line or in succession, as of a parade; to walk holding on to something or with uncertainty, as a child learning to walk; to move, as in checkers.
to exit dancing, as in a hula.
parade, procession; to march in a parade.
station of the cross (Catholic); procession of the cross.
to enter dancing, as in a hula.
to carry or go to and fro.
to march in step or proceed in unity, as soldiers; to lead together.
corpus Christi procession, so called because first communicants march. lit., parade for-the-first-time.
to come in flocks, as followers to a generous chief.
to drag along; to force to go against one's will.
• to lead,    • support,    • lift up; raise.
one so old that he is carried in a net; bedridden (a favorite figure of speech; cf. kani koʻo)
a kind of Spanish clover, an erect fodder plant (Desmodium canum), from the West Indies, a legume with three-parted leaves, pink flowers, and small, narrow, four-to-eight-jointed pods.

order, succession, sequence.  
same as kaʻi₁
   • to lead, direct, 
   • lift up and carry; 
   • to walk or step in a row or procession...
manner of walking, gait; pace, step.

• graceful prancing motion; 
   • to toss, as a ship.
division, portion; to divide into portions or heaps, apportion.
to support a sick or intoxicated person between two other persons. lit., lead like a kite.
fish net or seine; snare or noose for birds.
a decayed tooth that requires extraction.
the chant during which dancers appear and leave; to come dancing out before an audience;
dry, arid, bare of vegetation, as of deserts (usually not used alone).
rain cloud on the point of precipitation; first raindrops.
hard, arid, especially of red earth.
jowl, sagging chin, double chin; sagging part of the neck of an eel.
cucumber (Cucumis sativus), introduced. listed in (Ellis 1825, p. 247). (Nah. 11.5) , (Neal 811).
nimbleness, joy; nimble, agile, active, joyful, as one leaping for joy.
hemorrhoid or exterior obstruction to bowel evacuation.
type of pink, smooth, somewhat porous stone.
to creep along, move with a hissing sound, as fire.
perhaps Laysan albatross (Diomedea immutabilis); it breeds on the Northwestern Hawaiian Islands, Niʻihau, and Moku Manu. see song, (EM 65).
a native rather narrow fern (Polystichum hillebrandii) with scaly stems, the fronds twice divided.
thread, line, as of olonā fiber; snell of a fishline, snood; ply, twist, strand; to make thread, as of olonā.
to cut off squarely or crosswise (kā, strike, and ʻāpahu, cut off short).
game of spinning small gourds like tops.
the one who, the person in question (usually followed by i, completed aspect, and a verb, a shortening of ka mea).
same as ke (verb) lā, but less common.
denoting present tense at a distance from the speaker. cf. ke (verb) nei.
a native tree (Nesoluma polynesicum), with milky sap and oblong, alternate leaves.
a specially built place reserved for the high chief on the platform of a double canoe.
white, clear; fair-complexioned person, often favorites at court (Malo 201); shiny, white mother-of-pearl shell,
a variety of sugar cane, among Hawaiians one of the best-known and most-used canes, especially in medicine: clumps erect, dense, of medium height; pith white.
name listed by Hillebrand for kolomona, native shrub, (Mezoneuron kavaiense).
redup. of keha, lofty, high, prominent, majestic, dignified...; to flaunt.
place where refuse is thrown and burned, dump.
miscarried foetus. lit., child slide without cause.
illegitimate child whose father is not definitely known. lit., wonder child.
a child with parents who provide good care and affection; people who have important parents.
native whose ancestors for several generations back were natives of the same place.
suckling child. lit., child consume milk.
gauge, as on a sewing machine.
to glory in, take pride in; dignified, proud, glorious; one's pride and glory.
a hard rock from which adzes were made.
a religious service, especially for dedication of timber for a temple building, or to dedicate a live chicken or pig to be killed for sacrifice. (Malo text, chapter 26, section 7.1).
small and ugly, with pug nose.
degree, as in latitude, music; an academic degree.
redup. of keʻe₁, but more common; distorted, crooked, twisted. fig., unrighteous, erroneous, distorted.
monkey, ape; said to be an ancient name for a small and ugly creature, especially with a pug nose.

• surly, cross, cranky, 
   • violently rude, 
   • needlessly and unbearably insulting, 
   • snarling, often in the sense of making threats that may not be carried out; 
   • to shriek in anger.
about the same as kekē niho, but with more verbalization and scolding; sharp-tongued. lit., scolding beak.
indecent exposure by a woman or girl; admonition to a female to sit properly.
carob tree (Ceratonia siliqua), somewhat like the algaroba; in (Luka 15.16)  Hawaiian hua keratio corresponds to English pods (RSV) or husks (KJV).
checkered jacket; the material from which it is made.

a hula step invented by Hawaiian sailors: one foot swings alternately on ball and heel of foot, the other points with the toe front and back four times, then reversed; knees are bent, arms out, bent at elbows with hands up and fingers often snapping, swaying with the body; to dance thus.

excelling, exceeding, projecting beyond, reaching high above; to jut out, excel.  cf. ex.,ʻoi₂. cf.:
   kākela, to perform well...
   pākela, excel; exceedingly; great person who excels...
   poʻokela, foremost, best, superior, prime, outstanding, greatest...
excessively damp, wet, muddy, greasy, fat, etc.
thin, as watery poi; muddy, as water. hoʻo.kele wai To use much water in mixing or pounding poi, or in irritation.
process by which a priest cleansed himself of impurities (kele) from contact with the dead.
general name for metals, as brass, copper, bronze, tin, steel, lead.
telegram; to send a telegram or cable.
telegraph; to send a telegram or cable. See song, (EM 61).

redup. of kele₁,
   • mud, mire, slush, muddy, 
   • fat, oil; oily, rich, greasy.
consecrated oil and balm, as used in confirmation services; chrisom.
earthen crock as used for poi, said to have been introduced from Germany.
coarse tapa, as made from māmaki bark or from the waste of better grade tapa.

• watery, muddy, wet, swampy, 
   • greasy, fat, lush. 
   • fig., impurity.
to sail; reached by sailing; flight, sailing.
to scrape cooked taro with ʻopihi or spoon after peeling is removed, to clean it in preparation for pounding.
slimy, foul with snot; slippery, as thick mucus.
unpleasant stifling sensation of inhaling smoke; suffocation from smoke.
weary, as from heavy toil; grieved and distressed.
to assemble a complete outfit or set, as of furniture, food, fishing gear, clothing.
dime, ten cents, small change, means.
