a variety of imported white sugar cane; also called lahaina cane.
to walk softly so as make no noise,

• interruption; to interrupt; 
   • choppy, as the sea.

conversational chant, fast rhythmic chant or recitation, with every syllable clearly pronounced and without prolonged vowels and not requiring too much breath. The paha chants are in this style. To chant thus.
to catch bonito, so named because the fisherman's body turns as he snaps the fish from the sea into his craft; this kind of fishing.
wedge used in repairing wooden bowls, often hammered in obliquely in zigzag pattern.
to scrape, as dirt from a board.
contract labor (from Eng. "ship," so called because Hawaiians shipping out on whaling ships were under contract; the term was later applied to sugar contract laborers); to contract for such service.
a kind of hard stone from which adzes were made.

• remaining, additional, spare, surplus, extra, 
   • excessive, more, too much (often followed by ā).
convex, concave; crescent-shaped, as the moon; contorted, perverted.
boom, crane; beam from which a weight is suspended and swung to and fro; cable line, as on a cable car (kaʻakewe).
stasis diffusion of lymph, said to be due to prolonged wetting of the feet, as in taro patch, sometimes called " Hawaiian elephantiasis," but no relation to elephantiasis as found in the South Seas.
a stick game like peewee: one player pries a small stick up from the ground with a longer stick, hits it, and tries to run to a point and back before his opponent can catch it. lit., wooden cross.
to shoot or slide arrows made of the stems of sugar-cane tassels.
fishhook with more than one barb; small stick with hooks at each end and line in the middle, as used for small fish.
ladder with crosspieces, a poetic reference to the ladders used to scale Kauaʻi precipices.
redup. of keʻa₁, fig., to hinder, obstruct, intercept, block...; to object, prevent, oppose; disputed.
bow, dart; to shoot with bow and arrow.
male animal reserved for breeding; virile male; sire.
any footrest, footstool, footprint; ground or floor stamped on or trodden on. (Probably keʻe + -hana, nominalizer; keʻehi₁, below, is probably keʻe + -hi, transitivizer.)
to farm at night, especially during the moonlight nights of Akua, Hoku, and Māhealani.
haughty, disdainful, assuming an air of superiority. lit., treading brow.

• footrest, footstool, 
   • position where one stands, 
   • stance, firm position, 
   • place.
narrow space between top edges of house thatching.
sour, bitter, crabbed, surly, ill-natured, turning against friends (frequently follows ʻōpū, disposition).
place to work, workshop, office, laboratory.
office where land claims were adjudicated by the Board of Commissioners to Quiet Land Titles.
taboo room; tabernacle (Puk. 25.9) , sanctuary (Puk. 25.8) , private room.
crookedness; fault, defect, flaw, deformity; crooked, bent, full of faults.
bleached muslin of good quality. lit., genuine whiteness.
bleached muslin of inferior quality, so called because it was weighted down as though with starch (pia); it was used for underclothing.
white muslin (usually followed by maoli, pia, or wai).
contraction of ka mea e, the one who will, should, or is; the thing that (or which) is, will, should.
monument, gravestone, memorial tablet, memorial, commemorative pillar.
signpost, tall stop sign, any pillar or large object with a sign, or serving as a marker; image on the wall surrounding a temple. lit., sign pillar.
birdcatcher, birdcatching by gumming; to catch birds by gumming.
a prefix to types of canoes.
a fresh-water fish similar to nāwao.
person of fixed purpose; with one accord or purpose; in unison, constant; alone, unique, supreme, only one.
long, light, and swift canoe. fig., a tall, well-proportioned woman.
term used in 1848 land claims, perhaps a steep hill.
a canoe with a deep, curving hull.
a short canoe with a rounded hull, as used for fishing near the shore.
swift-sailing canoe; any vessel equipped with cross spars, bark.
faint streak of red, as in the rainbow or in the clouds.
algaroba tree (Prosopis pallida), a legume from Peru, first planted in 1828 in Hawaiʻi, where, in dry areas, it has become one of the commonest and most useful trees.
a streak; to stream gracefully, as rain in the wind; to sway, as branches.
guard at a gate or door, doormats, porter, gatekeeper.
beach plant like kākalaioa, but thornless. lit., guardian at the cape.
bodyguard, security guard. lit., head guard.
guard, watchman, caretaker; to watch, guard, picket; to overlook, as a bluff.
to emit fragrance; to perfume with kiele, as garments.
same as liʻawahine, blossoms of kukui.
supernatural lizard (in such names as Kihalani-nui, Kiha-nui-lūlū-moku, and Kiha-wahine); reptile.
a small native fern (Xiphopteris saffordii), narrow, 4 to 14 cm high, the fronds somewhat notched.
a red seaweed (Chylocladia sp.) with narrow cylindrical, branching stems.
a sweet potato. lit., large-feafed kihi.
crooked, twisted, angular; to turn aside; one who turns aside, as to avoid others.
name of one of the places, as under a tapa, where the noʻa stone was hidden in the game of pūhenehene.
points or edges of the shoulders; shoulder; shoulder of a mountain.
name of one of the places under a tapa, where the noʻa stone was hidden in the game of pūhenehene.
corners, curves; angular, full of corners, zigzag.
Moorish idol, a small, brilliantly colored fish (Zanclus cornutus) with black bands alternating with yellow. Varieties are qualified by the terms lau nui or māneʻoneʻo, alo ʻula, hālena, and pōhaka.
a variety of sweet potato. Descriptive terms are lau manamana, lau nui, and lau poepoe.
canoes guarding the sides of mālolo and iheihe fish nets.
to plug or patch a calabash or canoe.
Kauaʻi name for ʻamakihi, a bird.
to sit on the heels, squat.

a native fern (Cyclosorus [Dryopteris] cyatheoides), with pinnate fronds, 1 m high or more, used for food and medicine. Roots and young fronds eaten raw; the roots grated and salted to taste, slimy like okra. Also pakikawaiō. see ex., kiʻoa.
crescent-shaped; having corners like a cocked hat.
doorframe, covering for doorframe; side posts of a door, house post on a heiau; door casing (cf. kukuna).

• to dodge or move about quickly, especially with quick turning of sharp corners; 
   • canoe sailing, to sail.
to mend, as a crack in a wooden bowl.
same as ʻiʻiʻi or makaliʻi, tiny.
cry of the ʻōʻō bird; to cry thus.
distant time, either in the remote past or future; far in time or distance.
settling of water in pools or puddles; to settle.
a plug shaped like the kepa wedge but with the outer end longer, used in filling cracks in wooden bowls or canoes; to plug a hole, patch a canoe or calabash.
punctuation mark indicative of a pause, as comma, colon, semicolon, period. lit., resting punctuation mark.
period mark in punctuation. lit., single dot.
term of reproach for commoners committing incest (perhaps a post-Christian term). lit., hatch like chickens.
dotted, spotted, speckled, as a pig; to dot frequently; to discolor with spots; to nibble, as fish at bait; to peck repeatedly, as a feeding hen.
colored in stripes; to mark in long parallel lines in a variety of colors.
center of a circle; headquarters; Central, telephone operator; bull's eye.

• dot, point, spot, speck of any kind; dotted, speckled, spotted; to dot, mark, hatch [mark with lines]
   • tattooed with dots on the forehead
   • dot in music indicating time added to a note, also to repeat
   • punctuation mark
   • section of a story
   • to pick up food, as chickens; peck
   • to injure fruit, as by a fruit fly
   • cock or trigger of a gun
taboo mark consisting of two crossed ti leaves held in place by a pebble.
to draw or guess the winning number in chee-fah, a Chinese gambling game.
thin end of a fish pole.

• to run fast, 
   • to grow fast.
to shoot water with a hose or water pistol, to hose. cf. hoʻokahe wai to let water run in irrigation.
slimy liquid in the blossom of the mountain ginger.
steel for cutting ears [of cattle for identification].

• majestic, imposing; 
   • tall, 
   • strong, 
   • having poise that commands admiration.
seal, deed, patent, brand; sealed; to fix a seal.
pen; to write with a pen.
ice-cold shower; cold drizzle; to rain thus. fig., tipsy.
light, soft, gentle rain; pleasant patter of gentle rain; to rain gently.
fine, misty rain, somewhat heavier mist than the kili ʻohu.
stained with color, as a sky at sunset.

• fine, light rain, 
   • wind-blown spray, 
   • drizzle; to shower lightly.
a fine, delicate species of Hypnea (seaweed), probably H. cervicornis.
drenched, as by sea spray or fragrance.
a passing, moving shower; to shower lightly and briefly.
a kind of tapa, associated with Waipiʻo, Hawaiʻi.

the black mulberry (Morus nigra), introduced into Hawaiʻi in hopes of establishing a silk-producing industry. It is a low tree bearing juicy, sweet, red to black fruits and ovate leaves. The leaves are fed to silkworms, The tree comes from the Far East.
same as kilikili noe, misty, light rain.
a vine with small elliptical leaves at internodes of 11.5 cm. According to C. S. Judd, this may be a native climbing shrub (Embelia pacifica), in the Myrsine family.
well-shaped and moist, as of a flower wet with dew or fine raindrops.
to clap the hands with palms slightly cupped; to bring down the cupped hand.
a dipper or water carrier made of taro or ʻape leaf.
absorbed in an interesting, happy pastime, as love-making; contented.
some small cosmopolitan weeds, grasslike sedges, as nut grass (Cyperus rotundus); also two others (C. kyllinga and C. brevifolius); the flower stalk with head is used for stringing small fish.
raindrops; fine rain; to rain gently. fig., to go or move in a light, sprightly manner.

one who fishes for octopus by looking through a glass-bottomed box; formerly the kilo heʻe spit chewed kukui nut on the sea to calm the water, then examined (kilo) the sea bottom for octopus; to fish thus. Also ʻōkilo heʻe.
astrologer, astronomer, astronomy; to observe and study the stars.
a man who observes fish movements from a high place and directs fishermen; to so act.
soothsayer who predicts the future by observing the sky; to do so; astronomer, astronomy, astrologer.
one who observes the winds for purposes of navigation; to so observe.
oceanography, oceanographer; to observe and study the open seas.
palmistry, palmist; to predict on observation of the hand.
one who tells the future by use of playing cards; to do so.
stone placed under water to give a reflection, used as a mirror.
spiritualism, spiritualist; to communicate with spirits.

name of the outside, decorated sheet of tapa in the kuʻinakapa, bed coverings; the four inner layers were white, contrasting with the decorated kilohana. Hence extended meanings: best, superior, excellent.

• hillock, 
   • heap, 
   • lookout,  view out, 
   • top,high point 
    (kilo + -hana, nominalizer).
to glance, gaze, as into a mirror (kilo + hi, transitivizer).
redup. of kilo₁, stargazer, seer, to watch closely, spy, examine, forecast…; enchantment, magic, fortune telling; magical.

• stargazer, reader of omens, seer, astrologer, necromancer; forecast. 
   • kind of looking glass (rare); 
   • to watch closely, spy, examine, look around, observe
cf.:
     hākilo to observe closely, spy on, reconnoiter, snoop...
     mākilo  to eye wistfully, to look at longingly, to beg thus; beggar...
     ʻōkilo  same as kilo, observe, forecast... 
     kilokilo  redup. of kilo, stargazer..., to watch closely…; enchantment, magic...

• a small gourd or coconut shell, usually cut lengthwise, as used for storing small, choice objects, or to feed favorite children from. 
   • Used also as a quoit in the kilu game: 
     the player chanted as he tossed the kilu towards an object placed in front of one of the opposite sex; if he hit the goal he claimed a kiss; to play this game. (Malo 216-18: ch. 42). In the Bishop Museum are stone quoits labelled kilu. see ex., eo and (FS 275–83).
unpleasant musty odor, especially resulting from a cold in the nose.
to bend down the head, bow; to go headlong as in diving.

up-and-down motion, as of a trip hammer.
   redup. of kimo₁, (play) a game similar to jacks...
   redup. of kimo₂, to bob, as the head; to bend or fall forward...
a game similar to jacks: a stone is tossed into the air by the player, who quickly picks another off the ground before he catches the other; jackstones; to play kimo. The players often chanted.
fireman, fire extinguisher; to put out fires.
extinguishing, putting out, snuffing out of life.
the countless spirits and gods; the multitudinous spirits.
extremely well-suited, fine-looking. lit., many suitable.
pail for carrying poi (ʻai) or other food.
garbage or rubbish can. waste basket (HE)
a ball game, something like playing catch on the run; to play the game.
marble, game of marbles (formerly round pebbles or seeds); to play marbles.
Niʻihau name for kākalaioa₃, yellow nickers.
name of a game in which the stone called hiu was used.
multitude, many; forty thousand. [traditional 4-based counting: kāuna 4; kaʻau 40; lau 400; mano 4,000; kini 40,000; lehu 400,000]
marble (a child's best marble in the game; kinikini is more common).

a "fire body": the bones of a deceased thrown into a fire pit so that the spirit of the deceased may be with and serve family relatives, of the Pele family. The bones of Mary Kawena Pukui's great grandmother were thus buried.
spirit, especially of a living person.
apposition, in grammar. lit., enlarged form.
many forms taken by a supernatural body, as Pele, who could at will become a flame of fire, a young girl, or an old hag.
spirit of the dead; dead person, bodily remains, corpse.
a strong scent, as of tobacco.
a common mussel, probably Brachidontes cerebristriatus.
bristle-thighed curlew (Numenius tahitiensis), large, dusky brown, migratory bird with a long, curved bill; the cry of this bird.
spoiling, as a flower too long in the rain.
cliff or ridge with irregular projections.
young, immature, as flora or fauna.

• to throw, toss; 
   • to deposit, as, bones of the dead.
high, rickety or unsafe seat; high, long, rickety.
long fishing line for deep-sea fishing.
to ride or sit astride, as on a horse; to straddle.
probably Natica gualteriania. lit., sand-dwelling kio (mollusk).
a small native shrub (Hedyotis coriacea, syn: Kadua menziesiana), belonging to the coffee family, a rare or extinct species.
word used in reply to a question one does not care to answer, somewhat like rude English "What's it to you?"
cords made of hibiscus bark used as drawstrings of a large net.

mock warfare, training in warfare by combat (And); according to (Malo 66) kaua kio is mock warfare with blunted spears. (Kawelo's warriors greet him as he returns from fishing by hurling spears at him for him to dodge or parry: (FS 52))

mussels. see:
     kio₃, same as kaunaʻoa₂, a mollusk...
     kio nahawele, a common mussel, probably Brachidontes cerebristriatus...
     kionohoone, probably Natica gualteriania. lit., sand-dwelling kio (mollusk)... 
     kio poʻapoʻai, same as poʻapoʻai₂, a mollusk...
to go visiting from place to place.
to call without being asked; to intrude; to happen in on a visit by chance.
to send away, drive away, expel, discharge, banish, put out of the house, get rid of, rout, exile, evict.
to turn aside; to turn from the direct path.
to hew, trim; little by little.
rebellion, revolt, treachery, treason, uprising; rebel, seditious; to rebel, plot, revolt, resist lawful authority; to conspire against; to ram, as of a goat.
Hilo name for mound taro patches.
to dig with a sharp tool.
Oʻahu name for the ʻakialoa bird.
to make a hollow or round opening, like the eye socket; hollow.
mixed, mingled; varying in color or texture, as of the sea; to add to, as something of different character, as ferns to a lei .
to spy cunningly in order to entrap, perhaps by pretense of cultivating friendship.
spy, scout; to spy, observe secretly. cf. hoʻomakākiu.
untidy, disorderly, unkempt; scrawly, as writing.

• curved, bent
   • curved object such as a sickle
   • horn of an animal, antler
   • horn of the kala, a fish
   • to pull obliquely, as a fish on a line
   • to bend forward or sideways, as a sleepy person
   • to reel and stagger as in drunkenness
   • to fall or stumble head foremost
small cave, fissure, as used for burial. Niʻihau.
a name for the curved portion of a canoe rim.

• to peer, peep, as through a door or crevice; to look at slyly; 
   • to protrude forth.
height, altitude, elevation, rise, tableland, bluff.
to squat on one's haunches; to straddle; to stand with legs far apart. cf. Tongan sike, to squat on heels.
type of hula in which the dancer danced in a squatting position. cf. (UL 210).
slide picture shown on a screen by a projector. lit., image enlargement.
to make gestures in the hula pūʻili and hula ʻulīʻulī imitative of the words of the chant; these gestures.
cartoon. lit., picture to cause mirth.
to fetch something, as greenery for an altar, with observation of taboos.
John ʻĪʻī's name for kāʻai, casket.  lit., image wicker body.
to make time-keeping hula gestures with the left hand reaching forward and back to the front of the shoulder, while tapping the ʻulīʻulī on the right lap; these gestures.
prominent, wealthy, or important person, VIP; lit., big-eyed image (ON 1794)
printed picture, as in a newspaper.

in a hula, tapping the lap or left hand with the base of the ʻulīʻulī; tapping the palm of the left hand, floor, back of left hand and right shoulder with end of pūʻuli; both are now called in English "common motion"; to do so.
pupil of the eye. fig., beloved person.
lashing of wall plate to wall post.
gadabout, wanderer; to gad about, wander, on the move.
to stand, sit, or walk with legs wide apart, straddle; straddling.
drifting clouds of different colors, including black and white.
ointment made of breadfruit bark crushed with thin young coconut leaves.
enlarged, swollen, bloated, as of a rotting corpse.

• pas/imp. of
    • kiʻi₂ to fetch, get, procure, send for, go after, summon, attack, to seek for sexual ends....; 
    • kiʻi₆ gesture, as in hula...
   • war-club stroke.
homebody; to remain at home constantly.
to go about in idleness and mischief. [Pua was the name of a mischievous goddess of sorcery.]
hula step: one foot points to the side, front, and back; then the other foot does the same.
fiery pit, place of torment, hell.
swamp, mire (2-Pet. 2.22) , fen (Ioba 40.21) ; mud puddle, dirty pool.
pool of water, water hydrant, water hole, fountain (Mele 4.12) ; to settle, as water.
variegated, as calm and unruffled spots in the sea.
tapa-drying and bleaching place; to dry and bleach tapa; to dye tapa.
taro-leaf container as held in the mouth, so as to form a basket to hold shrimps (ʻōpae) while groping with the hands for shrimp. Also pūʻolo ʻōpae.
to excrete, evacuate, give birth to a child (often sarcastic).

a common roadside shrub or small tree (Leucaena leucocephala), from tropical America, with pinnate leaves, round white flower treads, and long, flat, brown pods; closely related to the koa. The small brown seeds are strung for leis, purses, mats; plants used for fodder. lit., foreign koa.
infantry soldier. lit., soldier goes afoot.
var. of koa makua ʻole. lit., koa without trunk.
a kind of koa tree regarded by Hawaiians as male. lit., strong koa.
a variety of koa. lit., large-leafed koa.
famous legendary koa tree at Kahi-ki-kolo, Kauaʻi, thought to have no roots or trunk, and to spread over the ground like a creeper. lit., koa without parent.
young shoots of mulberry plant used for medicine; soft mulberry fiber used for making fine white tapa.

a native tree (Acacia koaia), much like the koa but smaller, the pods narrower and with seeds arranged vertically in the pod, rather than horizontally as in koa, and leaves averaging narrower; the wood is harder, formerly used for spears, fancy paddles, and for the iʻe tapa beater; later for furniture. fig., person from the upland country. Also koaiʻa.
naked, exposed, of a male. fig., dissipated, debauchee (Laie 501 [104]), dissolute.
a tropical American weedy vine (Merremia aegyptia, synonym, (Ipomoea pentaphylla) with tawny-hairy stems and leaves, the leaves five-lobed, the flowers white.

the moonflower (Ipomoea alba), a morning-glory found in many tropical countries, with fragrant, white, night-blooming flowers, to 15 cm long, and heart-shaped, angled, or lobed leaves. Also, large form of koali ʻawa.

an African morning-glory (Ipomoea cairica var. hederacea), with pink or purple flowers and five-to seven-lobed leaves; the long trailing stems were formerly used as cordage, the tuberous roots and main stems, though somewhat bitter, as famine food. Also koali lau manamana and paʻaliʻi, and koali ʻaiʻai on Niʻihau.

a morning-glory (Ipomoea indica), a native of Pacific islands, with heart-shaped leaves, flowers opening blue in the morning and changing to pink later in the day. When pounded, the bitter-tasting stems and roots are used externally for bruises and broken bones, but are dangerous to take internally. Also koali ʻawahia and koali lāʻau on Niʻihau.
some kinds of morning-glory (Ipomoea spp.). The vines were used for swings and nets (kōkō).
swing; to swing, twirl about, twine.
spacing, space, as between rows of stitching in a quilt; width of pandanus strips used in plaiting, weft.
bruised or parched spot on fruit, as breadfruit.
koa with yellowish wood, regarded as female by Hawaiians. lit., ginger koa.
the white-tailed tropic bird (Phaethon lepturus dorotheae), which inhabits cliffs of the high islands...
the red-tailed tropic bird (P. rubricauda rothschildi)
to adjust and fit canoe parts to the canoe body.

the tropic or boatswain bird, particularly the white-tailed tropic bird (Phaethon lepturus dorotheae), which inhabits cliffs of the high islands. The red-tailed tropic bird (P. rubricauda rothschildi) is koaʻe ʻula; the white is koaʻe kea.
a taro; varieties are qualified by the colors ʻeleʻele, keʻokeʻo, ʻulaʻula.
a snapper, probably Etelis carbunculus, an important commercial fish also known as onaga (Japanese).
except for this, however, but, furthermore
a large remainder, a balance, remnant; to be many remaining.
to edge away, back away, creep, move cautiously and carefully, as a frightened or feeble person.
to sway in the breeze, as a tree.

• nude, naked; bare, 
   • alone, by itself.
taro growing in front of the door and about the house. lit., naked urine (so called because people urinated there).
division between the vagina and anus.
venereal disease of women. lit., itching vagina.
warm, clear, serene weather; to be such.
all species of a genus of sedges (Eleocharis), some introduced, some native. Also pīpī wai.
a white loli that lives in the sand (perhaps Holothuria arenicola). lit., hanging vagina.
corrugated stone used for smoothing wood or stone; to file or rasp with this stone.
an ancient sickness characterized by ill-smelling vagina discharge. lit., rotten vagina.
to choose at random, without thought or care, arbitrarily; to vote without forethought, or for the sake of voting.
first choice, primary election, first guess; hypothesis.
right choice; to choose rightly; to vote a straight ticket.
to cast a ballot, vote; voting, election, suffrage.
the first law a chief promulgates, a strict law.

lance for boils, sores, as of fishbone or a sharp stick; abortion stick; this term, like that referring to other sharp things (shark, sea urchin, eel) is applied to chiefs as indicative of the sharp defense of the chief against contact with his taboo person, or infringement of his taboos.
a scandent shrub, native to Kauaʻi, in the composite family (Dubautis latifolia), with long branches, opposite, elliptical, pointed leaves, and small flower heads in large panicles.
election, choice, selection; to choose, select, bid, decide on, pick, nominate, vote, elect, draw lots.
sap of kukui fruit stem used as a purge.
not matching, unsuitable, ill-suited, ridiculous, absurd, inappropriate, of poor taste, silly; nonsense.

• resemblance, appearance, likeness, match; like, resembling, alike, similar.
   • suitable, agreeable, appropriate, matching, 
   • in good taste, attractive, becoming, pleasing, fit,

• crack of a whip, report of a pistol, slapping sound, loud squeak; to resound thus, 
   • squawk, croak.
to resound loudly, as poi being vigorously pounded.
to sue for or claim damages.
to move to and fro restlessly, as the sea.
to rest on, as the moon on the surface of the sea; to sink into, penetrate.

• to urge, implore, 
   • persuade, 
   • compel, 
   • require, requirement,
   • insist on, ask insistently, 
   • demand, 
   • claim, 
   • pull;
fishing pole, pole fishing (same as the more common mākoi).

a native hibiscus, a small tree or tall shrub (Hibiscus arnottianus) with large, white, fragrant flowers. It is found chiefly on Oʻahu; also a similar hibiscus (H. waimeae) from Kauaʻi, with smaller leaves.
Hibiscus kokio, a native red hibiscus. Also kokiʻo, kokiʻo ʻula.
a native shrubby hibiscus (Hibiscus kokio) with red flowers. The wood produced fine charcoal.
all species of a native genus (Kokia) of small trees related to the hibiscus, with red flowers, and round, leathery leaves with from three to seven shallow points.
anemia; to have such. lit., watery blood.

a hairy cosmopolitan spurge (Euphorbia hirta), a small, weedy herb; leaves opposite, oblong, pointed at tip, oblique at base, with brownish spot near center, tiny flowers clustered at leaf axils.  lit., foreign koko.
high blood pressure. lit., mounting blood.
jet, spurt; to flow, rush, as a torrent or crowd.
bloody; rare, as steak. fig., violently angry.
to have intercourse with a menstruating woman. lit., vagina blood.
small, inferior, and sometimes soggy sweet potatoes.
taro of the fifth generation. see kalo for names of generations.
any food crop stunted by weeds or drought.
to grow strong after a period of weakness.
settee, couch (formerly made of pandanus plaiting).
crow, cackle, of chickens; to crow.
to lay waste, especially to devastate crops.
to spread out, as a turkey's tail.
variety of the fish kole, said to have fine hairlike growths around the mouth. lit., kole with hairy mouth.
Heiau, temple, built by a chief after recovering from serious sickness, named in honor of the first man who learned the use of herbs in healing and who was deified after his death.
to cry, of the kōlea, bird; to sing, of the kāhuli, land shell in Hawaiian belief. fig., a child that runs about wildly.
variety of moana, goatfish, perhaps Parupeneus chrysonemus.
said to be Kauaʻi name for a large kole, the fish.
weak and spent, as an old plant.
a variety of domesticated ʻilima with bronze-red flowers. lit., kukui candle.
an ʻilima rod, a fathom or so long, tipped with feathers and used as a wand in the ʻume game.
to rush out, as pent-up water; to flow swiftly, leak.

a native lobelia shrub (Trematolobelia macrostachys) to 1.8 m high, with several horizontal branches at the top when in flower, each branch bearing a long cluster of pink flowers, each flower 5 cm long; the narrow leaves to 30 by 2.5 cm.
to disappear gradually, as a ship on the horizon; to evaporate; to be barely visible, as the sun's first rays.
luakini dedication prayer. Also koliʻi maomao
• to whittle, pare, sharpen, peel;    • to trim, as a lamp or the raveled edges of a dress;    • to shave, as hair.see paʻi koli, to trim, cut short...

Hawaiian duck (Anas wyvilliana). Also koloa maoli, native koloa, to distinguish it from migratory or introduced ducks, also called koloa. Formerly on all main islands except Lānaʻi and Kahoʻolawe; in 1976 common only on Kauaʻi; birds raised in capitivity and released have been seen on Oʻahu and Hawaiʻi; considered endangered in 1978. Koloa birds protected a legendary blind giant, Ima-i-ka-lani, and quacked to warn him from which side he might expect an attack.
shoveler or spoonbill (Anas clypeata), a migrant. lit., bright duck (said to be named for the dark glossy green head of the male).
pintail duck (Anas acuta), a common migrant to the Hawaiian Islands. lit., wind-blown duck.
to stretch out; stretched out, long and thin.
pheasant (Phasianus colchicus torquatus), the showy ring-necked pheasant. lit., creep go on.

method of catching birds by means of a long stick with a crosspiece at the end; flowers were attached and smeared with sticky juice to which the birds stuck. The birds were first attracted by whistling. A bird catcher; to catch thus. lit., creep whistle.
the beach vitex (Vitex ovata), distributed from Hawaiʻi west to Japan and India, an aromatic, prostrate beach shrub, with downy, ovate leaves and small, blue, clustered flowers. lit., beach creeper.

two loosestrifes (Lysimachia daphnoides, L. hillebrandii), small native shrubs with purplish flowers, the branches densely covered with narrow, pointed leaves. L. daphnoides is confined to the high bogs of Kauaʻi. lit., mountain creeper. also kolekole lehua.
humble, modest, thoughtful, kind. cf. kolokolo, creeping, as in respect to a chief, and akahai, modest.
tiny stage of the kūmū, weke, and other goatfish; other stages are ʻāhuluhulu, kūmū aʻe, and kūmū.
redup. of kolo₁, to creep, crawl; to move along...; to track down, investigate, seek evidence.
soft, weak and helpless, as a newborn baby or newly hatched bird; soft and not yet hardened, as a new growth of bone; easily influenced and impressed, as an unstable person.
third mate on a ship; the officer next to the second mate.
a native shrub (Cassia gaudichaudii) with greenish-yellow flowers and thin flat pods.
a similar shrub (Cassia surattensis syn. C. glauca), with an Asian to Australian distribution, naturalized in Hawaiʻi and also grown ornamentally, with yellow flowers and flat pods.
a weedy shrub (Cassia floribunda syn. C. laevigat), from tropic America, with yellow flowers and cylindrical pods.
Crotalaria incana, C. pallida, C. spectabilis on Niʻihau.
name listed by Hillebrand for Mezoneuron kavaiense.
gentle, pleasant breeze; gentle, mild; softly blowing. lit., gentle creeping.
fragrant, as air laden with the perfume of flowers, sometimes said of the breath. lit., creeping flowers.
old, infirm, of an aged person bent with age. lit., creep crouched.
to fight, scream, kick, as children in tantrums; to jerk away from, as a runaway horse; to bolt.
well-proportioned, of a large person whose flesh is evenly distributed; also said of a long koa tree trunk that grows straight without branching.
name of a law in the time of Kū-aliʻi safeguarding the rights of commoners.
old, worn-out, of an old hag or old sow.
to pull, tow, drag, to pull a seine.
call to fowl, pigs. Kolo, kolo, kolo! Come, come, come!
same as pāʻaila, castor bean or castor-oil plant. The name may be qualified by keʻokeʻo, light-colored, and ʻulaʻula, red. Niʻihau. See castor bean.

a thorny, weedy shrub (Acacia farnesiana), widespread in the tropics. It is a legume with finely divided leaves and fragrant, round, orange flower heads, used in the perfume industry. The bark yields a gum for glue; sometimes spelled klu.
same as ʻinikō, indigo plant, used for bluing.
apostrophe, glottal stop. lit., comma (Eng.) above.
tomato (generally called ʻōhiʻa or ʻōhiʻa lomi).
stone, as used with octopus lures.
housewarming; moving into a new house.
to trespass, enter by mistake or illegally, intrude; to put on in a wrong way, as clothes wrong side out.
to put on clothing inside out. lit., wear seams.
to go from house to house, as a census taker or salesman.
to enter without permission or ceremony, trespass, intrude.
to do with unanimity; to undertake a project wholeheartedly; to cooperate with enthusiasm. lit., to enter whole.
to take possession of a land; to acquire land, as by inheritance.
house visiting, as by a priest making the rounds of his district; visiting from district to district, as by a church committee. lit., enter district.
evil possession resulting from sorcery. cf. noho.
term used in 1845 for a military company.
very small, tiny, of small stature; also said of people of little consequence.
to dress, put on, wear (any garment, formerly only lower garments).
a variety of introduced sweet potato. lit., Kona packet (Eng.).
a native tufted grass (Panicum nephelophilum), to 1.3 m high, with a large, open-flowering panicle to 35 by 25 cm.
posts on each side of the two center posts at the back wall of a grass house.
to move the ʻiliʻili, pebble, in the kōnane game.
rock badger (RSV), coney (KJV) . described by (Kep), perhaps a gony (gooney).
to entice a bird, as by imitating its call, and then to snare it; a birdcatcher.
to catch black crabs (ʻelepī), as by tying ʻopihi limpets to a cord dangled above a rock fissure; the crab snatches the bait, the cord is drawn up and the crab seized.
headman of an ahupuaʻa land division under the chief; land or fishing rights under control of the konohiki; such rights are sometimes called konohiki rights.
same as konoʻele (darkness, as of a forest; said also of the inside of thighs thought to be darkened by the chafing of the malo; somewhat darker than konouli...), but perhaps less dark.
darkness, as of a forest; said also of the inside of thighs thought to be darkened by the chafing of the malo; somewhat darker than konouli.
to attract the attention of a bird, as by imitating its call, and then to snare it, as with gummed ʻieʻie roots. ʻUaʻu birds were snared thus.
hard, unyielding, unfriendly, contemptuous, brusque, haughty.
strong, as the hand of a fighter.
a native shrub (Hedyotis [Kadua] glaucifolia), found only on Kauaʻi, with narrow, tubular, inconspicuous, pale-yellow flowers, and narrow-ovate to heart-shaped leaves; related to the ʻuiwi.

• to scribble.
   • redup. of kope₁ to rake, scratch...
hornet, wasp, scorpion (kopiana is the usual name for scorpion).
copy, duplicate; to copy or duplicate.
coping on the top of a building.

the foreign kou (Cordia sebestena), a small tree, related to the kou, from which it differs in having stiff, rough, dark-green leaves, brighter red-orange flowers, and white, pulpy, instead of dry, fruits.

a tree found on shores from East Africa to Polynesia (Cordia subcordata), with large, ovate leaves, and orange, tubular flowers 2.5 to 5 cm in diameter, borne in short-stemmed clusters. The beautiful wood, soft but lasting, was valuable to the early Hawaiians and was used for cups, dishes, and calabashes.

many words are spelled with and without -w- after -o- or -ō-, as koali and kowali, kōelo and kōwelo. In the dictionary the form without -w- is preferred unless the w is the initial of a base; cf. wehe, kōwehe; welo, kōwelo.
noisy, as the sea dashing against the cliff.
thrifty, saving; to have saved or accumulated.
to stay or live in one place.
coral shoal with rough sea where two or more opposing currents meet. fig., valiant. lit., dashing coral.
coagulated mass of blood that fails to come away with afterbirth.
small pool from which most of the water has evaporated.
dregs, sediment, small fragments, particles; to settle, as dregs; to stay or settle in one place, as people.
fishing grounds, usually identified by lining up with marks on shore.

shrine, often consisting of circular piles of coral or stone, built along the shore or by ponds or streams, used in ceremonies as to make fish multiply; also built on bird islands, and used in ceremonies to make birds multiply.
any sea worm, as the marine nematodes; roundworms or threadworms.
design on a tapa beater or on tapa consisting of gently waving, delicate parallel lines (the waves are smaller and less jagged than those of the hāʻao).
Koʻeau design with one or more straight lines separating every two wavy lines.
same as kaikoʻeke, most used as a term of address.
cool, damp, chilled from wet and cold.

• sound of tapping, as wood against wood; to tap, 
   • ticking, as of clock; to tick, 
   • thumping, to thump, 
   • trudging; to trudge, 
   • rattling, as a window; to rattle; 
   • crack of thunder; 
   • to crackle,
   • noisy, 
   • stormy.

• sound of footsteps; 
   • to walk, trudge.
pig's jawbone used for grooving (hole) boards for making ribbed tapa.
adze used to smooth a canoe. broad, bent adze; used to shave off smooth in the direction of the grain. (Holmes)
chisel. narrow and deep adze [koʻi hoʻoma] (Holmes)
carpenter's plane; scraper, as for olonā fiber. lit., shaving adze.
wood-working plane, carpenter's plane. [koʻi kahela chisel (Holmes)]
joiner's adze. lit., adze for putting together. (finishing adze (Holmes))
adze with straight edges, used to shave down the sides of a bowl or canoe.
adze, axe, hatchet. lit., sharp adze. (used for hewing koa trees (Holmes))
small, oval adze as used for finishing a canoe.
chisel, stone battle-axe. lit., dagger adze.
planing adze, as for rough (ʻāhuluhulu) lumber
socketed adze, as used for hollowing out the narrow bow and stern of a canoe hull.
gouge. lit., twisting adze. Also koʻi wili.
genealogical chant; to sing such chants.

• fresh, as plants; 
   • erection of male genital.
axe, adze; adzelike, sharp, projecting, as a forehead.
young stage of all ʻulaʻula, red snappers.
long tail feathers of a cock.
same as kōkoʻo, partnership, partner, but usually followed by a number; partner.
canoe carrying only one person (a canoe carrying two persons was koʻolua, three was koʻokolu, etc.).
taboo with death as penalty for breaking; to lay such a taboo.
to have gray or white hair.
cane with a handle. lit., tee-shaped cane.
an introduced coreopsis (Coreopsis lanceolata), with ray and central florets all yellow.

all kinds of beggar ticks (Bidens spp.), most native, a few introduced, some used medicinally by Hawaiians, as a tonic in tea; the plants are still dried and used for tea, often in preference to tea bought in stores.  cf. kī₂.
Niʻihau name for nehe, Lipochaeta perdita, a hairy herb.
to reach far for; to rest one hand for support (koʻokoʻo) and reach out with the other.
var. of kōkoʻo, and likewise followed by numerals and -hia.
to swell out; stick out, as a ruffle.
hillside, slope, mountain slope; hillside road or path.
ulua fishline 15 or so fathoms long.
a native shrub with pale-pink flowers, otherwise like koʻoloa ʻula.
a native, hoary shrub (Abutilon menziesii), related to the hibiscus, with heart-shaped leaves 2.5 to 8 cm long, and dark-red flowers from which protrude many stamens borne on a central column.

• brace, support, wand, prop, helper;    • small stalks to which feathers on large kāhili, standards, are tied, and which are attached to the main pole;    • pole as used in pushing a canoe; to pole, push with a pole, 
   • to prop;   • sprit of a canoe's sail;    • stick fastened across a small fish net near the meeting of the sticks (kuku) supporting the net;     • to uphold.
tail feathers, as. of a cock, or as below the tail of the mamo, a bird.

(rarely used except after kai).
   • force, strength; strong, 
   • rough.
loose, slack; to lay on in folds, as pleats in a dress; to loosen, slacken.
light-green leaves near the center of a cluster of pandanus leaves.

• to cluck. 
   • fig., to talk too much.
team (horse or oxen) closest to the pulled vehicle.
wooden anvil, as used for beating tapa.
back of the temple of the head.
surf just before it breaks, wave crest  (sometimes used without article).
to hew boards or planks; to hew out a poi-pounding board.
portion of boom (ʻiako) lashed to the canoe.
generations back, two (or sometimes today, one) more than the suffixed number.
once, twice, three times, twofold, etc., depending on numeral suffix
mountain area where trees are stunted as due to altitude.
name of a quilting design. lit., turtle back.
supporting rods for house purlins (Kam. 76:98), brace.
any wild vegetable eaten in time of famine; to eat such.
to scour, rub, polish, grind, scrape; to drag a scraping object; to mark a line from which marbles are shot.

to give up, as a riddle; to be unable to answer; expression used in riddling. The person who can not guess a riddle says: Kuailo! I can't guess the answer, you tell me. If the riddler doesn't want to give the answer, he may reply tartly: ʻEu nō ka ilo, make! Maggots move! Defeated!
border or bank as between taro patches or cultivated fields.
swipes, home-brew, as made of pineapples, mangoes, molasses, or watermelons. slang.
once, singly; first; single, unwedded, unmarried.

three generations removed, as great-grandparent (kupuna kuakahi) and great-grandchild (moʻopuna kuakahi), as distinguished from a great-great-grandchild (moʻopuna kualua) and a great-great-grandparent (kupuna kualua). Sometimes today kuakahi denotes two generations removed.
unobstructed, unhampered, free from interference; straight to the point, without deviation, as a story.
medicine made of pua kala plant and taken as treatment for pyorrhea, neuralgia, stomach ulcers.
taboo on approaching a chief from behind. fig., quiet, safe, peaceful, so called because of the protection and security afforded by the taboo.

• travail of childbirth, especially bearing-down pain; to suffer labor. 
   • fig., uncontrolled anger.
five generations removed, of a great-great-great-grandparent or great-great-great-grandchild, as kupuna kuakolu, moʻopuna kuakolu, for some speakers, four generations removed.
newly made taro patch embankment; process of packing the earth for the banks and floor of a taro patch.

strip, especially space between lines of stitching in quilting; embankment between taro patches that was kept under cultivation (Malo 19, Emerson note); leaf midrib; narrow land strip; strip of fish netting; ridged cloth, as corduroy or piqué.
a sea creature, perhaps Aplysia dactylomela or A. juliana.
raw fish mashed to a pulp; to be hand-fed this pulp by the kau method.
officer who watched over a sleeping or resting chief and waved the kāhili, feather standard.
lazy, indolent, bored, fatigued; roving about without a chief to support one, as a "floater" (lana); to wander.
to float on the back; buoyant.
to stretch out or project, as a cape.
pugilist in the high chief's court, a muscular young man who might also be asked to massage a chiefess or have relations with her.
cooked, unpounded taro (same as kalo paʻa, nēʻū).
pure white mother-of-pearl shell, much prized because of its rarity, as used for fishhooks or lures.
a great talker; to talk verbosely. lit., lip chopping.
to stretch, as tapa to free from wrinkles; taut. fig., to concentrate the thoughts.
five times, especially said of medicines given once a day for five days or five successive times morning and evening.
reported to be a kind of grass used in thatching.
taboo on approaching a chief from behind (same taboo as kuaʻā, kuakapu, kua liholiho, kuapala). lit., critical back.
to overturn, as an unfinished canoe.
to block, obstruct, hinder (less used than ālai).
four generations removed, of a great-great-grandparent or great-great-grandchild, as kupuna kualua, moʻopuna kualua; for some speakers, three generations removed.
continuous record, history, story, succession of events.
clamps used in making or repairing canoes.
a tapa used in sorcery ceremonies.
a shellfish, something like the kuapoʻi.
to do a thing grudgingly; bored with a tedious task; tedious, boring; to struggle with a task, as one in which one has no interest.
Kauaʻi name for māono, a basalt.
verdant mountain, where all thrives and grows.
a taboo chief who had the right to carry a pala fern in ceremonies.
sacrificial or offering stand for fruit.
an inedible moss applied to sores (no data).

• heap, pile; to heap or pile up; heaped up; 
   • numerous.
the chiton (Acanthochiton viridis), a small sea creature used in the māwaewae ceremony for babies.
taboo night proclaimed in month of ʻIkuwā during the makahiki festivals.
weatherboard covering canoe top fore and aft.
shell on back of crab or turtle.
kneepan, patella; bone in arm or hand.
belt; to put on a belt.
hunchback; hunchbacked; hump, as of a camel.
dashing, slashing, as waves on a shore.
small tribute to a high chief.
a form of guava with white pulp (Psidium guajava), but otherwise like kuawa lemi.
lemon guava (Psidium guajava), a form of guava with sour, pink pulp. lit., lemon guava.
a form of guava (Psidium guajava) with sweet, pink pulp, thicker skin, and larger seeds than kuawa lemi. lit., sweet guava.
valley (awaawa). cf. awaawa. Used poetically, as follows.
dark caterpillar resembling the poko, cutworm, about 5 cm or less in length; it feeds on grass and comes in great numbers.
overexposure to the sun; excessive ultraviolet rays.

• long repetitious prayer said at luakini dedication ceremonies, 
   • hence repetitiousness in general; 
   • to repeat, 
   • to wander, digress, perhaps senselessly.
a shrub in the carnation family (Schiedea lychnoides), endemic to Kauaʻi; leaves broad-ovate, 4 to 5 cm long, flowers many and small said to be named for a place on Kauaʻi.
altar or place of worship in a private house.
a kind of lichen (Peltigera polydactyla var. dolichorhiza).
first brewage of liquor; mixtures following are called pōkiʻi, little brother or sister.
same as nēnē, a variety of kava. lit., turtle back.
to remove internal organs of animals, disembowel; to clean, as chickens.
upper ridgepole of a house above the lower ridgepole (kauhuhu). see illus. 1, illus. 2, illus. 3, illus. 4
ribbed or grooved tapa, as made with a grooved board.

severe taboo on approaching a chief from behind; having such a taboo. lit., flaming back, perhaps so called because infringement of the taboo was punished by death; a person with this taboo might not lend out any garment that had touched his back, or permit anyone to touch his back.
country (as distinct from the city), countryside; person from the country, rustic, backwoodsman; of the country, countrified, rustic, rural. lit., back land.
yoke of a dress; back of a garment; ox yoke.

poles used in quilt making; the three unsewed quilt layers are placed on one another with the kua, poles, rolled into each end; the entirety is set over wooden horses and is stretched taut, so that the sewer may sew the layers together.
var. of akua, god, image, especially after -a (cf. hoa kua). cf. also Kealakekua [Ke-ala-ke-kua] (place name), the pathway [of] the images.
to attract ʻuaʻu, petrel birds, to a net by imitating their call, kue, kue, kue!
to shake a tapa in a way that seems innocent but that will bring a curse upon the person to whom the motion is directed.
sound of tapping, tap, as of a mallet on a tapa anvil; to tap-tap.
to shake, tremble, vibrate, swing back and forth, as a waving kāhili, feather emblem.
able to move only slightly, as one hurt in an accident or as one near death.
completely stuffed, packed, as after overeating.

• vagabond, exile, wanderer; wandering, 
   • friendless, 
   • homeless, 
   • unstable.
call to attract ʻuaʻu, petrel birds, believed in imitation of their sound.
fishhook with point of hook curved inward almost to the shaft, used for large fish.
saliva, spittle, sputum, expectoration; to spit, expectorate.
children of a high chief by a secondary wife or of second degree collaterality.
same as ʻōkuhe, a variety of ʻoʻopu, a fish.
of changed color, as of a bonito that is caught; black-and-blue, as after a bruise.
to suppose wrongly, err in judgment, give wrong directions; to mistake a person for someone else; erroneous supposition, illusion.
certain priests of Lono who marked land boundaries with ʻalaea coloring; to mark thus.
blundering, off one's course; to give wrong directions.
directing, pointing out, gesturing, reference, instruction, program, director.

seer, soothsayer, necromancer, especially a class of priests who advised concerning building and locating of temples, homes, fish ponds, hence a professional architect. lit., point out the sand dunes.
to point out and interpret signs in the sky; a reader of signs in the sky.
to keep others doing one's bidding, lord it over others, domineer, bossy.
minister of interior, in the days of the monarchy; secretary of interior.

powerful officer in the days of the monarchy. Kaʻahumanu was the first to have this title; the position is usually translated as 'prime minister' or 'premier,' but according to Kuykendall (see References), carried greater power; the kuhina nui shared executive power with the king. The office was abolished in 1864.
minister, premier, regent, ambassador, secretary, diplomat, cabinet member; highest officer next to the king; officer in the king's guard.
fat, rich, satiated with rich or fatty food. (See kuhikuhi₂ and -nia).
an endemic lobelia (Lobelia hypoleuca), 60 to 120 cm high, with narrow, white-backed leaves 30 to 45 cm long, and bluish flowers in racemes.

• to point, pointing
   • gesture,  gesturing,
        as in speaking, 
        directing an orchestra, 
        or dancing the hula;

• to suppose, infer, presume, assume,
   • think,  
   • expect, 
   • surmise, 
   • imagine.
to thicken, as scrambled eggs; to become pasty; to gel.
dove, turtledove (Kin. 15.9) ; cooing of a dove.

• to plop, splash, as a stone dropping into water, or as a leaping fish; 
   • sound of a deep cough.
awl, gimlet. lit., piercing sharp instrument.
large needle, as for darning or on a sewing machine. lit., steering instrument.
carpet tacks. lit., sharp instruments for nailing mats.
to string flowers, beads, seeds, shells into leis; a lei stringer.
one who decorates the chief in finest apparel; to decorate the chief thus; decorated elegantly. lit., string red leis.
to go arm in arm, to hold hands; arm in arm.
wooden peg, especially as made of hardwood and used in mending bowls.
covering made of dried ti leaves attached to a netting of olonā fibers or hibiscus, and worn as a rain cape.
staple, as for wire. lit., bent nail.
large, curved needle as used in sewing gunny sacks.
stickpin, common pin; lit., pin to attach.
metal binder, as in a notebook.
old form for kukui, candlenut, light (commonly used on Niʻihau).
prayer committed to memory and recited in unison during luakini (temple) dedications (Malo 171); to repeat, pray.
a stringing together, as of leis.
method of making a hat lei by sewing leaves and flowers to a pandanus strip; to make such a lei. lit., string on a base.
to carry under the arm; to escort arm in arm. lit., string armpit.
raincoat. lit., oiled coat, so called because early raincoats were made of oiled unbleached muslin.
sycamine, a tree mentioned by Jesus; according to (Harper), a mulberry, probably the black variety.
a rough lemon (Citrus limonia), liked for the fragrance of the skin, but too sour to eat. lit., having the nature of the kane skin fungus.
to push with elbows and shoulders, as forcing a way through a crowd; to blow violently, as wind, to bluster, rage, as waves or storm.
thin type of adze (2.5 or 4 cm wide), as used for finer work in handicraft.
customs, duty; to be on duty or watch.

• strong desire, whether good or bad; lust, compulsion; to lust, desire; 
   • to think about, as approaching death.
general name for any nut not native to Hawaiʻi.
projector, as for lantern slides; magic lantern.

• candlenut tree (Aleurites moluccana), a large tree in the spurge family bearing nuts containing while, oily kernels which were formerly used for lights;    • hence the tree is a symbol of enlightenment.    • the nuts are still cooked for a relish (ʻinamona).    • the soft wood was used for canoes,    • gum from the bark was used for painting tapa;    • black dye was obtained from nut coats and from roots,    • (nuts were chewed and spat into the sea by men fishing with nets for parrot fish (kākā₄ uhu₁) in order to calm the sea (FS 38–9): see ex. pili₁).    • polished nuts are strung in leis;    • the silvery leaves and small white flowers are strung in leis as representative of Molokaʻi, as designated in 1923 by the Territorial legislature.    • the kukui was named the official emblem for the State of Hawaii in 1959 because of its many uses and its symbolic value.    • kukui is one of the plant forms of Kamapuaʻa that comes to help him (FS 215).    • called kuikui on Niʻihau.
sound of boiling water; to sound thus; sputtering.
redup. of kula, school; to go to school.
knee; to kneel; to crouch or lie as an animal, with feet under the body.
Hawaiian stilt bird (Himantopus himantopus). Also aeʻo, fig., a thin, long-legged person.
a crab, often qualified by the terms kea, white, and ʻōhuluhulu, hairy.
mangrove (Bruguiera gymnorhiza); calyx of a mangrove, as used in leis. lit., ray of the sun.
to do with great enthusiasm, with might and main.
clubfoot; one with a twisted or deformed foot.
practice of telling stories all night, especially to a chief. lit., spreading tales dawn.
storyteller; to recite, narrate, recount; to join words together coherently. lit., joining speech.
physic nut (Jatropha curcas), a tropical American shrub or small tree with soft wood, milky juice, and very poisonous seeds. Like the kukui, it is in the spurge family.

• beam, as of a house; 
   • stick, as used to support and distend a net.
redup. of kū₁, to stand, stop, rise, hit... ; crowded.
day school. lit., school daily going.
primary school, kindergarten. lit., children's school.
gathering place of birds, as near water or food; plain with birds; tree branch that is gummed or smeared to attract birds.
boarding school. lit., school staying fixed.
chest-slapping game; the player attempts to push opponent out-of-bounds with his open palms.
to tilt, rock, reel, sway, toss and pitch; wobbly, shaky, unsteady. fig., insecure, hesitant.
fuchsia (Fuchsia magellanica), an introduced plant so called because of resemblance of flower to an earring.
sport in which players attempted to unseat one another by pushing with their feet. lit., foot pushing.
to push, shove, etc., in two ways or with great force.
plain, field, open country, pasture. An act of 1884 distinguished dry or kula land from wet or taro land.

right, privilege, concern, responsibility, title, business, property, estate, portion, jurisdiction, authority, liability, interest, claim, ownership, tenure, affair, province; reason, cause, function, justification; small piece of property, as within an ahupuaʻa; blood relative through whom a relationship to less close relatives is traced, as to in-laws.
dividends. (Will 129, island of Maui, State Archives, 1856.)
owned land (common term in wills of the 1860s).
to doze; too drowsy to hear (a deeper sleep than kulu hiamoe). lit., sleep deafly.
stingy, penurious, niggardly, deaf. lit., solid deafness.
design with zigzag stripes, in tapas, mats, and quilts. lit., bent knees.
knee. (A mother would rap a disobedient child on the knee: see hoʻokuli; knocking on the knee was also a sign of stinginess: the person referred to is deaf , kuli₂,  to appeal for generosity).
deafness, deaf person, noise, racket; deaf, noisy, loud.

having no wife, children, or relatives (name derived from a lone mulberry tree growing in a cave at Kūloli, Kona, Hawaiʻi, which was known as ka wauke kū kahi a Kūloli, the lone mulberry tree of Kūloli); also said of any very young wauke plant.
perfect, without error, as a prayer.
sap from green kukui nuts, used to prevent infections in cuts and as a gargle for sore throat and thrush.
accustomed to, acquainted with, intimate with; customary, usual, chronic.
endemic small trees and shrubs (Nototrichium spp.), with small more or less hairy leaves, and downy catkin-like flower spikes.
timber used in houses, as sticks, posts; fuel sticks.
to be late at night. kulu aumoe is more common.

• traitor, turncoat; traitorous; to betray; 
   • to abuse one who has been kind to one.
(rare in conversation, Biblical). The origin is uncertain. Ellis (1827:479) suggests that the old term may have been kumu ma, beginning and; perhaps kumu assimilated to kuma before mā.
to set in order, as in laying stones.
cracking of the skin between fingers and toes, as with athlete's foot.
teaching, source of learning, teacher, tutor.
beginning of the world, creation, origin of the earth.
means of propagation, source of progeny.
herd of cattle (less common than pūʻā pipi).
staff or five lines on and between which music is written.
groin, joining of leg and torso. lit., source of thigh.
topic, subject (as topic of discourse or grammatical subject); matter. (kumu₁ + -hana, nominalizer.)
kind of lashing used on outrigger of a chief's canoe.
concoction made of gourd vine and kukui nuts.
lamp, not including the chimney; candlestick. lit., lamp base.
constitution, law code, provision of law. lit., source of laws.
female who has produced young, as of horse, cow, pig, chicken; to have produced young, female; root with many sprouts, propagating plant (rare); major source.
providers of ti leaves for hukilau seining.
name of a disease, perhaps jaundice.

origin, genesis, source of life, mystery; name of the Hawaiian creation chant (see (KL) and (Johnson 1982). written kumu uli po in (Malo text, ch.1, sec. 11). [Malo (2005 ptg): ch.1, sec. 11 (p.2) has kumulipo.] MUS
a crab (Simocarcinus simplex) commonly found in līpoa seaweed. lit., līpoa source. Perhaps also makuaokalīpoa.
topic, subject, essay, tract; text, as of a sermon; proposition, theory.
any type of green Hawaiian stone, as used for maika stones.
an endemic fern (Doryopteris spp.), with broadly heart-shaped fronds, spore-bearing on edges.
sleeping mat thicker at one end than the other, with the thicker end used as a pillow.
perhaps a net used in bag-net fishing.
sandbank; sandstone, used for maika stones. lit., sand base.

• firm foundation, firmly established,
   • ancient times
family god (same as the much more common ʻaumakua).
kind of lashing on canoe outrigger.
tortoise-shell handle as on a kāhili staff.

• an article bought, sold or exchanged; 
   • price.
itch, scabies; scabby skin condition; to itch.

• weariness, fatigue; 
   • to stagger, reel, totter with fatigue.
fire kindler; to kindle or light a fire.

a type of kuni practiced while the sick person was still alive but showed symptoms of being prayed to death. It resulted in the death of the sorcerer and saved the life of the intended victim. To practice such.
to heal one afflicted with illness from another's ʻanāʻanā.

type of black magic that results in the death of a sorcerer, achieved by burning an object taken from the corpse of the sorcerer's victim; to practice kuni. Pebbles and kukui nuts used for discovering the sorcerer were wrapped in tapa such as ʻaeokahaloa, ʻēkahaloa, ʻōʻūholowai, and puakai.
to broil on coals, as of meat, fish.
love prayer used by a kahuna hana aloha to invoke love in one of the other sex.
a large cowry, probably Cypraea reticulata.
kind of fishhook, said to resemble the top of a cowry shell.
probably all endemic species of a genus of sedges (Rhynchospora), with tufted stems, numerous narrow leaves, and clusters of small brown flower spikelets.

• to rub, 
   • scrub, scour, 
   • polish, 
   • scratch.
to tremble, as the voice; to shake, as with palsy; to vibrate, resonate, as a chanting voice.
to walk gently, slowly, softly; to lag behind.
surprising, strange, wonderful, amazing, extraordinary, unaccountable, marvelous; astonishing situation.

• small, diminutive,
   • dwarfish, 
   • humble, 
   • of low rank; 
   • of retarded growth.
a variety of kava with very small leaf.
a dark-red cowry shell, as used for octopus lures.
soup, stew; to boil, make soup or stew; boiled.
cooper; to do the work of a cooper.
an edible bivalve found at Pearl Harbor, possibly Chama species.
canoe manu made of one piece.
to stumble, twist the ankle. fig., to misstep, err in conduct.
a hula step: with the feet still and the knees bent, the body swings three times quite low down to the right, over to the left, and up.
to steer a canoe; canoe endpieces.
long, narrow fern (Nephrolepis duffii), with numerous short lateral divisions to the frond. lit., small-leafed fern.
a fern (Thelypteris boydiae, synonym Dryopteris cyatheoides var. depauperatum).
rose geranium (Pelargonium graveolens), flowers pink, leaves fragrant, used in leis with odorless flowers.  Also kupukupu haole and laniuma.
general name for ferns on a single stem, such as kupukupu₃.

sword fern (Nephrolepis exaltata), a long, narrow fern with many lateral divisions; it was sometimes added to the hula altar to Laka, for knowledge to kupu (sprout). Also niʻaniʻau and palapalai on Niʻihau, and ʻōkupukupu.
great grandparent, great grandaunt or uncle.
to flourish, grow vigorously, mature early, as an adolescent.
an endemic genus of small trees (Broussaisia), with a few forms, in the saxifrage family. lit., mountain sprout.

hero, wondrous one, so called because the hero of tales often as a youth was mischievous and fond of plundering taro or stealing chickens (as Kamapuaʻa), a means of showing his exemption from the taboos of ordinary men.

considerable spelling variation exists between kuw- and ku-, as kuwala, kuala; kuwelo, kuelo; kūwō, kūō. Both variants are listed in the dictionary, but the definition follows the preferred form, which is usually kū- unless the remainder of the entry exists as a separate word, or begins with a long vowel.
to make a din, talk loudly, resound. see wā₃ and chant, kūmaumau₃.
prayer for special events, as trimming grass from over the door of a grass house, or completion of a new canoe or net.
lonely, forsaken, barren, desolate, dreary. fig., awkward, unintelligent, ignorant.
boom connecting canoe hulls of a double outrigger.
bank or border of a taro patch; stream bank.
to push aside; to move back and forth, as a fan belt.
eyebrow. see ex., nunu₂, and saying, ʻeaʻea.
to push with the elbows, to elbow; to move back and forth, as a piston or as the action of the tide.
art of lua fighting; to fight thus.
to pound and shape iron; to forge; blacksmith.
one who makes brass articles, metalsmith, tinsmith; to work with brass, copper, bronze; to pound brass.
molar tooth yellow with age; insulting reference to old person.
boxer, pugilist, pugilism; to strike with the fist.
to add on, increase, punch doubly hard, etc.
to make palu relish or bait; to pound into fine pieces, to beat to a pulp, thresh, demolish.
to pummel, pound, abuse horribly. lit., pound pelt.
to beat flat. lit., pound crush.
to pound food, especially poi; one who pounds food, as poi.
privileged and trusted persons in a chief's retinue. lit., join [at] late night.

• hesitating, uncertain, undecided, wavering; 
   • hurt in feelings
to swing and hit, as with a war club [this is the name of the club of the legendary hero, Kawelo].
sculpturing; to carve and shape an image; ceremonial making of the makahiki festival image, Lono-makua
redup. of kuʻi₁, to pound, punch, strike, box, hit, hammer...; boxing, prize fight; to box.
liquid medicine made of the sap of the ʻakoko tree.
to toll or ring, as a bell.
chief supporting a chief, a chief's mainstay. lit., inside joint.
tapa bed covering, consisting of five layers stitched together at one end; the inner four (iho) were white, the outer was designed (kilohana).
blow, punch; peal, as of thunder.
joint, joining, seam, junction. fig., center, key.
quiet and still, without rustling; weird solitary quietness of a deep forest.
roaring, as of the sea; to roar.
deflated. fig., discouraged. lit., punch swelling.
a variety of sweet potato. lit., decayed molar.
to disseminate news; to spread, as news.
move in the kōnane game. See (For. 4:57).
to drop to one's knees; to bend the knees, as while genuflecting.
to release a word, make known.
to let down gradually, slack off a little at a time.
small, short-legged spider, so called because it lowers itself (kuʻu) on a single string fiber.
unrestrained, promiscuous, wanton (Iak. 5.5) ; free to do as one wants, whether right or wrong.
place where a net is set in the sea; to let down a fish net.
to do with all one's might or strength, exert oneself; to go the limit; to release all checks, inhibitions, restraints.
type of net let down from a canoe; gill net; to set or lower a net or catch in a net.
ceremonial throwing of spears at a high chief returning from a voyage; he dodges or catches the spears to show his courage and skill; to hurl thus.
death by sorcery. lit., death indeed from someone else.

ceremony initiating boys, usually at age of six, after which they were permitted to wear a malo and join the men in the mua, men's house; henceforth they might not eat with women; to perform the ceremony. lit., thrust to the mua house.
dye container, probably so called because the edge of the container was hit (kā) with the bamboo stamp to dislodge excess dye before printing the tapa.
to thatch the inside of the house with leaves, especially pandanus leaves. lit., knot leaf.
to dash to death, hurl down, as a foe in lua fighting; to doom to death.
a game in which one player lay rigid or limp on his back while the other player tried to lift him off the ground. lit., to fish with a human pole.
the one of.  (This is probably short for ka mea o)
canoe bailer; to bail a canoe.
the local, as kā ʻaneʻi paia, the walls here (a-class; cf. kō ʻaneʻi).
to catch ʻōhiki crabs with a nohu blossom as bait.
inclusiveness, in the first person dual and plural pronouns kāua, kākou.
non-productive caus/sim. prefix similar to hoʻo-.

amberjack or yellowtail (Seriola dumerilii). Kāhala ʻōpio is S. aureovittata. The name may be qualified also by maoli and moku lei. Āmuka is a variant name or a name for the adult stage. Another name is mokuleʻia.
ripe, said of a gourd with stem beginning to wither.
net made of strong cord, used for sharks.
clearing, as in a forest. Kaʻū.
to diminish, abate, lessen, as a storm or sickness.
to call to someone who is leaving (this was believed to bring bad luck, because the departing person had to change his plans).
a call to come and eat; a prayer calling on the gods to come and share the food.
pool, especially a rock basin where the sea washes in through an opening and salt forms; salt pan.
plural and diminutive of kāheka; small sea pool or pools; artificial salt pan.
redup. and intensifier of kāhela₁, to lie spread out...; to sprawl, kāhela₂, a hula step, kāhela₃, gourd drumbeat:...
gourd drumbeat: the gourd is thumped down on a pad; it is then raised with the left hand and is struck with two quick slaps of the fingers of the right hand.
decorated for a journey, as with a lei.
to weed and stir up the soil.
to miss, fail, not succeed; to hit by mistake; foiled or thwarted in an attempt.
red stains or streaks, as at dawn; bloody.
to catch fish with a scoop or hand net.
to slip flowers from the stringing needle to the string.
to train or practice, as for foot races.
entanglement, perplexity, involvement, blocking; entangled, choked, as by weeds; blocked, involved, as with the law (Mat. 5.40),  trapped, framed (slang).
war finery, formerly, shield, helmet, feather cape.
finery, ornaments; to wear finery, dress up; to harness.
medical combination of juices of the gourd and the puʻukaʻa sedge.
small kāhili carried in the hand.
the crape myrtle (Lagerstroemia indica), an ornamental shrub from China, with small oval leaves and panicles of pink, white, or purple crapy flowers.

a small tree (Grevillea banksii) from Australia, related to the silky oak, ʻoka kilika, but the leaves with fewer subdivisions and the flowers red or cream-white. This is a later application of kāhili to a plant. Flowers not used for leis on head or around neck because of it irritating hairs, but made into leis for hats by sewing alternate rows of flower clusters and own leaves on pandanus band.
Kāhili ginger (Hedychium gardnerianum), from the Himalaya region; much like the white ginger but with a more open flower head, the flowers with narrow yellow segment and one bright-red stamen apiece.
to knock down, take advantage of, deceive.
to rub with oil, grease, petroleum jelly; to anoint (kā-₂ + hinu).
dark pupil, as of the eye (kā- + hiwa).
to lean to one side (kā-₂ + hinu). cf. the more common hiō.
kind of sorcery prayer spoken in a moderate or natural voice.
to strike, break; to strike of a fish at a hook (ka-₂ + hoa).
beginning of a chant, with others then joining in; to begin a chant.
hasty, nimble, swift, quick; to move fast, progress rapidly. cf. holo, to run; pule kāholo.
to sew with long stitches; basting; sennit lashings on royal canoes.

the "vamp" hula step, more common in modern than in ancient dance, consisting of four counts: (1) one foot is extended to the side, (2) the other is brought alongside, (3, 4) this is repeated on the same side; then the four steps are repeated on the opposite side; to execute this step.
level landing place, as after fording a stream or coming down from a cliff.
unsteady, shaky, rickety, variable, unsettled; to sway, reel, tip, rock, totter; tossed about, as a ship.
sport or mutant, as of sweet potato.
place where food is cooked in an underground oven, as in a cookhouse; tending of the oven.
to sprinkle tightly, especially with salt.
large, fat, plump, as of a well-fed dog.
interj. of suprise, wonder, displeasure; to wonder, be surprised, astonished, amazed, puzzled; surprise, astonishment.
first appearance of young caterpillars on vines, especially of sweet potatoes; to be eaten by caterpillars. Kaʻū.
of disapproval or disbelief; the vowels are sometimes nasalized and the last two greatly leangthened, spoken with rising inflection. Horrors!

• runner on sweet potato vine; 
   • string of fish, string or fiber of any kind on which fish are strung.
hit, struck; strike! destroy (said by a sorcerer invoking eternal destruction upon a victim); incantation.
to grow irregular and scrubby, as unpruned hau trees
Panicum colliei, kind of grass. Niʻihau.
strip of barren land near the sea shore; shoal.

handle, as of a bucket, pot, basket, purse; strings by which a netted (kōkō) calabash is hung; woman's scarf (Niʻihau); to tie on; to encircle with a band, specifically, to stretch the taboo cord before the entrance of a chief's house (this cord was said to fall of its own accord if a relative approached).
ancient name of a disease, the symptoms of which suggest appendicitis in various stages.
a disease whose symptoms suggest appendicitis.
black with brown markings, of a pig.

gray nickers (Caesalpinia major, misidentified locally as C. crista), a straggly bramble, a pantropical vine indigenous to Hawaiʻi, with thorny branches and leaf stems and with small yellow flowers. Within each large spiny pod are two or three gray marble-like seeds, which are used for leis, also powdered for medicine.
yellow nickers (Caesalpinia bonduc), today commonly called Hawaiian pearls, similar to the gray nickers, but with yellowish-gray instead of gray seeds. Also hihikolo.
sharp spurs of a fighting cock.
octopus hook used with a stone sinker and a cowry shell.

• surf comber; to form combers; 
   • to blow in gusts.
mature, of a gourd, with a dry stem.
royal scribe; writer of chronology or history of chiefs.
to sign a name, register, as for voting or as at a university; to endorse, enroll; sign, signature, autograph, registration, recorder.
to make lines, print, mark, paint, tattoo.
author, writer of stories; secretary or recorder.
solid tattoo pattern; to tattoo thus.
secretary, clerk, scribe; to act as secretary.
young but fully marked and fully developed fish.
to shift or roll, as the eyes.
to rub with oil, to mix or stew with sauce or gravy.
to cast with hook and line, as for ulua.

• to slide, skid, glide, 
   • to go rambling at will and hence to do as one pleases.
slimy, as mucus; to hang, as mucus.
to cross the arms high in front, with hands on shoulders; to cross the hands behind the back (either was considered a curse and highly insulting).
to nail down, to wedge or fasten tightly; nail, pin, wedge.
to strike (kā) with a side stroke or obliquely; to strike in order to ensnare or catch in a noose; crooked, bent, curved.
to grow by ground layering; plant so grown. cf. laʻa. fig., chain, succession:

• to strike at, 
   • aim at, 
   • smite (FS 89); 
   • to brandish threateningly, as a war club (FS 61).
mange, impetigo, itch, itching pustules of the skin.
to charge, as a bill; a charge, bill.
to tie a slipknot securely, but so that it can be loosened with one jerk at the end of the rope; slipknot.
to stop, hinder, especially of a firebrand hurled in the old fire-throwing sport.
a native grass (Panicum torridum), 30–70 cm. high, covered with silky, light-colored hairs, the cone-shaped flowering panicle 7.8 to 16 cm long, coated with silky hair.
to uphold, support, favor, assist, prop up; to bind, as with a sash or belt; support, aid, recommendation, girdle.
to bind or fasten on, as a sarong or belt.
to worship the gods, especially by food offerings; to appeal to the gods.
to torture to death by flaying or piercing. lit., strike poke.
a cuplike dish, usually of stone, used to hold tapa-printing or tattooing dye.
clumsy, awkward-moving, gangling, blundering in speech, uncouth in manner and speech; rambling, as a road.
raw salted meat; to cut raw meat into large pieces and salt it. lit., chop raw.
hunks of cooked meat scored and salted for preservation; to prepare cooked meat thus.
visible spirit of a living person.
Molokaʻi creeper (Loxops maculata flammea); the male is largely scarlet; the female and the immature male are brown with scarlet markings. lit., wood chopping.
odorous, either fragrant or otherwise; to make an odor.
to excrete; dirty, excreta (a euphemism, taught to children).
to fish, as for uhu, parrot fish, with a square net (FS 39) or ulua with hook and line but no pole; net or nets dropped in a semicircle in shallow water, as for mullets or ʻōʻio.

to sacrifice food (fish, bananas, kava) to the gods, as at every meal; to feed the spirits of the dead; to deify a dead relative by food offerings and prayer; to dedicate the dead to become family protectors (ʻaumākua) or servants of ʻaumākua (HM, p. 123); to transfigure, transfiguration (Kam. 64: 64, 91). (Contraction of kākua ʻai)
the barracuda (Sphyraena barracuda), as long as 60 cm.
gourd calabash, as used for fishing.
weft strands of mat, so called because the strands are worked (kā) to run up (kū) from the worker.
sculptor, wood carver; to make statues.
stone cutter (2-Sam. 5:11) ; to carve or hew stone.
canoe carver; to build a canoe.
to plot evil, concoct mischief, contrive secretly to destroy by witchcraft or treachery. lit., carve evil.
counselor, prime minister, high official; to perform such office. lit., manage island.

name of three woods (kauila, nīoi, ʻohe) believed to be the tree forms of two male gods (Kāneikaulana-ʻula and Kahuilaokalani) and one goddess (Kapo); the wood was considered deadly poisonous at Mauna Loa, Molokaʻi only; small pieces of the wood and roots were used in black magic.
financial, as a committee or bill.
political; politics; political economy. lit., land carving.
to go around to the back from the side.
curve, as in the road or along a beach.
to go from one side to another.
intermittent pains in the side of the neck, probably neuritis.
to hold and carry, as a pail.
stick dancing; to stick dance; dancing stick (KAN). sometimes this term is applied to fencing instead of the more frequent kākā lāʻau.
swelling, probably due to failing circulation.
to lean on in a rude fashion; to lean heavily; to press down hard.
to lean back, to lean over the outrigger of a fast canoe to keep the canoe from capsizing. fig. to relax, lead an easy life.
to flap, wave, flutter, as sails of a ship; to luff.

trader, merchant, salesman, peddler; to trade, sell as merchandise, peddle; mercantile. trading (HE). lit., to strike flag, so called because a salesman hoisted a small flag to show that poi or another article was for sale.
same as peʻa, canoe sail, as made of young pandanus leaves.
place near the luakini, temple, where the ruling chief and a few others stood apart from the multitude.
prayer calling on the ʻaumākua, family gods, for help; to pray thus.
garlic.  See more common ʻakaʻakai pūpū.
corset, girdle, tight waist binder, suspenders; to tie, as a corset.
brassiere, corset cover. lit., breast corset.
dying, at death's door; to lie hovering between life and death. (kā-₂ + lilo, lost.)
long vine, as of sweet potato.
to hurl spears at a chief as he landed from a canoe, in order that he might exhibit his dexterity and courage in dodging them, almost a ritual.
